movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers definitely get the visuals right across the board. Things go wrong elsewhere, however.
The best of this year's family-friendly film explosion so far.
Its celebration of the importance of the family unit makes it a family film in the truest sense of the term.
Alone in the Dark is amateurish at best and asinine at worst.
The actors playing the live-action incarnations of the show's characters do them justice.
From the perspective of pure entertainment, Alfie is never boring and always easy on the eyes.
For those who need proof that the National Lampoon brand of humor ain't what it used to be, National Lampoon's Gold Diggers does more than illustrates how far the mighty have fallen.
Serves as an insightful primer for the uninitiated.
Yu-Gi-Oh! The Movie keeps the kid-friendly spirit of the show while raising the stakes enough to justify a serviceable big-screen treatment.
Surprisingly sharp, if convoluted, romantic comedy.
Unoriginal, unrelentingly vulgar and, worst, unfunny.
A lean, mean revenge picture that works on a purely visceral level.
A smart but safe parable about how power can corrupt even the best of men, and how complacency is not a virtue.
Torque is like a grease stain on your favorite shirt - dirty, maddening and unnecessary.
Looks and sounds first-rate, but is saddled with a cliche- and stereotype-riddled story.
With The Haunted Mansion, the second movie this year to be based on a popular Disney attraction Eddie Murphy may have finally brought his career back to life.
Although it succumbs to overt audience manipulation when the story loses steam, Radio tunes in some solid performances from a skilled cast, led by Cuba Gooding Jr. and Ed Harris.
The Rock does have a winning screen presence, even when the material falls short.
Perry's performance as Madea may have worked onstage, but seems out of place on the screen, even though it's clear he has a great deal of affection for the character.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie finally manages to find its groove in the when director Bille Woodruff steps aside and allows his talented cast to mine the material for all it's worth.

Ice Cube brings his trademark charisma and street sensibility to a film that wouldn't be nearly as entertaining without it, though he gets considerable help from better-than-the-material-deserves performances by Jackson and Dafoe.
With too many twists and false alarms, chances are not too many people are going to care.
Some of the bits work; just as often, they don't. Black and Gass' appealing rapport masks those problems for a while, but eventually, they, too, wear out their welcome.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining popcorn movie featuring a veritable who's who of game British actors (and a trio of equally game American performers) who keep the proceedings lively even with a too-predictable plot.
If you have the time and densely plotted potboilers are your thing, it's worth the trip.
... if there was ever a role that The Rock was born to play, he's found it here
... an American remake of a European original that works.
A welcome throwback to the ways of old-school kung fu movies, The Protector doesn't hold up to scrutiny if you're looking for a coherent story or powerhouse acting.
Works overtime to inspire audiences, but relies way too much on pop-mysticism and half-baked artifice to make its point stick.
Marlon's no-limits performance, relying only on his voice and facial expressions, proves to be the film's strongest asset.
Even though it stars a Disney sitcom actor, Cabin Fever is not for kids -- or for anyone else with intelligence.
Squanders a premise that's filled with comic gold by playing it too safe.
A dramatized, sometimes compelling retelling of the beginnings of the program depicted in Mad Hot Ballroom.
While not a laugh-out-loud comedy, Something New offers enough moments of genuine humor mixed in with the predictable pathos, thanks in part to its adept ensemble cast.
Made with the intention to scare moviegoers silly, and it succeeds.
More bewildering than entertaining.
A better-than-expected parable -- inspired by actual events -- about the power and reach of corruption.
James and Strait make the most of the material, even though there's no real mystery as to how things are going to work out.
Meanders from one overblown action sequence to the next, without bringing along for the ride the goofy charm of the show on which it's based.
Li's best English-language movie to date.
A respectable if not entirely worthy addition to the burgeoning neo-noir film genre.
Entertaining enough that kids might not even mind the history lessons along the way.
Considering how inconsequential the first film was, it should come as no surprise that the second installment is nearly as trivial.
In a summer filled with overcooked turkeys, it's a refreshingly irreverent snack.
An airy, scrumptious valentine of a romantic fable.
A psychological thriller heavy on schmaltz and light on brains and originality.
Just when Joe Dirt thought it had a lock on being this year's worst film, along comes Jeepers Creepers snatching that distinction from its grasp.
Summer Catch aims to be a Generation X Bull Durham but ends up falling somewhere between Major League and The Bad News Bears All Grown Up.
There may be some arguments over Li's work as an actor, but his physical performance more than makes up for any other on-screen shortcomings.
The effortless charm the first outing possessed is taxed to the point of exhaustion in Dr. Dolittle 2.
One of the funnier, well-acted comedies to come down the pike in a while.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A nail biter so meticulous in its plotting and so intoxicating in its marathon-like pacing that once it's over, you feel as psychologically taxed, yet emotionally relieved.
There's nothing particularly groundbreaking about Tomcats, but it's still a fun way to spend 90 minutes -- at least if you enjoy cheap laughs and predictable fluff.
A preposterous collection of sight gags and lame special effects that doesn't amount to much of anything.
Can't sustain its silliness, and resorts to a rushed ending that rudely brings reality into the picture.
Do yourself, and film in general, a favor - stay away. Then maybe, just maybe, the movie studios will stop insulting our intelligence with such repugnant claptrap.
A melodramatic, adventure-filled feast for the cerebral senses that, despite its lack of originality, manages to somewhat captivate the action enthusiast in all of us.
An infectious film that successfully juxtaposes four seemingly different families during the most joyous and stressful time of the year.
Bait is one wild ride that goes down like iced tea on a hot, late-summer night.
Saving graces can't save Loser from keeping its name.
Lipnicki and Weeks share a great rapport and imbue all their scenes with playful energy that elevates the material to heights of imagination rarely achieved in films of this genre.
The film is smart enough to play up its melodramatic moments with assured authority.
In an age when self-acceptance and taking a hold of one's destiny is more relevant than ever, Big Eden may be the right inspirational movie for our evolving times.
Falters when it takes itself too seriously and when it depends too heavily on its otherwise talented cast to clown in situations that aren't funny.
A textbook example of how keeping it simple can yield big rewards -- and big laughs.
Still as high-octane the second time around, even if it's firing on a few different cylinders.
May not be in the same comedy league as the original, but it is amiable and action-packed, buoyed with two genuinely funny performances from Michael Douglas and Albert Brooks.
While it may not be off the hinges, It Runs in the Family is disarming enough that you won't exit the theater doors feeling like you've been hoodwinked.
An action-packed popcorn movie that never pretends to be anything but fast, loose and funny.
It's the hometown footage that really stands out amid the stand-up. With material like that, Griffin and family may have a pilot for a new reality show on their hands.
It's undone by narrative and continuity turbulence.
Manages to entertain and defy logic in equal measure.
Works in large part because you actually care about what happens to the characters.
The best summer action movie since 1994's Speed.
Shot and edited in typical rapid-fire MTV style, Biker Boyz is both arresting and dizzying to sit through.
Epps has neither the charisma nor the natural affability that has made Tucker a star.
The film gets so bogged down in style that its lack of substance is all the more apparent.
Hawn and Sarandon form an acting bond that makes The Banger Sisters a fascinating character study with laughs to spare.
A comedy that not only serves up the laughs, but also great-looking entrees and a dash of romance.
This is a throwaway, junk-food movie whose rap soundtrack was better tended to than the film itself.
Instead of letting the laughs come as they may, Lawrence unleashes his trademark misogyny -- er, comedy -- like a human volcano or an overflowing septic tank, take your pick.

As any creature-feature fan knows, when you cross toxic chemicals with a bunch of exotic creatures, you get a lot of running around, screaming and death. On that score, the film certainly doesn't disappoint.
Armed with a game supporting cast, from the pitch-perfect Forster to the always hilarious Meara and Levy, Like Mike shoots and scores, doing its namesake proud.
The mildly amusing buddy/action comedy is more over-the-top Lawrence fare.

Cedric the Entertainer doesn't really act here so much as riffs, as if he's working out the kinks in a misconceived stand-up routine. Some of his ad-libs are funny, but you know you're in trouble when the outtakes are funnier than the film as a whole.
Lathan and Diggs carry the film with their charisma, and both exhibit sharp comic timing that makes the more hackneyed elements of the film easier to digest.
The predictable story and hackneyed dialogue -- the interplay between April and Casey is particularly bad -- get in the way of the movie's slick and sleek visual style.
Surprisingly, considering it's made by the Farrellys, "Hall Pass" fails to take full advantage of its premise.
Director Ivan Reitman and the cast do what they can with the material, but it's hard to tell what "No Strings Attached" is trying to be.
Despite its shortcomings, including a predictable plot twist, "Faster" isn't the turkey you might expect it to be.
The use of 3-D to tell the story brings a great deal of dimension and scope to the story. Some scenes are so photo-realistic, you forget you're watching an animated film.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Except for a few of the cast members' better-than-the-material performances and a nifty opening sequence, the movie would be straight-to-video fare.
Some of the visual razzmatazz isn't as polished as it should be, but the dance sequences, especially the go-for-broke finale, more than compensate for that.
Despicable Me may not be up to Pixar's output, but its heart, and Carell's contribution to it, help get the movie into the same league.
Fans of the original can rest assured: Macchio was, and will continue to be, the true karate kid.
The romantic comedy Just Wright only halfway finds its footing as a comedy, and misses the mark entirely as a romance.

Seyfried has worked opposite some of the greatest actors in filmdom in recent years, including Meryl Streep and Julianne Moore. That she again holds her own, this time with Redgrave, is a measure of her talent.
Made in the spirit of an old-school farce, Death at a Funeral manages to find most of its fun through the interaction of its game cast, who clearly had a good time working together.

Television director Julie Anne Robinson's big-screen debut makes one thing clear: As likable a performer as she is, Cyrus simply can't act. Even Sparks' formulaic material proves too challenging for her.
How to Train Your Dragon is a visual marvel, and not just because it's in 3-D.
A surprisingly sweet-natured affair with solid performances.
It's a testament to the cast that the entire enterprise is more entertaining than it has a right to be.
Bogart and Bergman it's not.
It's been nearly eight years since his last starring role onscreen, but fans needn't worry: Mel Gibson still has the makings of a formidable action star.
"Your Highness," a largely improvised oddity, is as tired and clunky a movie spoof as you'll likely see this or any other year.
What it lacks in length, the 45-minute movie makes up in entertainment value.
A pale copy is still a pale copy, even when it's in 3-D. That's the moral of the animated sequel "Hoodwinked Too! Hood vs. Evil."

As great as it is to see both Bassett and Devine headlining a film, they are saddled with stereotypical characters - the uptown snob vs. the downtown sistah - that neither seems completely at home inhabiting.
It's a shame that nearly everything in the middle of Stomp the Yard is so predictable, because the opening and closing dance competitions are filled with amazing moves and other surprises.
By no means is "And So It Goes" a great romance. But seeing two seasoned pros like Douglas and Keaton together on-screen for the first time, even in an otherwise predictable effort, is pretty great.
As for Ealy and Bryant, you'd be hard-pressed to find two more attractive people working on the big screen - who still have barely passable chemistry together.
While it's still no "Big Chill," the sequel will mostly satisfy fans of the original "Best Man," especially since it brings back the entire cast of the first movie.
While the story is a bit convoluted, the easy rapport between Washington and Wahlberg makes this well-shot comedy-thriller far more engaging than it has any right to be.
While most film franchises sink as the number of their entries rises, "Fast and the Furious" keeps cruising along with no finish line in sight.

Even though it stars Oscar-winner Halle Berry, there's not much in "The Call" to set it apart from the women-in-peril movies that fill cable TV, thanks in large part to an unbelievably wrongheaded ending.
Plays like a sanitized remake of "Sleeping with the Enemy," right down to an over-the-top climax set during a fireworks display.
Sandra Bullock is two for three in 2009.
Despite a talented cast, the film's promising premise - old-school parenting vs. new-school kids - is mishandled.
Sandler fans likely will eat this nonsense up like ice cream. Non-fans could do worse - a lot worse. Like "Jack and Jill."
"Think Like a Man" is a rare thing: a studio-backed romantic comedy with a who's who of young, attractive, talented African-American actors who aren't relegated to thankless secondary roles.
With "This Means War," Oscar-winner Reese Witherspoon pulls off the seemingly impossible: She's made a film that's even worse than "Legally Blonde 2."

Featuring a mix of musical genres, "Joyful Noise" works best as a musical showcase for the formidable talents of Latifah and Parton. Without them, the film's lack of down-home soul would be even more glaring.
That the film ultimately doesn't quite gel is no fault of Atkinson's. He gives it his all in an agreeably engaging performance.
As outrageous as the proceedings get, "The Change-Up" is just too predictable. Even if you aren't old enough to remember those old body-swapping movies, you'll feel like you've seen this before.
Timberlake and Kunis manage to bring sexy and funny back to the otherwise exhausted rom-com genre.
Gibson knows a thing or two about lost, troubled souls, and watching him navigate around the edge of the abyss is fascinating.
[It] has a threadbare plot and marginal acting from its stars. But unlike the third movie, all the razzmatazz makes up for it this time.
Although Astro Boy has its moments, in a movie year already crowded with animated successes, it may not have the superhuman strength to stand out.
Both funny and romantic, "The Five-Year Engagement" runs a good 20 minutes longer than it should, but the winning on-screen chemistry between Segel and Blunt makes that a little easier to take.

While the increasingly surreal weather activity could be jarring for some small children, the movie is solid family entertainment all the way -- even while incorporating Public Enemy's still-incendiary anthem "Fight the Power" in its soundtrack.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even as the film's most stereotypical figure, stand-up comic Katt Williams manages to be the only consistently funny character in this uninspired inspirational comedy.
Everything you want a family film to be: clever, literate, and above all, engaging.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Queen Latifah often is the saving grace of many of the movies she's in. That can't be said of her latest, however.
Wholesome family entertainment with a life-affirming message.
A wry, smart and perceptive dramedy about family and life's other surprises.
A generic, predictable, family-friendly comedy that seems a better fit for the Disney Channel than for a theater near you.
There's a funny movie somewhere in Mr. Woodcock. It's too bad that the filmmakers weren't more mindful of the pot.
Unfortunately, it loses its sense of humor as it gets more desperate to find its way to the end.
Whether it's a hit or not, Rush Hour 3 has just enough story to justify reaching the screen. But let's hope the filmmakers stop while they're ahead.
Little more than a long-form music video that isn't that far removed from its direct-to-DVD animated predecessors.
What the film lacks in substance it more than makes up for in style.
As dark comedies go, You Kill Me nearly hits all the right targets, playing like a tongue-in-cheek hybrid of Prizzi's Honor and Clean and Sober.
In its cast, especially Bateman, The Ex has better material than it seems to know what to do with.
There are only so many ways to kill a person before it starts becoming utterly predictable, making things feel boring even as they become more harsh.
A solid effort with an insightful script and strong performances.
In addition to being a solid thriller, Disturbia is also a scathing indictment of life in suburbia and the movie gamely plays to teens while taking their angst to task.
Like its predecessor, Are We Done Yet? is amiable enough, but not enough to make it compelling.
This is another American remake of a European original that loses something in translation, in a story that never offers any real sense of tension or doubt about how it'll all end up.
How She Move is a solid addition to the dance genre's dance card.
This is, first and foremost, an actors' showcase, and the entire ensemble delivers.
Charlie Bartlett is an often-laugh-out-loud-funny comedy that takes aim at privileged WASP culture and the public school system with equal fervor.
The outcome isn't exactly in doubt, but the ride is pleasant enough along the way. Connell in particular gives a strong central performance, and a couple of the musical numbers are infectious.

Keeper, striving to manipulate the audience, goes on a little longer than it should. However, the performances are so true that it's easy to forgive such unneeded, straight-to-the-heartstrings tactics.
Surprisingly charming and smartly executed.
The Wayans brothers used to know how to do this right.
Fool's Gold, like its namesake, is a poor substitute for the real thing, which is feeling rarer all the time.
This enjoyable, if sometimes uneven, denouncement of consumerism run amok is clearly Fisher's show.
Chandni Chowk to China has something to offer every discerning film taste. And that's its major shortcoming.
Henson, in a role that could easily have degenerated into an angry-black-woman caricature, is better than the material deserves.
In a season soon to be filled with better-made family movies based on better-known material, the movie's serviceable-enough animation isn't likely to help it stand out.
The 3-D animated alien-invasion flick Battle for Terra upends well-worn conventions of the genre and packages them in a compelling story.
It's to the actors' credit that none of it feels forced or fake. In particular, Eisenberg's comic stylings and Harrelson's rock-'em-sock-'em performance really set the pace.

A tense and mostly satisfying take on race relations and the deep-seeded hatred some try to suppress, Lakeview Terrace realistically depicts such a heated scenario by giving equal voice to both sides.
These women, like the movie they're in, are far from perfect, but spending time in their company isn't an entirely unpleasant experience.
First-time director Sunu Gonera and cinematographer Matthew F. Leonetti's strong visuals save this otherwise formulaic undertaking from being interchangeable inspirational film.
Presented with humor but not at the expense of its subjects, American Teen was the toast of this year's Sundance Film Festival.
The dependable Chan and Li keep the proceedings lively, even though it's all fairly predictable. What they lack in material, they more than make up for in onscreen charisma.
Nim's Island is funny when it needs to be, serious when it's required and fantastical throughout.
In lieu of character development we get musical montages, and the film is sliced and diced more than all of Sweeney Todd's victims combined.
Visually striking from start to finish.

If you're the type of person who can offer a three minute impassioned defense of Fool's Gold or more than five reasons why Just Like Heaven is worth grabbing out of a five dollar bin, paying to see this movie is far from a horrible idea.
I recommend The Family in the same way I might mint-flavored gum. It's not what you would hope for, but when choosing at random, you'd do worse a little more often than not.
This movie would be exponentially better if it were called Twenty-Something Jobs or Jobs, Woz And The First 2 Apples.
It's unfair to say Machete Kills is boring and stupid, but it flirts with both of those adjectives far too often to be considered a good movie.
Clocking in at just over eighty minutes, Sarah Landon is a filmmaker's clinic in consistency: how to be consistently awful.
movie_title: Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour (2007)

movie_review_blurb: College is painfully stale, pathetically unfunny, and I can't think of a single reason why you should sit through [it].
The acting occasionally borders on great. The story itself is more than worthy. But none of that comes close to overcoming the misguided pacing and overall lack of depth.
None of this matters at all because the main characters are completely unlikable, and the momentum is consistently ruined by poor decision-making.

I was swept away by the drama about a selfish, beautiful Southern belle who loses everything in the Civil War but claws her way back after vowing - backed by composer Max Steiner's trumpets - "As God is my witness, I'll never be hungry again."
The story weaves together beautifully and you're left with a film that makes you want to go out and do nice things for other people yourself.
The soundtrack will be smothered by the sounds of screaming girls, and laughing at them may be the only pleasure you get out of this arduously edited angst fest.
Poor editing makes Gamer overlong, and the negative portrayal of gamers is as hard to swallow as the cheesy plot.
This is a gripping mystery in its own right, and even retains the original Japanese voice actors (with subtitles).

As usual, the director retains his controlled style even as he moves toward a more traditional narrative mode.

movie_review_blurb: To a layperson's eyes, the military exercise does look authentic, and the cross-country skirmishes are ruggedly watchable on an acrobatic level. Yet it's impossible to overlook the inanity of the plotting ...

movie_review_blurb: Brims with warmth and gentle optimism.

Neither the story nor characters have any moral ambiguity or psychological shadings.
More comfort food than haute cuisine.
Whips up the sort of worst-case-scenario, anti-Communist hysteria that's a hilarious throwback to the Cold War propaganda of 1970s cloak-and-dagger movies.
A compelling depiction of how brave individuals from all walks of life mobilized a whole nation to bring a recalcitrant dictator and his henchmen to their knees.

As with so many of Tsui's works, subplots and characters multiply out of control after the first act.

The dark, tempestuous mise-en-scene serves to underscore the story's moral confusion. American-born Indian composer-singer Gingger Shankar's tensile score moves fluidly between heart-pounding and lyrical.

movie_review_blurb: The plot of how a math geek devises the perfect cover-up to clear his loved one of murder is so ingenious, it will impress anyone who doesn't already know the source material.

movie_review_blurb: One is left with such a lingering sense of loss and helplessness that it begs the question of whether there's really "a time for everything" in such a troubled world.

movie_review_blurb: Certainly less of a dud than the director's inane original, this follow-up is even more tyke-oriented, but at least it's a livelier yarn and boasts a slick upgrade in visual effects.

movie_review_blurb: Less offensively nationalistic than the second installment but falling short of the glowing humanity, genial Cantonese humor and visual flair of the first, the pic is somewhat tarnished by its pedestrian plot and limp characterization.

What weighs the characters down is not their parachutes or rock-climbing gear, but their sententious First World guilt and bland casting; gone is the free-spirited fun of Kathryn Bigelow's cult-hit original.
A lazily executed dud padded out with infantile pranks, shambolic plot turns and knockabout action.

It restores my faith in the concept of redemption to see McCarthy bouncing from The Cobbler straight to Spotlight
In his 1st project on the serious side, after movies like The Campaign, Dinner for Schmucks & Meet the Parents, Jay Roach delivers a rather fine job.
Zootopia is the best Disney animated movie, either with Pixar or without it, since Toy Story 3 in 2010.
I never enjoyed the company of a screaming, out of his lungs, Gerard Butler, yet I can honestly say that he was just as hard to tolerate as everybody else.
A loyal adaptation of a familiar story, but the unique creative vision and dramatic philosophy makes it necessary to label it 'unparalleled'
A claustrophobic, blood boiling, experience that is, surprisingly, very easy to follow and be engaged with
I laughed hard watching "Central Intelligence" and I believe it's the best movie so far that has been designed around the type of comedy where Kevin Hart belongs

I enjoyed Demolition, but that doesn't mean that I can't fill a few letters of complaints myself.
A superior film to its predecessor and, maybe, with different circumstances, boosting its influence and effectiveness, it would've reached the highest spot in the "Alien" pyramid

Why is Sam Shepard in this movie?
[Drew] drags down an otherwise likable drama that draws its three stories together in a quietly effective climax.
Petersen orchestrates a handsome battle sequence, but this attenuated stew of stagy posturing and unconvincing domestic drama runs aground on Pitt's preening deportment and drama-class line readings.

[Has] road-accident appeal.
The plot and characters feel like afterthoughts.
The combination of Lee's discomforting subject matter and distancing style ... makes this slow-moving drama a challenge that doesn't seem entirely worth the effort.

A dreary slog through haunted-child movie cliches.
A film that isn't sure whether it wants to be smart-alecky or gritty.
The story takes a seriously wrong turn that requires Strother to rush in where anyone -- no matter how skittish or sleep-deprived -- with a lick of common sense would fear to tread.
Feels simplistic and a little condescending.

The film's saddest contention is that five decades later American public schools remain economically segregated by economics, which too often produces classrooms whose complexions have changed little since the pre-Brown era.
movie_title: With All Deliberate Speed: The Legacy of Brown vs. Board (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What could easily have been a sentimental, fannish exercise in musty nostalgia is in fact a lovely tribute to an era of feverish creativity that seemed as though it would never end yet now lives only in memory.

Wassel's reach exceeds his grasp: The film's storytelling is choppy and sometimes obscures important relationships, and not all of the actors are capable of the emotional range that would give their characters convincingly tragic dimensions.
Documents the quick-tempered writer's meandering journey from miserable childhood through hardscrabble adulthood to comfy late-life acclaim.
Part ethnographic study and part fable.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [Cuaron] leaves his mark without betraying the source material.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If you're already asking, 'Why don't these alcoholic losers just stop picking at their mental scabs and grow up?' this is not the movie for you.

Kidman and Law are chilly performers, and their fundamental remoteness drains the sublimated passion from Inman and Ada's hope-sustaining romance. It also allows the supporting cast to steal the movie out from under them.
A lopsided mix of top-shelf spectacle and cut-rate casting.
Cheerfully ham-fisted celebration of love and family in modern-day Madrid.
movie_title: My Mother Likes Women (A mi madre le gustan las mujeres) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Takes a desperately wrong turn about 45 minutes in, and you can almost hear the great sucking sound as the whole thing churns down the drain in a swirl of narrative contradictions.

Salvatores draws strikingly unsentimental performances from his young actors, all making their film debuts, and juxtaposes the petty meanness of children with the calculated cruelty of desperate adults to haunting effect.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A leaden, tone-deaf remake.
Slick but deeply dumb.
Leeson's sensibility is a thoroughly irritating mix of intellectual hauteur and juvenile smuttiness.
Unpredictable deviations from the formula ... keep the film interesting.
Delivers the facts and illustrates the work with a generous selection of well-chosen clips.
movie_title: Charlie: The Life and Art of Charles Chaplin (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Works equally well an eerie fable or a sharply observed family drama.
A showcase for the loose, occasionally very funny, give-and-take between instantly recognizable characters.

Deeply disturbing material -- murder, suicide, insanity, kiddie porn, animal abuse and more -- mixes uncomfortably with the film's time-travel conceit, which requires some serious suspension of disbelief.
A romantic comedy whose no-holds-barred gross-out elements sour an already graceless mix of crude pratfalls and heartache.
Has just enough astringent touches to keep it from sliding into sloppy sentimentality.
The film's bleakly inevitable ending packs a wallop and its hauntingly desolate images linger long after the story is told.
Watching it is the closest thing yet to seeing a first-person driving game play itself.
The film's mix of sentiment, body-function humor and family values preachiness is relatively good-natured, obligatory kicked-in-the- 'nads-by-a- little-kid scene notwithstanding.
Broomfield's film is typically self-aggrandizing but filled with unsettling moments.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Young Tamimi is a terrific rider but a lackluster screen presence, and the film's brevity ensures that her trials have a perfunctory quality that keeps them from being truly compelling.

Demystifies the world of ballet while paying loving homage to the dedication and discipline of dancers.

Infuriating and challenging in equal parts.
As the weepy days go by, transgressions are forgiven, priorities reassessed and hearts healed.
Even by the standards of pop-moral parables passing for entertainment, this is bland stuff.

Both affectionate and knowing.

If The Rock weren't such a fundamentally genial screen presence, this short, stripped-down revenge drama might leave a sour aftertaste.
Jordan's nightmarish vision of the Australian landscape is vividly haunting.

A buzzed-up gloss on the original, it's entertaining -- if fundamentally shallow.

It's just plain exhausting to watch the admirably game cast members running around like headless chickens in chic period clothes, surrendering their dignity to the task of navigating the plot's frenetic contrivances.
Consistently unpredictable and sneakily charming.

An intriguing mix of the familiar and the alien.

Dumb and shabby.
Sleekly engaging documentary.

Never dull -- no mean feat, given that it spends two hours telling a story whose end is widely known -- and features performances that range from coarsely effective to phenomenal.
There's no denying the freak-show appeal and you don't see frontal nudity like this on TV, but otherwise it's all as contrived and artificial as Survivor.
This film's lavishly beautiful animation is as sophisticated as the story is solemnly dopey.

The rare sequel that actually improves on the original.

A deliciously bitter tale of lust and betrayal among dog-eat-dog Wall Street bigwigs.
Formulaic but surprisingly affecting.
Even when the film is in danger of getting bogged down in its own complications, the hard-boiled poetry of its images is arresting.

Di Pego's convoluted construction is all frippery with no foundation, and eventually its intricate inventions just seem ridiculous.
Even by the debased standards of later films released under the National Lampoon banner, this is sorry stuff.
There's never a dull moment and seldom one that isn't sublimely ridiculous.
Breathtakingly beautiful.
Like the fresh-faced leads, the film is an unexpected charmer.

movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Boe's surefooted manipulation of characters and themes is genuinely dazzling, and cinematographer Manuel Alberto Claro gives the film an intoxicating look.
The film's form is measured, but its message is incendiary.
Quickly tumbles down a rabbit hole of annoying psychobabble, dubious science and embarrassingly silly animation.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Simultaneously groundbreaking and remarkably faithful to the classic play about the boy who won't grow up.

Less an adaptation of Bataille's first novel, The Story of the Eye, than an exploration of its thematic underpinnings, the intersection of eroticism, power and baroque perversity.
movie_title: Georges Bataille's Story of the Eye (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One soggy, charmless heap of chum.

The film's persuasively doom-haunted atmosphere and star Christian Bale's astonishing transformation into an emaciated walking skeleton are hypnotic, in a roadkill, rubbernecking sort of way.
One of the flat-out creepiest films ever released by a major American studio.
A beguiling mix of the familiar and the exotic, vivid proof that a good story can withstand endless variations without losing its fundamental vitality.
The gags fall flat as often as they hit their mark.
A tour de force and an utter delight.
Overall it doesn't amount to much more than a goofy campfire tale.

Clancy's mild farce is nowhere near as bracingly mean-spirited as he apparently thinks, and the occasional amusing one-liner can't compensate for the broad caricatures and awkwardly structured story.

Parello's deadpan re-creation of the stranglers' repellent war on women is all the more chilling for being so matter-of-fact, and cinematographer John Pirozzi flawlessly evokes the grit-and-grime look of low-budget '70s crime films.
First-time writer-director Jordan Roberts' male weepie ricochets between affecting scenes and insufferably maudlin ones.
Director Pieter Kramer successfully reproduces the bright colors and cheerful ambiance of musical comedies of the 1950s and '60s.
movie_title: Ja zuster, nee zuster (Yes Nurse! No Nurse!) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This oddly flat serial-killer picture shows none of the baroque flair that characterizes the best of Italian horror filmmaker Dario Argento's work.

The film is rich with evocative images and while never frightening, it creates a pervasive atmosphere of unease that lingers like the faint scent of unfamiliar perfume.

David O. Russell's smarty-pants head-trip, which aims to provoke discussion of big questions by wrapping them in hipster laughs, begins with a sputtering burst of profanity and ends up struggling in the sticky strands of its own elaborate contrivances.
For a good hour the film breezes along on the promise that there will be a moment when everything coalesces and its point becomes clear. But the moment never comes.

Although phenomenally well-acted, the film's leisurely pace ultimately makes it feel as oppressive as the tropical heat and humidity that gradually turn the characters into slow-moving heaps of damp, dirty rags.
Features more vehicular stunts and low-brow gags than the delicately contrived premise can comfortably support.
A rollicking cross between Raiders of the Lost Ark and The Good, The Bad and the Ugly.
movie_title: Warriors of Heaven and Earth (Tian di ying xiong) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Although the story is as predictable as can be ... the performances are better than those in most super-low budget horror pictures, and Jessica Gallant's super-16mm cinematography is surprisingly handsome.
Shimizu generates a sense of palpable dread in each segment, expertly manipulating tried-and-true scare tactics supplemented by a truly inspired use of spooky sound effects.
A quirky take on the popular character Zatoichi.
At 133 minutes, the film doesn't feel longer, just deeper and more richly textured.
A refreshing alternative to the hypertrophied spy thrillers in which exaggerated action sequences, over-the-top super-villainy and high-tech gadgetry trump character and plot.

An unexpectedly engaging futuristic mystery.

A mesmerizing spectacle.

This anti-thriller radiates dread rather than suspense; it delivers creeping apprehension rather than adrenaline-pumping kicks, and the uniformly strong and finely calibrated performances more than compensate for the absence of technical razzle-dazzle.
Watchable, if not particularly cinematic, and faithful without actually evoking the uniquely literary qualities that have seduced generations of readers.

A fine and thought-provoking film in its own right.

This mean-spirited revenge story would once have starred Cole Hauser's father, veteran B-movie psycho Wings Hauser, and played grindhouses and drive-ins. And it would have been a far more entertaining picture.

A beguiling blend of traditional martial arts epic and operatic Western a la Sergio Leone.
There isn't a one-note character in the mix, and they respond with haunting, subtle performances that feel utterly natural and unaffected.

movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks the novel's drier-than-dry bite, but compensates with a strong ensemble cast and a series of glamorous party sequences in which the decor has at least as much depth as the guests.
Deville gently reveals that they're all simultaneously hauntingly fragile and amazingly resilient, their smiles as piercing as any resigned gaze.
Rough-edged but affecting.
The dogs are cute, the scary parts are appropriately subdued and everything works out for the best.
Silly, good-natured and full of unlikely moves.

Mark Moormann's documentary tends to the worshipful, but Dowd, a charmer onscreen, was by all accounts just as appealing in real life, a gentleman and a scholar who loved music, loved musicians and loved making them sound their best.
movie_title: Tom Dowd and the Language of Music (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Once the running and screaming starts, the proceedings degenerate into a surprisingly Alien 3-like morass of claustrophobic sprints through dark corridors, punctuated by boogie beasts springing out of the shadows.
An ingenious triumph of imagination over budget.
Unsatisfying account of [Stander's] life and crimes.
Winterbottom's moody meditation on love in the future imperfect -- a future that looks very like the outer edges of the present.
A vivid record of live acts whose rough-edged immediacy is an integral part of their appeal.

Pokey, blood-spattered, cheap-scare- larded prequel.
Uneven, profane and occasionally flat-out hilarious.
Green actually makes the mix sing, and the film is genuinely absorbing.
A spectacle of the first order.

2 shallow 4 words.
Without an assured character at its center, the movie quickly collapses in a heap of moldy clichs and contrived (and not especially funny) situations.

McKee's darkly clever notion that tragic hipsters doing their second-hand damnedest to be weird are thoroughly unprepared to handle someone who truly is weird gets bogged down in a listless narrative and one-dimensional characterizations.

movie_review_blurb: Though of particular interest to students and enthusiast of international dance and world music, the film is designed to make viewers of all ages, cultural backgrounds and rhythmic ability want to get up and dance.
First and foremost a family drama rather than a wallow in drug-scare conventions
The film is unquestionably educational: If nothing else, one comes away with a certain respect for the dedication true kinkiness demands.

The film is juvenile when it should be adult, coarse when it ought to be bubbly, and upfront when witty circumspection is indicated.

Jolie is a far better actress than this relentlessly shallow material warrants.

movie_review_blurb: Ejiofor's subtle, infinitely humane performance is the invisible glue that holds everything together and Chris Menges's darkly shimmering cinematography lends the story a gritty, coolly seductive glamour.
[A] familiar but well-told tale.
Witless parodies of James Bond-style spy thrillers don't come much more pointless than this dopey vehicle for Rowan Atkinson in Mr. Bean mode.
Longer, louder, stupider and more vulgar than 1995's Bad Boys.
Meticulously crafted but frustratingly meaningless.
Numbingly ordinary.

Tricky thriller.

Patwardhan offers no solutions, but poses disturbing questions.

An assured piece of genre filmmaking that delivers the goods so stylishly it hardly matters that they aren't fresh.

A chic, vitriolic polemic that's as irritating as it means to be provocative.

movie_review_blurb: It's hard not to feel sorry for the high-profile cast, obviously working for brownie points in heaven -- they're so good, yet nothing they do can make the movie fly.

Far too much of Griffin's routine is just that -- routine.
A bit amateurish, but wholesome and achingly sweet.

Small but beautifully acted drama.

Candy-colored fluff wrapped around a story so flimsy it can hardly support the gossamer-thin characterizations and simplistic moral.
An enthralling, suspenseful documentary about spelling bees... yes, spelling bees.

Director Fred Schepisi's Last Order is exactly the kind of rueful, bittersweet comedy-drama this film appears intended to be, but the mawkish sitcom schtick about loved ones driving each other crazy defeats him.
Sit back and enjoy the sharp performances and stylish ambiance that are clearly this film's real reason for existing.
The puzzle pieces are all there. But when you put them all together, the result is a bit of a gyp -- neat but utterly forgettable.
The film seems longer than its 93-minute running time, but kids will probably enjoy its potty humor.
An excellent introduction to the subject, and a movie buff's delight.
Pacino's no-holds-barred performance is either the reason to see this tepid thriller or the reason to avoid it.
The quality of the CGI-heavy special effects is variable ... but the demon zombies and Doson's cackling familiar are crowd pleasers.
Feels 100-percent false, stagy and stylish.
... Has the haunted air of a silent film unearthed just before its irretrievable decay.
Simultaneously nakedly formulaic and oddly clumsy.
It's an astonishing act of imaginative restoration, bringing the sheer wondrousness of everyday sights into sharp focus.
So formulaic it starts to fade from memory before the last punch is thrown.
All it's no more preposterous or jingoistic than American big-budget action thrillers, except for the musical numbers, which are a given.
movie_title: The Hero: Love Story of a Spy (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Dillon makes an assured directing debut, neither indulging in unnecessary stylistic flourishes nor allowing scenes to run too long, a tendency in actors-turned- director.
Roberts's performance is wrong for the period ... and she can't overcome a script that hands Katherine improbably easy victories and sugar-coated defeats that aren't really defeats at all.
This chronicle of SNAFUs foretold doesn't have much new to say but says it with biting precision, and Phoenix's sharp, sneakily sympathetic performance is a pleasure to watch.
The film's real draw is the oversized 3-D format, which makes mountains of anthills and finds a whole world in a few square feet of foliage.
If the third-act denoument is predictable, the film has already delivered more twists than the average genre picture.

Busch's performance is the movie's heart, and like the screen idols whose every gesture he's lovingly absorbed, Busch can pack a world of meaning into an arched eyebrow and a slight crack of the voice.

Leitch's previous foray into political documentary, the sloppy, anarchic 'The Last Party' was overwhelmed by the juvenile antics of its host, Robert Downey Jr., Hoffman establishes a more sober tone, though the new film isn't without its lighter moments.

Though her no-nonsense brand of tough love isn't the stuff of greeting cards, it helped build a remarkably successful halfway house for recovering drug addicts and alcoholics without government help or staff beyond Sister Travis herself.
Coarse and misguided, Keith Gordon's film of the late Dennis Potter's own reworking of his intricate, dyspeptic, 1986 miniseries is a failure on every level.
If the casting, synopsis and very concept don't deter you, you'll probably find it very funny.
Walks a thin line between refreshing irreverence and shameless exploitation of offensive gay stereotypes.
More a string of set pieces than a coherent narrative.
Director and co-writer Takashi Yamazaki mines familiar territory and does nothing especially new with it.
So utterly unimaginative it doesn't even count as hommage; it's just a smudgy copy of a still chilling original.
There's way too much of the usual bonding, beatings, petty humiliation by guards, cat fights in the yard and trips to the hole.
Differentiated from countless similar tales only by the Filipino setting.
Zeta-Jones and Clooney, movie stars in the best sense of the term, pitch their performances perfectly.
If your sensibilities are in line with Tarantino's, the result is sheer sleaze Nirvana.
If [Eastwood] were a more subtle director, it would be a great film; as it is, it's an extremely good one, anchored by the subtly devastating performances of Penn, Robbins and Bacon.
Anyone who remembers Harrison fondly will enjoy this musical tribute, though it assumes a level of familiarity with Harrison's associates that not all viewers will have.
An elusive but dazzlingly sleazy examination of addiction, selfishness, greed and self-destruction in the California sun.
It brings the saga to a satisfying close.
Curtis's directing debut is frequently funny, generally fizzy and occasionally piercingly perceptive about the price love exacts.
The result is rather like eavesdropping on a bright but painfully self-absorbed adolescent's secret thoughts: sometimes fascinating, other times just infuriating.
A low-budget valentine to big-budget Hollywood musicals of the 1940s and '50s, this affectionate homage to dreamy movie romances is a sweet-natured charmer in its own right.
Subtle performances and the 'you are there' immediacy conferred by digital video give Roy's film the feel of a series of stolen moments.
Caine captures Broussard's banal wickedness but, like the rest of the principal cast, his unrepentant English accent is always jarring and occasionally comical.
Davidson's young cast is remarkable, engaging and guilelessly funny without being so cute that their calculated actions ring false.
A deft blend of fantastic noodling and astute psychological drama.

Newcomer Grace seems born to the part of an unformed young woman whose character cries out to be shaped, but it's Ivey's unobtrusive skill that shapes their onscreen relationship into something thoroughly convincing.
An honorable film hamstrung by Hollywood conventions.
Palfi's engrossing feature debut is a breathtaking feat of filmmaking.
Though intelligent and well-crafted, the film suffers from Ron Howard's fundamental sense of decorum and concern for his viewers' tender sensibilities.
Slick but ludicrously contrived.

Filled with pseudoscientific gibble-gabble, arbitrary time-travel rules, howlingly clichd dialogue and renaissance-fair ambience, this dreary science-fiction/historical-action hybrid is a misfire of staggering proportions.
Slight but affecting.
This amateurish comedy features some amazing sequences shot in Moscow. But everything else about it is second rate.

A truer title would be Mike Myers' Cat in the Hat, since this coarse, loud assault on the senses bears few traces of Dr. Seuss's tartly whimsical sensibility but fairly oozes Myers's brand of smirking humor.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As Sebastian Gutierrez's script careens from hackneyed endangered-woman situations to loony implausibility and Kassovitz piles up the scary movie cliches, it becomes increasingly difficult to remain absorbed in Miranda's noir nightmare.
In keeping with his generally perverse filmmaking aesthetic, von Trier systematically does everything he can to alienate horror enthusiasts.

Rosen attempts to provide a rounded picture of the composer's life and work through archival footage and voice-over readings by Eric Bogosian from Khachaturian's diaries and letters, but the man remains a less vivid presence than his music.
movie_title: Khachaturian: A Musician and His Fatherland (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Lazin's film gets off to a bad start with a miscalculated opening sequence presented in a way that implies we're listening to Shakur speak about his own murder, an impossibility that undermines the film's documentary credibility.
There's no need to be a fan of Patrick O'Brian's 20 Aubrey/Maturin novels to enjoy Peter Weir's adaptation of the first and tenth entries in the series.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rodriguez's film captures the grinding routine of street-level drug use with numbing precision.
A harmless disappointment, hampered by the thin story and a surprisingly dreary looking video-game setting, heavy on the floating platforms, cartoony future-cityscapes and goofy gadgetry.
This low-key oddity stresses character over broad laughs and shock effects, allowing Campbell and Davis to develop a quirky rapport that's a real pleasure to watch.
Rather than converting messy, real-life experience into slick, formulaic entertainment, Well's script transforms it into a shapeless, internally inconsistent mess of artificial contrivances.

Pekar's autobiographical chronicle of day-to-day banality is a rich, if dingy, tapestry of ordinary life in all its infinite, homely peculiarity, which filmmakers Sheri Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini bring to uniquely eccentric life.
A formulaic hodge-podge that trades on a certain demographic's affection for the bogeymen of their formative years.
It's big, but not insanely overblown.
Though the ensemble cast is a triumph of apt casting, Isabel's pivotal affair with Edgar is strangely bloodless.
Whether deliberate or accidental, the look of stunned perplexity on little Jadu's face when he finds himself in the middle of a hillside musical number is itself worth the price of admission.
Adventurous viewers will find this unusual genre hybrid an intriguing experience.
The various segments of [Brown's] deeply uneven, globetrotting grab bag range from authentically uplifting to seriously silly.
Frequently gross but often very funny.
Embalmed in the deadening juices of Affleck and Lopez's throwaway celebrity.
The movie's greatest strength lies in phenomenal performances that reach from the leads right down to the smallest supporting roles...
No one familiar with the cold precision of Kubrick's work will be surprised that this isn't the steamy erotic thriller a synopsis (or the ads) might suggest.
Monstrously funny and truly scary, Cheadle is handed a scene-stealing role and never hesitates to do it justice.
Beatty's contribution to the ranks of recent political satire is bold, merciless and frequently very funny, and his performance is just plain fearless.
Finally, science fiction the way it used to be: rousing, cosmically xenophobic and ferociously patriotic... Take that, space bullies!
Gorehounds and smirking fans of the nudge-nudge, wink-wink school of self-referential horror may be disappointed, but that's their loss.
[A] ragged political satire.

A train wreck of a film whose chaotic, partly improvised story and too-tricky mix of film stocks, image sizes, split-screen effects and color/B&W footage overwhelm some phenomenally beautiful sequences and a memorable performance by Saffron Burroughs.
A leisurely elegy for the American West with Kevin Costner's Unforgiven written all over it.
The chaotic, brutal iconography of Italian Westerns is put to novel use in this time-traveling, self-referential, hugely ambitious story.
The complications are predictable, as is the resolution.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Too many undifferentiated teens in peril undermines this landlocked variation on Lifeboat.
Breezy entertainment.
The harder you try to follow the narrative the more frustrating the film becomes, but its sleekly menacing images work their way into your brain like slivers of dry ice.
Though ultimately something less than the sum of its parts, the film's performances are reason enough to see it.
Peosay appears to have taken the Dalai Lama's non-violent philosophy to heart. Rather than rage, his film radiates sadness over a singular way of life in danger of imminent obliteration.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Handsome though the film is ... the story is strangled by speeches about bloodlines, customs, alliances, feuds, battles and ceremonies.
City slickers learn once again that country folk are a pack of seething, resentful savages in this sluggish thriller directed by Mike Figgis, whose heart doesn't appear to have been in it.
This slight and pleasantly predictable film coasts along on the considerable charms of its cast and exotic setting.
It's repetitive and obvious but somehow endearing, like a truly ugly dog with sweet eyes.
Mehta's hybrid is strangely clumsy, given that she's an experienced filmmaker familiar with both Hollywood and Bollywood conventions.
A breezy crime picture with an unforced sentimental underbelly.
De Mello's dedication is inspiring enough to speak for itself.
Poignant documentary.
A lovely meditation on memory, movies and the almost magical power of images to fire the imagination and keep the hope of happiness and beauty alive in the face of real-life ugliness and despair.
Banderas inhabits the role of the mariachi with a feral grace undimished by the seven-year gap between films.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While many films of this kind are undermined by amateurish performances, the main cast is solid and some of the supporting performances (many from non-professionals) are small gems.
While the actors try to play things straight-faced, they're defeated by Helgeland's screenplay and take refuge in old habits.
Green's St. James steals the picture out from under [Culkin] (poetic justice of a sort), and the supporting cast is nothing short of amazing.
The film's appeal is limited to serious fans of the band and the New York punk scene.
Is it preposterous? You bet. But it's also an incredibly beautiful exercise in high-gloss cheesy teasiness, relentlessly kinetic and self-aware without being camp.
Sharply written, flawlessly acted.

The greatest mystery surrounding Rupert Murray's impressionistic documentary about a man who's lost his memory is neither whether it's real or an elaborate put-on (as persistent rumors suggest) but why it's so fundamentally unaffecting.

The performances are better than one might expect from a cast of first-timers and lightly employed professionals, and Mena's characters rarely do the sort of spectacularly stupid things that provoke derisive laughter from seasoned horror-moviegoers.
Ti West's affectionate homage to no-frills fright flicks keeps it simple and succeeds on its own stripped-down terms.
This spare, downbeat shocker shows considerable promise within the scope of its own modest ambitions.
The film's disingenuous air of bittersweet chic becomes deeply tiresome long before it's over.

This tribute to old-fashioned hard-boiled detective fiction is laced with Hollywood satire and the snappy, lightning-fast dialogue that helped make writer-turned-director Shane Black's name synonymous with hard-edged '90s action comedies.
Ultimately, it's a whole lot of style at the service of a story that adds up to nothing more than a great big 'Gotcha!'
[A] gory, shameless ALIENS (1986) rip-off.
A soggy ghost story wrapped in an aggressively swirling wall of mist.
Eminently worth seeing, even if it leaves you wishing it were as consistently inventive as Aardman's first feature, Chicken Run.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This lighthearted meditation on life, death, love and timing contains some genuinely lovely scenes, but they're buried in a shapeless jumble of cutesy-pie vignettes.
The overall impression is of lives that began before Garcia started shooting and continued after the camera was shut off, a remarkable and quietly haunting achievement.
A fundamentally unrewarding story.
Nothing more or less than a secular retelling of the Biblical parable of the prodigal son.
Pacino is a one-man three-ring circus, blustering, capering, cursing, raging and weaseling his way through this predictable morality play like a trickster Satan on speed.
The movie is driven by slyly clever dialogue loaded with sneaky character insights.
You could be forgiven for missing the thematic underpinnings amidst the long, fetishized sex scenes.
The densely worked-over look of this dark, hugely stylish fairy tale directed by mixed-media artist and first-time filmmaker Dave McKean is ultimately more absorbing than the story.

The cast is little more than the sum total of golden skin, firm flesh and blindingly white teeth, but in a film that demands them to be half-naked and soaking wet most of the time, looks trump technical acting skill every time.
British documentarian Peter Bate frames a mix of archival materials and re-creations with a 'trial' at which Leopold listens to testimony against him from within a wood-and-glass booth.
movie_title: Congo: White King, Red Rubber, Black Death (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This is absolutely not a film for all tastes, but it's a masterpiece of pitiless power whose audacious, ambiguous climax strikes a note of insane romanticism as haunting as it is perverse.
You don't have to know an arabesque from an alligator handbag to enjoy Daniel Geller and Dayna Goldfine's loving documentary about the various incarnations of the Ballet Russe.
Younger ... has no evident flair for comedy.
Utterly formulaic and pointless.

Even a bracing mean streak can't save this gross-out romantic comedy from its lazy mess of a script, a string of slapstick gags that demand arbitrary, stupid and out-of-character behavior from all concerned.
Costanzo evokes a world of human complexities in his characters' relationships, and the film's sadly ironic ending is anything but simplistic.
The tone is so poorly established that it takes a while to realize its cavalcade of outrageous misfortunes is meant to be farcical, not melodramatic.
A killer.
The draw is Phoenix and Witherspoon. Together the two are hotter than a pepper sprout.

Inventive visuals and funny bits abound, but the film's gritty look and unsentimental characterizations -- Harry, Hermione and Ron are far from golden teens -- ominously foreshadow the truly wicked shape of things to come.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Shot on low-end digital video, the movie looks harsh and the sound is often dodgy, which wouldn't matter if the material were inherently more interesting.

The film's Buck Rogers-style graphics are cool, but the shrilly squabbling brothers are insufferable, the story's your-turn/my-turn structure is tedious, and its relentlessly reiterated message about brotherly love and cooperation is really grating.
[A] witless farce.
[Derailed] pivots on the kind of big twist that thriller fans will see coming when there's still plenty of time to get off the tracks.
English director Joe Wright's fresh, vivid adaptation of Jane Austen's much-filmed Pride and Prejudice is an eloquent reminder that times change but people don't.
Contains a couple of lovely scenes that are all but smothered by a shambling mess of self-conscious eccentricity.

However fact-based the material may be, Jordan's salt-of-the-earth characters, with their bluster and pride and rough-edged loyalty, are all too familiar, and their travails feel formulaic, right down to the life-affirming climax.
Avrich's colorful account of Wasserman's career starts out looking like a puff piece, but quickly reveals a refreshing willingness to delve into the dirty side of a glamorous business.
movie_title: The Last Mogul (Life and Times of Lew Wasserman) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While most anthology films have one standout and one weak link, all three tales are short, sharp shockers.
Though it reunites the stars and director of the rousingly old-fashioned swashbuckler The Mask of Zorro (1998), this unnecessary and overlong sequel fails to recapture its predecessor's zing.
Fails both as an update of F. Scott Fitzgerald's dissection of American aspirations and class barriers and on its own boorish terms.
Though the story is predictable, Cronenberg's cool touch keeps it from degenerating into tired action-movie clichs.

Jodie Foster's fiercely intelligent performance drives this disappointing thriller, whose taut, carefully constructed first half is sadly negated by its implausible and -- worst of all -- unengaging conclusion.
The result is 93 very long minutes' worth of admirably committed actors putting themselves through the emotional wringer to very little end.
It's a hauntingly original film in which the seeds of Park's even more audacious Oldboy (2003) are clearly evident.
Shot in the 12 months following 9/11, Jones' love letter to New York is an insider's game through and through.
His film is a subtle and deeply moving tribute to a flawed idealist who saw kinship in bears' eyes, where Herzog sees only the abysmal indifference of nature.
Its mix of baroque plotting, awkward soft-core sex and a simmering violence never gels.

What's absent from this spiteful, ridiculously melodramatic recitation of grudges and enthusiasms is any sign of either the eloquent orator considered second only to Adolf Hitler himself or the brilliant strategist who wrote the book on perverting public
Somewhere past the one-hour mark, it's hard not to start rooting for the bad juju.
This bare-bones plot is merely an excuse to string together a series of gross-out jokes involving bodily fluids, private parts, food and genetic deformities.
An intoxicatingly beautiful, maddeningly elliptical and utterly enthralling meditation on the fleeting pleasures and haunting aftermath of doomed romance.
Former goofball Murray, who's aged into a glacial icon of chilly sadness, is the perfect vehicle for writer-director Jarmusch's brand of detached, hipster cool.
The film's ambitions are so low that it's hard to imagine how it fell short of them.

Morrison and screenwriter Angus MacLachlan put an unusual spin on the old chestnuts, playing them straight -- well, almost straight -- and letting the subtle, knotty humanity shine through the surface tics and traits.
This lovely and piercingly sad film is rooted in a free-floating malaise that's endemic to fast-paced, materially oriented cultures throughout the industrialized, urban world.
Even by the degraded standards of dim-witted summer blockbusters, this is sorry stuff.
A didactic Disney kiddie comedy that filters run-of-the-mill high school through comic-book superhero conventions.
Michael Bay's stab at grafting his brand of high-octane mayhem onto an idea-driven sci-fi story gets off to a promising start before degenerating into endless car chases and stuff blowing up.

Kelly Duane's mediocre documentary squanders a terrific subject: pioneering conservationist David Brower's transformation of the Sierra Club from a hiker's association to a groundbreaking force in the American environmental movement.
It's all too arty for its own good.

This wry, low-key comedy swims defiantly against the stream of contemporary comedy, eschewing bodily-function jokes and obvious gags in favor of laughs so sly and self-effacing you could almost overlook them.
The profoundly unconvincing CGI work only makes the sorry screenplay and lackluster performances look worse.
The sequel is a live-action Road Runner cartoon, which is a criticism to the degree that you think story, characterization and some fidelity to the laws of gravity are important.

If the film's pop-psychedelic noodling about fate, self-determination and the power of love looks muzzy-headed on closer consideration, its dense barrage of images richly repays second and third viewings.
This dyspeptic exploration of modern romance was written by TV-star Jenny McCarthy, who tailored its vulgar slapstick to her own apparently endless willingness to be the butt of raunchy gags.

Frothy, sentimental and thoroughly good-natured, Malcolm D. Lee's tale of coming-of-age at the roller disco doesn't have an original bone in its body, but it's as energetic, eager to please and endearing.
Frankly, neither the characters nor their moral dilemmas are particularly fresh or insightful; anyone who's interested in the topography of Hollywood sleaziness has already been over this ground.
Wadlow and cowriter Beau Bauman start with a clever conceit, but Wadlow's gimmicky direction runs it right into the ground.
Though conceptually clever, the results look stagy and schematic and recall nothing more than a pale imitation of Terry Gilliam's Brazil.
[A] handsomely styled horror picture, which also makes a good-faith effort to differentiate among the victims-to-be before it starts picking them off.
Beneath the ghoulish in-jokes and horror-geek allusions, there's a core of the same bittersweet truth that makes the best fairy tales resonate from one generation to the next.
As it is, it's shamelessly manipulative shtick brightened by sharply drawn supporting performances.
That the 27-year-old Usher isn't much of an actor is no surprise, but he's strikingly uncharismatic for someone who's been in the spotlight since he was six.

The film's underlying notion, that imperfection is the essence of humanity and the pursuit of bland flawlessness a kind of soul-killing drug, is far more compelling than its story of clichd teen angst.

Jem Cohen's nightmarish portrait of a deracinated world includes footage shot over 10 years in several countries but cut together so seamlessly that the film seems to unfold in a single, continuous strip of malls, hotels and airports.
This film contains a couple of bracingly mean sequences, but it cleaves so closely to the slasher-movie formula that it can't muster up any suspense at all.
Bleakly funny and bitterly cynical.
The courtroom shenanigans drain the suspense from Emily's story and, frankly, they're not very convincing.
Solid, if hyperactive.
movie_title: Edge Codes: The Art of Motion Picture Editing (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If it weren't for the running flatulence gag, the whole silly business might be mistaken for slight, clean, fast-moving fun.

Hallstrom's resolutely old-fashioned film, based on Mark Spragg's novel, is sympathetic to the internalized WASP way of grief, and enriched by Redford's and Freeman's subtle, superlative performances.

Aimed at the head rather than the heart, Karz's film is intended to encourage wide-ranging thought and promote constructive debate, useful ambitions in a post-9/11 world too often characterized by hard-line ideology and us-against-them thinking.
[Fisher's] heavy-handed montage of war, civil rights demonstrations... is so amateurish it very nearly succeeds in trivializing the power of [Shicoff's] performance.
movie_title: Finding Elazar: Portrait of a Tenor and a Role (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The juvenile gags seem aimed at moviegoers who hate the whole idea of independent/art/foreign-language films and the stuck-up eggheads who like them -- so what's the point?
While snowboarding enthusiasts will eat up every minute of its two-hour running time, it's thin stuff for the unconverted.
Either the most inept vanity production ever made or the most deadpan satirical prank ever pulled.
Certainly evidence that truth is stranger than fiction, but it's also tedious and shockingly uninvolving.
This tale about a successful playwright and a vitriolic theater critic begins on a strenuously schematic note ... and descends into a tangle of heavily symbolic nonsense.
So unsubtle as to verge on the comical ... this didactic drama is set safely in the past and says nothing about the culture of conformity at all costs that hasn't been said before.
... a shockingly successful update of a seminal 1970s shocker.
The main story, whose creepy premise demands major tiptoeing around lest it slip into the realm of outright smarminess thoroughly unsuitable for a PG-13-rated comedy.

It simultaneously overloads the first film's silly teen-wolf metaphor with modern family dysfunction and coarsens the body-switch mishaps into juvenile shtick about marking territory and slobbering dog kisses.
Kurt Wimmer's film epitomizes just about everything wrong with post-Matrix, comic book-/video-game-inspired, Hong Kong-action-style sci-fi thrillers.

The film's saving grace isn't that its plot is particularly unpredictable, it's that [director Richard] Donner and screenwriter Richard Wenk give the actors time to put some flesh on their characters' bones.
A down-under fable with a sweet country-music twang.
The film's heart is Magdiel and the modest dreams that get him through the day but may also be the death of him.
By the time he unveils the final plot twist, his film has lost every shred of credibility.
[The film is] too long and its tone is disconcertingly uneven, but Perry never betrays or condescends to his characters: He agonizes with their unhappiness and rejoices in their victories.
It's way too violent and perversely excessive for many tastes, but there's more to its outrages than meets the eye, and that second look is well worth taking.

Fiercely loose and less ragged than it first appears, this story of persistent addiction and fragile recovery plays out in Sydney, Australia's blue-collar suburbs and features powerhouse performances by its stars.
Even the stunningly downbeat ending smacks of sub-Tarantinoesque theatrics.
It's hard not to hope things work out for everyone, even though you know perfectly they will.

While it echoes a host of CGI-heavy, action-oriented supernatural thrillers, it manages to retain its own distinct identity. Although this first chapter in a three-part tale is inevitably overburdened with back story, it ends on one hell of a cliff-hanger
Khanna addresses the volatile issue of women's rights within Islamic households, and if his sensationalistic debut feature makes its point with a heavy hand, it's also starkly provocative.
A collage of highly personal reflections that range from the goofy to the surprisingly affecting.

Brutally gorgeous and seething with incendiary images, the Wachowski brothers' monumental call to revolution, based on Alan Moore's gloomy graphic novel about a masked madman who restores anarchy to the U.K., is a vivid but muddled pulp political parable.
Eckhart is dazzling as a born phony almost brought low by believing his own lies, and he's matched at every turn by a stellar supporting cast.
Simultaneously heartbreakingly beautiful and exquisitely sad.
Romano and Caltabiano mostly watch TV and squabble about whose fault it is they're running a few minutes late.

A showcase for triumph-of-the-underdog sports-movie cliches and coming-of-age-through-adversity moral lessons. But thanks to Banderas' understated sophistication and the efforts of the attractive young cast, it's still a charmer.
Prehistory's first blended herd begins a new adventure some tens of thousands of years after joining forces in the face of a global deep freeze (no, the math doesn't work, so stop worrying about it).
The story is familiar, but terrific performances and a vivid sense of place elevate it above the average teen-oriented picture.
For all the sex and slicing, the most shocking thing about it is how dreary it is.

It's an impressionistic experience rather than a linear one, and the process of surrendering to the images and rhythms of lives lived in simultaneous harmony with the physical and the spiritual is greatly helped by the chants.
This well-intentioned film about loss, grief and new beginnings gets bogged down in syrupy cliches and blunt self-help dialogue.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Serbian cinematographer Vladimir Subotic's photography transforms New York's outlying neighborhoods and anonymous streets into a weather-beaten dreamscape suffused with mystery, danger and the hope of heaven.
Actually makes good on the 'horror comedy' label by being both flat-out creepy and darkly funny.
Stephen King's 1982 Different Seasons collection has been a gold mine for moviemakers:
The movie equivalent of junk food: It's not good, but it's predictable and even satisfying, in a low-expectations way.
Hugely entertaining, the film strikes a near-flawless balance between sly pop-culture allusions and the details of how business gets done under pressure.
Despite the low budget, the film is handsomely designed and well acted, and Bai's inventiveness turns what could easily have been liabilities into assets.
Slyly devastating.
The stellar supporting cast helps compensate, and Phil Parmet's muddy photography is a constant visual reminder of the everyday desolation that helped drag Jim into his black hole of despair.
Just another cautionary tale about fast times, intemperate passions and bad dope.

It's by no stretch of the imagination a good film, but it delivers what it promises: naked girls whaling on each other, flesh-ripping zombies and genre stalwart Todd growling and glowering satanically.
The ghost of Dashiell Hammett haunts the corridors of a nondescript suburban high school in this odd but engagingly off-kilter thriller.

Richard Linklater's cynical kiddie-sports comedy is less a remake of The Bad News Bears than a cover version; for all the updated riffs and personal noodling, it's best when it doesn't stray too far from the original material.
Despite the hot-button issues and go-for-broke emoting, Freedomland ultimately feels didactic rather than urgent.

A high-tech variation on The Desperate Hours (1955, 1993), this thoroughly formulaic thriller, in which a middle-aged everyman has to go mano a mano with the bad guys who threaten his family, goes through the motions with singular dispiritedness.
The comic payoff is slow to come and culminates in a kind of triumph-of-the-little-guy ending that only Frank Capra can pull off.
Indie director Bezucha has held on to just enough individuality to breathe a little life into the cliches.
Xiao's bittersweet film is superficially a swoony love letter to the cinema. But her valentine has a hidden sting, rooted in some hard truths.
The film falls short even as a record of Broderick and Lane's crowd-pleasing rapport: Both have done the show so many times that every scrap of life is gone.
The product of this ingenuity is a slight spin on an obscure motion-picture artifact, but it's surprisingly artfully done.

Jones handles his fellow actors well, drawing a hard, anguished performance from Pepper and allowing January Jones (no relation) to bring a touching vulnerability to Mike's bored, vapid, baby-doll wife.

movie_review_blurb: Simultaneously gorgeous and forgettable, sentimental and prurient.

movie_review_blurb: A quietly harrowing chronicle of addiction and fragile recovery anchored by Vera Farmiga's intense performance.

This live-action cartoon tries to walk the line between pleasing the faithful and appealing to a broad-based action audience. It fails on both fronts.

Shut your brain down for optimal viewing pleasure.
Repetitive and uninspired, it panders to the lowest expectations of horror buffs and squanders the efforts of a competent cast.

movie_title: What the Bleep!? Down the Rabbit Hole (2006)

... offers a solid overview of the pioneering African-American filmmaker's wide-ranging career.

movie_review_blurb: The impressionistic presentation actually undermines the horrifying facts and moving testimony from survivors on both sides of the conflict.

Offbeat and ravishingly beautiful.

Two siblings and a would-be lover scratch and claw at the air and each other...
A silly, stupendously artificial enterprise.
