Runner Runner gives both [Justin Timberlake and Ben Affleck] room to show what they can do, and rather than pump up the volume, they play it close to the vest, as good gamblers would.
Formulaic post-apocalyptic thriller...when you don't especially care who lives and who dies, all the skull-crunching action doesn't amount to a hill of beans.
Horror buffs looking for an old-fashioned scare will find one or two here, but filmmakers Leigh Whannell and James Wan are spreading their brand thin.

Four young men from a rough neighborhood are bound together by an ugly secret that continues to haunt them long after they've taken different paths to adulthood... Feel free to stop us if you've heard this story, oh, about a hundred times before.
Imagine a cross between The Road Warrior and Death Race 2000 and you'll have an idea what this sometimes clever and always action-packed post-apocalyptic romp is up to.
A thoroughly generic action picture...The Outsider never rises above the clichs of an overpopulated genre.
Its combination of grit and fatalism won't be to all tastes, but it's a refreshing alternative to the bigger-is-way-better swamp in which most Hollywood crime movies are mired.
...more than competent and less than inspired, [Almost Human] should find a nontheatrical niche among genre fans.

Odd Thomas is not for every taste, and for many viewers it will rank somewhere on a scale that starts with twee and ratchets up to insufferable. Yet its resolute sweetness in the face of fairly credible horror has the potential to beguile...

This astonishingly inept romantic comedy ignores the most basic rules of character development, and demands that the Robertsons do and think things so stupid and venal that it's the next best thing to impossible to like or care about them.
...in practical terms Aftermath is likely to disappoint viewers expecting a fun action movie with monsters.
The gags rely heavily on boogers, bird poo and sheep dung, and Farley falls down with monotonous regularity.

How much you enjoy the film will depend entirely on how much you enjoy the spectacle of Williams spewing forth streams of nonsensical gibberish in an attempt to impersonate a German record producer, and Crystal pitching snit fits.

Andalusian filmmaker Paco Cabezas, making his English-language directing debut, is unable to keep the complicated story and international cast in line; the results are never dull but are sometimes unintentionally hilarious.
This big-budget bore looks lovely but is so miscalculated that you can't help but wonder whether anyone involved had ever seen the original.

Most of the characters are either types or anonymous bodies in motion... but the handful with backstories are well played by a cast composed largely of actors with respectable and diverse TV and indie-movie credits.
A brutal and admirably grueling serial-killer thriller, this Australian import is also repetitive and ultimately a little dull.
This star-studded documentary about poster artist Drew Struzan would never play as fiction: His rags-to-riches journey from poverty to Hollywood acclaim is straight out a '30s movie.
movie_title: Drew: The Man Behind The Poster (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Michd's sweet spot is the intersection of high and low, the place where genre clichs bleed into unpredictable and nuanced storytelling.

That Jonah Bekhor and Zack Math's The Final Member isn't a sniggering, 72-minute dick joke is an achievement in and of itself. That it's a genuinely moving portrait of men attempting to secure legacies...is remarkable.
Director/co-writer Zack Parker's second feature is more ambitious and subtle than it first appears
If your taste in horror runs Saw-wise, it might seem a little tame, but if you prefer slow burn and a muted but suitably grim payoff, Oculus should be your cup of bitter tea.

Moran's writing and directing debut is an admirably ambitious examination of the one-baby-step-at-a-time process that leads a fundamentally decent person to shut down his moral compass do things that are, by any objective standard, reprehensible.
Despite boasting five directors, eight writers and more than a dozen producers, Locker 13 - partially financed with a Kickstarter campaign - hangs together better than many anthology pictures.
[A] bizarre hybrid of romantic comedy cliches and less-than-subtle social commentary.

The bad news is that uwantme2killhim? is less engaging than the 2005 Vanity Fair article on which it's based. After the bizarre and sadly sordid details of the real-life story are smoothed away, what's left feels both familiar and simplistic.
Destined for life on late-night cable TV, The Bag Man is the definition of a modest diversion, just the thing for the hours when thinking is too much effort and sleep is elusive.
For all its familiar genre elements, Blood Glacier is pretty entertaining, assuming a basic predisposition to like monster movies.

Battle for Blood continues to make 13th-century England look like a truly wretched place to live or, more often, die in. But while it delivers some strong battle sequences, the characters are less vividly drawn than in its predecessor.
...it delivers a handful of creepy moments and the opening-credits montage of old newspaper accounts of the Jarvis family's fate is genuinely disturbing.

A lackluster neo-noir thriller set deep in the dark heart of Texas, Rushlights delivers plot twists galore. If only the protagonists, a pair of hard-luck L.A. teens, were interesting enough to make audiences care what becomes of them.
A message movie whose only subtlety is found in the portrayal of Adderly, a sexual predator who actually believes in some twisted way that he loves the children whose childhoods he's destroys.
Genuinely creepy horror movie, which suggests more than it shows but shows enough to make non-genre fans watch from between closed fingers.

Imagine Saving Private Ryan relocated to Afghanistan and Pakistan and you have the gist of first-time feature filmmaker Stphane Rybojad's actioner about the rescue of a French journalist marked for death by the Taliban.

Ben Moses' documentary argues that even thwarted and deeply flawed elections are empowering because they engage ordinary citizens in the political process and challenge the self-defeating apathy engendered by opting out of the process.
Unlike many "lost" treasures, Wake in Fright lives up to its nightmarish reputation.

Reports of the found-footage movie's death have been greatly exaggerated, if this sly and often very creepy horror anthology about four lowlifes who agree to steal a mysterious videocassette is anything by which to judge.
A dystopian sci-fi action thriller shot in 3D and 50 shades of gray, this adaptation of the bleakly satirical comic-book series plays its story of future justice at gunpoint straight and dull.

Clearly designed as a downbeat, character-driven psychological thriller, not a shock machine...but it never really pays off, in part because it relies too often on the very clichs it aspires to avoid.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A series of snapshots from the working life of two hot-dogging but fundamentally decent L.A. police officers... lifts it above cop-movie clichs.
Raaz 3 delivers some effective gore (including the grisly fate of Sanjana's maid and a ripped-off head) as well as lots of steamy make-out scenes.
Paranormal Activity 3 delivers, and does it without gore or "look at me!" special effects.
Something of a disappointment, but serious genre fans and anyone who thrills to the idea of seeing cannibal zombies ruin a perfectly lovely wedding will check it out anyway
Earnest drama about an Indian immigrant who learns the hard way that the streets of 1973 New York aren't paved with gold has some effective moments despite its reliance on clichs and stereotypes.

Already a genre festival favorite, this dark comedy, in which a soldier killed in Iraq comes back from the grave a blood-drinking zombie, will appeal to horror fans looking for something a little different, but may have trouble crossing over.
An epic feast for fans of Chinese fairy-tale movies, from the stunning visuals to the surprisingly complex relationships.
In this action romance, two spies--one Indian, the other Pakistani--fall in love and stir up a whole lot of trouble when their respective bosses find out about their extreme fraternizing.

Reimaging of the 1990 movie "inspired by" a Philip K. Dick short story should please fans of nonstop action sequences punctuated by the occasional scrap of narrative exposition, rather than lovers of PKD's dense, allusive brand of speculative writing.
This taut thriller wrings maximum suspense from all-too ordinary, real-life terrors while gradually edging into full-blown horror territory.
Cloud Atlas is consistently entertaining and surprisingly effective, as well as the shortest three hours most moviegoers will ever spend in a theatre...and that's no small recommendation.
The micro-budget horror movie pulls off the harder-than-it-looks feat of tucking food for thought inside a very scary wrapper.
Dark, funny, and deeply affecting
As IFC clearly realizes, Berberian Sound Studio is a niche item, but a niche item whose target audience should embrace it with a hearty Ciao, bella!
American Mary is the newest addition to a long list of horror films about disturbed and disturbing doctors,and it's a worthy one.
Director Ben Wheatley is capable of simultaneously embracing both the awkward comedy and creeping horror of Chris and Tina's voyage into darkness.

Oddly lifeless, despite the clearly devoted efforts of the cast and crew: It's admirable without being particularly engaging, so respectful of its cinematic predecessors that its own voice is strangled.
A series of strenuously oddball vignettes masquerading as a movie.

Shock rocker turned filmmaker Rob Zombie pits an emotionally fragile radio personality against a coven of undead witches in his fifth feature. The result is genuinely creepy if not jump-out-of-your-seat scary.
A dark comedy driven by spot-on digs at academia, cutthroat art-world competition and the quest for inspiration.
Even by the standard of paranormal teen romances, The Host is ridiculous stuff, and derivative too.

The lives of a small-town couple eagerly anticipating the birth of their first child are shattered when they lose the baby under suspicious circumstances in this creepy psychological thriller that plays out very differently than its early scenes suggest.
Short, sharp shockers about death in all its infinite variety, one for each letter of the alphabet.
This documentary unfolds in Romania, but its depiction of multi-generational poverty perpetuated in part by substandard schooling could as easily have been set in dozens of other countries.
UK shockumentarian Nick Broomfield's investigation into the death of rock idol Kurt Cobain exudes a near-irresistible freak-show fascination.
There are many roads to hell, and A Dark Truth travels the one paved with well-intentioned efforts to wrap complicated social/political issues in genre movie clichs.
Allegiance's commitment to shades of gray translates into excellent opportunities for its cast, and they take full advantage.
A cute cast enlivens this body-count picture set in a snooty high school, but once you get past the formulaic clichs, there's nothing there but more clichs.

This shaggy-dog story based on the improbable real-life adventures of exotic dancer-turned-bookie-turned-journalist Beth Raymer is never quite as amusing as it thinks it is, despite a charming performance by Rebecca Hall.
A black comedy at its most stygian, a parade of sad-sacks, no-hopers, sellouts, screw-ups and basket cases:
The new Red Dawn is polished to a high Hollywood gloss and stripped of nuance and moral ambiguity, while flamboyant man's-man Milius' version dares to accord the invaders a measure of humanity.
A dreamy, claustrophobic thriller about family secrets and lies, alternates between genuine creepiness and a disconcerting goofiness that undermines its atmospheric chills.
Will entertain some viewers and infuriate others with its clunky mix of feminist fury and awkward action sequences.

If Beneath isn't as good a movie as the nerve-shattering The Descent, well, few are. But Beneath aims for the same ambitious mix of physical and psychological terror and does a tidy job of not showing its hand until it's good and ready.

It's entertaining enough if you're a fan of rotting-girl catfights...and evil conspiracies, but there's no there there and little reason to stick it out to the predictably miserable end except so you can say you did.
It's hard to imagine how this tedious rehash of exorcism-movie clichs secured a theatrical release.
Consistently favors relationships over special effects and overall features characters who don't act like complete morons.
There's just not much room to work with [the abundance of] clichs.
Though the set-up sounds insufferably gimmicky [...] Michael Kospiah's screenplay for The Suicide Theory is a tight, thoughtful piece of work.
[Mad Women] all too often feels as smug and self-satisfied as [its main characters], all of whom feel less like characters than wacky improv exercises.
Formulaic horror movie benefits from unusual setting but will still feel all-too-familiar to the genre fans who constitute its primary audience.
Kudos to the special-effects team, who relied less on CGI and more on practical effects.
All three human leads-Courtney and the two Clarkes-fall somewhere on the spectrum of weak to terrible.
...plays out like a dumb but surprisingly entertaining action movie, but it's laced with bits of business and dialogue that make it clear the film isn't dumb at all.
Lacks the go-for-the-gut sense of grizzlies as hairy great white sharks that could have made it into a landlocked Jaws.
Anarchy Parlor is little more than a variation on the Hostel theme, which, however exploitative, does contain a nugget of wisdom.
The Stranger is far from a perfect film, but it's admirably eerie and remarkably restrained.
Genuinely spooky ghost story continues to favor atmosphere over gross-out shocks.
Pays tribute to a wide range of films, old and new, while staking out its own distinctive territory, one that's equal parts melancholic family drama and supernatural shocker.
Like the sort of sleepy slasher film it vaguely resembles, Sunset Edge [...] is ultimately all about the sins of the fathers being visited on the next generation.
Any Day falls into the painfully crowded trough between not-bad and seriously not-good movies.
Too grim for the average fan of crime pictures, and too brutal for many viewers who might appreciate its matter-of-fact portrayal of the lives of many PTSD sufferers.
Sharply written, unusually well-acted and well worth a look that it will be lucky to get.
A neat little diversion filled with familiar faces, especially if you have a little thing for '90s genre movies.
The odds that The Runner will change hearts and minds are slim.
It's hard to imagine Dark Places matching Gone Girl's big footprint-those shoes have already been filled.
Pitched somewhere between Duel and Joyride, this motor-psycho picture fails to stake out new territory or ring any significant changes on a decades-old formula.
Hard Labor is a smart, sneaky little shocker whose subtexts add depth to its haunted-house framework and pay off in a final scene that's both weirdly off-kilter and entirely logical.
Julia does put a small spin on the by-now well-worn [rape revenge] formula[...] But ultimately that's not enough to elevate Julia above its genre roots.
A sharp little genre mix-it-up that delivers one hell of thoroughly set-up sucker punch without ever undermining its spiffy sci-fi/spook-show hijinks.
Momentum has plenty of visual flash, but the script is deeply dumb.
An aspiring gangster tries to work his way up in a Japanese underworld teeming with monsters of every kind in a movie that's sometimes weirdly brilliant.
A strong, if not genre-changing, feature debut for actor-turned-writer/director Justin Trefgarne.
Cannibal killers invade a Mexican restaurant and torment the staff and patrons in this broad but not particularly funny comedy/horror picture.
1915 is sadly dull and didactic, even within the parameters of a film whose primary purpose is to educate rather than entertain.
While the film has some nice moments, they don't add up to anything particularly original.
An idiosyncratic portrait of a man whose life went to hell after he did the planet a major favor.
movie_title: The Man Who Saved the World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Transporter Refueled is shamelessly derivative, but it's a good show.
Bloody enough to satisfy fans who want their comedy with some bite.
Impressively light on its feet given that it's slogging through the twists and turns of a plot heavy on maggots, gore and rotting flesh.
Zipper has ambitions that go beyond mere prurient exploitation appeal, but the film's reach significantly exceeds its grasp.
The Curse of Downers Grove has more on its mind than the teenage body-count movie it resembles in all except the steadily escalating body count.
Brothers: Blood Against Blood is a surprisingly fast-paced and engaging drama rooted in subjects that never grow old.
Neither director Fouad Mikati nor writers Patricia Beauchamp and Joe Gossett seem to have found a new angle [on the rape-revenge genre].
Some Kind of Hate deserves credit for yoking the slasher-movie formula to an always timely message that's particularly relevant to the age group that dominates horror movie regulars.
Swirl together a pious message movie, a silly high-school yuck-fest and a raunchy, booty-shaking comedy, and this picture is the infelicitous result.
...a sadly obvious and pedantic exercise in making a classic story "relevant" to modern audiences.
Kkudos to the filmmakers for opting to use practical effects rather than 100% CGI, which would have been easier to do but also easier for viewers to dismiss out of hand.
[Hangar 10] breaks no new ground but delivers some creepy moments.
Depardieu lumbers through the film looking as though he's tormented by indigestion rather than a lust for vengeance.

Jamie Nash's script travels the road less taken; far from a gentle giant that just wants to be left in peace, his Sasquatch is a natural born killer with enough brains to outsmart underprepared interlopers on its home turf.
While the film lacks the macabre humor of the original story, it does an excellent job of conveying the creeping horror of Victorian medicine.
A wildly ambitious first feature whose lush visuals belie the fact that it was shot on 16mm for a mere $150,000.
The takeaway: Polygamy is complicated, something the average person could probably figure out without too much heavy thinking.
Brush with Danger appears to mean well...But the movie's laudable message is undermined by some terrible acting.
But ultimately, Autumn Blood, which proceeds at a pace that could be equally described as measured or glacial...feels less like a fully realized film than a half-imagined idea for one.

A noisy, hyperkinetic, visually gorgeous spectacle that tackles the mother of all big questions - the meaning of life - Terry Gilliam's latest is sometimes frustrating and occasionally outright goofy, but it's never dull.
The movie's father-son dynamics smack of too much therapy and some of the effects have an insubstantial computer-generated look, but the whole thing is fun for 11-year-olds of all ages.
But it's an unusually clever and even subtle genre movie, one that gives viewers everything they expect plus an extra little turn of the screw. And what more could you ask?
...The Quitter is destined for niche markets where, with any luck, it will find a core audience of viewers looking for movies with more heart than razzle-dazzle.

While its theatrical prospects are limited...The Frontier could find a strong second life via cable and streaming video, particularly among older moviegoers looking for character-driven dramas rather than action-heavy genre pictures.
The Damned could find a niche as part of a Halloween possess-a-thon, but on its own there's just not much to it.
The Possession of Michael King is nothing new, but it gets the job done.
So let the viewer beware: Moebius' rubbernecking appeal is hard to resist, but you run the risk of winding up feeling like a mouse caught in the hypnotic snare of a snake's unblinking gaze.
Aimed squarely at the elusive point where the attention spans of young children, teenagers and adults meet, the 3D Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles strikes it with surprising regularity.
Fans of neo-noir thrillers could do worse than to give The Lookalike a look.
[Why Don't You Play in Hell? isn't] for everyone-it's not even for every diehard movie buff-but for fans of Asian shock cinema it's a treat.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: First-time feature directors Zeke and Simon Hawkins deliver a smart, polished feature from a twisty, tightly constricted script.
[Late Phases is] a sly, rueful rarity that plays its monster-movie tropes straight, but gives them a poignant little twist.
[Home Sweet Hell is] nothing more or less than a toothless satire of suburban conformity that might have felt a little more dangerous six decades ago.
Imagine 'Mad Max' populated by suburban morons crossed with 'On the Beach' through the eyes of people who just want to get messed up.
Unfortunately, the film ultimately peters out rather than coming to a satisfactorily disquieting conclusion.
While not a breakout feature, Out of the Dark should appeal to genre fans looking for fare beyond the usual slasher movies and creature pictures.
A meta-variation on Clive Barker's Nightbreed, Digging Up the Marrow tackles all the same questions [...] with considerably less grace and intelligence.
For all its au courant posturing, Girl House doesn't even cut it as old wine in a new bottle.
[A] supremely silly film.
[Enter the Dangerous Mind] lacks the depth and resonance required to keep it from being merely unpleasant.
[Ghoul] is remarkably creepy, even if it's hard to work up a lot of initial sympathy for the callow, smug young filmmakers [at its core].
Though well-executed, [Alien Outpost is] ultimately overly familiar and predictable.
For viewers fond of Indian movies, this delirious Tamil melodrama [...] makes surprisingly short work of its three-and-a-half-hour running time.
Dark Summer falls short of knock-your-socks-off greatness: It's creepy and intelligent, but never leaps off the screen and into your nightmares.
Fans of backwoods horror won't be disappointed by Preservation, but more mainstream audiences are likely to be a hard sell.
Free the Nipple is ... a silly little bit of fluff and, worse, a painfully amateurish piece of filmmaking.
Ultimately, Theo's House is less preciously obscure than it sounds... But it's slow going nonetheless, and ultimately painfully obvious.
Poker Night is a clever little piece of filmmaking.
Whatever Dying of the Light was intended to be, the end result is feature-length sleeping pill with car chases.
A good, old-fashioned alien-encounter picture.
[The Phoenix Project boasts a] slow build, subtle characterizations and a story that toys with genre expectations without betraying them.
Frequently funny -- sometimes very funny indeed.
This persuasive documentary about the sled-dog industry focuses on the economics of animal cruelty and aims to inform rather than entertain.
Both dull and pretentious.

The gleeful sadism and snarky dialogue of the film's opening scenes quickly gives way to something darker and more disorienting, driven by a deep, coruscating disgust at the world's venal duplicity and corruption.
Through Hanks' and Talancon's subtle, naturalistic performance [writer-director Eric Nicholas] cultivates a human dimension often missing from thrillers.

Bean carves out his own modest variations on the theme of John Ryder-on-the-storm, but Bush and Knighton are so blandly forgettable that it's hard to believe that they're the protagonists and not Victims 1 and 2.

Writer-director Azazel Jacob's bittersweet, wistfully minimalist comedy charts a day and a half in the lives of two restless, unhappy men -- both named Rodolfo Cano -- and the woman who finds herself trapped in the mesh of their discontents.
Though the film's raison d'etre is the big croc, veteran genre screenwritering team John D. Brancato and Michael Ferris pin some boldly provocative thoughts on motor-mouthed Steven Johnson's sleeve.
Uneven but filled with flashes of painful insight into the pitfalls awaiting adolescent girls.
Unlike most mainstream filmmakers, Ratnam doesn't try to include something for everyone, but he does deliver several handsome production numbers.
The mockumentary conceit gives a vivid immediacy to the material, and the PAL digital video cinematography is often surprisingly lyrical.
For all the sundered families, bereaved mothers and mourning spouses, there's not a shred of genuine feeling in the entire film.
The attractive youngsters run, scream, declare that this can't be happening and repeat as necessary.
movie_title: I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately aimed at a Christian audience looking for genre entertainment with a certain sense of propriety, the film tries to serve two masters and doesn't quite deliver for either.
In all, it's a peculiar mishmash, simultaneously bland and suggestive.
Formulaic though it is, the story hits the right emotional buttons and promises that hope and dogged work trump despair.
The sordid psychodrama comes to a jaw-dropper of a conclusion that's oddly touching despite its outrageous proposal that marriage is the cure for post-traumatic shock syndrome.
Ranks with the best examinations of children's inner lives, but be warned: Its haunting insights are best left to adults.
Criticizing such a gentle film too vigorously would be like giving Peter Rabbit or Tom Kitten a swift kick in the nose.
With lesser actresses in the leads, it could be merely nasty, but in Dench and Blanchett's hands, it's scathingly tragic without ever resorting to vulgar melodrama.
... Seraphim Falls is a pale shadow of Leone's The Good, The Bad and The Ugly ...
Morgan borrows Christmas-specific nastiness from a wide range of fright flicks, but the result is less than the sum of its parts.
The film's underdeveloped characters and thin -- though busy -- story are forced into the foreground, and its 88-minute running time feels far longer.
While the cast is uniformly committed, some are able to make more of the material than others.
When Cooper is on screen it's mesmerizing.
De France finds the hint of sadness beneath the ready smile and knows how to play genuine, self-effacing goodness.
There are fewer laughs and more lectures... but there's plenty of sass and soul in between.

This bittersweet indie's greatest asset is that stars [Jonathan] Bray and [Wilson] Cruz have both real chemistry and a real problem -- as opposed to a series of trumped-up plot machinations -- standing in the way of romance.

Writer-director Marc Lawrence's dispiriting romantic comedy is a formulaic exercise in mismatched characters doing stupid things to delay the moment when they fall in love, then doing more stupid things to temporarily derail their budding romance.
The Zodiac case receded into limbo, and Bulkley's film ends on an inconclusive and profoundly unsatisfying note.
Despite the high-powered credits... this slight cautionary tale about slumming rich kids is a minor effort.
Marred by a certain awkward earnestness.
In the aftermath of 9/11, its assertion that religious terrorism is about more than simply faith is food for thought.
While [director] Kudlacek lets some of the elder statesmen ramble, their recollections are a vivid, firsthand window into a bygone era of American art.
For all the shallowly witty banter, Max and company are even less interesting than Annie and Alvy.
Filmmaker Mani Ratnam leavens his trademark politically charged melodrama with a smoking belly dance by sultry Mallika Sherawat and a wet-sari number for the stunning Rai.
The Pangs keep it moving and deliver the 'gotcha!' moments, but a steady diet of mechanical scares is thin stuff.

Miller gives a go-for-broke performance as the increasingly desperate and undone Sedgwick. But she lacks the fragile charisma evident in even the coarsest Warhol films, and without it there's no reason to care.
The twists and turns continue until the very end of Choi's mesmerizing, high-energy romp, whose 139 minutes zip by like a round of speed poker.
Just when the film seems to be getting bogged down in 'before I made it big' anecdotes, Gurwitch wisely broadens her focus, interviewing ordinary victims of corporate 'right-sizing.'
The stage is set for emotional pyrotechnics that never quite materialize, because for all their squabbles, grudges and grievances, they all basically love each other.

Ultimately, Mantel and Skrovan achieve the goal of reminding a generation that grew up enjoying the protections that Nader had spearheaded. But they also frankly acknowledge that the very qualities that made him an incorruptible activist also blinded him.
The film, though admirably ambitious, is resolutely earthbound, mired in ick and slime and never more wooden than in the delirious climax.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay, which differs significantly from the novel, is uneven, but the distorted mirror it holds up to the present is disturbingly clear.
Robert De Niro's icy drama, from Eric Roth's densely researched original screenplay, unfolds over the course of two decades and traces the history of modern-day spycraft.
... this intricately plotted mystery ventures into darker psychological territory and never misses a step.
Emilio Estevez's lament for the lost ideals of the '60s draws heavily from the Robert Altman playbook.
Reservations aside, the film marks the beginning of a new phase in James Bond's history, and it promises to be a gripping one.
Lipsky puts utterly ordinary lives under a microscope and finds a teeming microcosm of chaos no less devastating for being so unremarkable.
Director, cowriter, coproducer and star LaMarre is more interested in Jesus' teachings than in his suffering, and suggests that race may have helped shape the course of biblical events.

The film has a worn, live-in feel, and its unhurried narrative captures the subtle rhythms of small-town life. Nothing much happens on the surface, but worlds of hope, hurt and determination lie right behind the characters' eyes, waiting to be discovered.
A whiff of the ridiculous taints every scene.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a slow slog to a payoff that isn't worth the effort.
A trippy trifle from the Charlie Kaufman/Michel Gondry school of pop metafiction.
In the end, the tiny Shimohira's voice is the most powerful, bearing witness in hopes that future generations will choose peace over war.
Only Rejtman's sharp eye for absurd detail and the bleakly subtle joke separates comedy from tragedy.
It's a fearless performance and yields some squirm-inducingly funny moments.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's no particular message to their joint feature-film debut, except perhaps that chance plays a significant part in the direction people's lives take, but it's an entertaining diversion whose clever structure gives pulp-crime cliches a welcome twist.
If not a social history of the '60s, it's a close examination of a quintessential '60s phenomenon that speaks volumes about the attitudes and experiences that shaped the decade.
Crammed with outrageous turns of fortune and quicksilver shifts in tone, Almodovar's film is held together by performances so subtle and complex it's hard to single out only one as exceptional.
The emphasis on character is a welcome change, but the principle of diminishing returns still holds.
Given the controversy, which strongly suggested that the filmmakers had it in for President Bush, the film's biggest shocker may be how kind Range and coscreenwriter Simon Finch are to him.
[The film] combines live action and their trademark animation into a creepy, glittering object whose dreamlike quality are mesmerizing to a particular kind of sensibility.

The sad thing is that Arnett, Shepard and McBride quickly establish a loose, easy camaraderie that's a real pleasure to watch. The shame is that they're working with such unrewarding material.
An intoxicatingly beautiful but painfully simplistic fable about love and death.

The film benefits from a strong cast; McConaughey's Lengyel is eccentric but ultimately engaging, while David Strathairn and Ian McShane, as Dedmon and a grief-stricken father, respectively, deliver subtly powerful performances.

A deep and astonishingly authentic streak of melancholy runs through this fifth sequel to the 1976 sleeper that made both struggling actor Sylvester Stallone and hard-luck slugger Rocky Balboa international stars.
Soderbergh's film is no more cynical or world-weary than its inspirations, and in the end, it feels like a clever trick wrapped around a hollow center.
This puff piece is shapeless, repetitive and feels much longer than it is.
Murphy is a revelation as James, and what American Idol castoff Hudson lacks in technical acting craft she makes up for in raw energy and a voice that could melt the rhinestones off a beauty queen.

Director Gary Winick doesn't downplay the tough stuff -- a matter-of-fact cut from Wilbur's first reprieve to a pan full of frying breakfast bacon connects adorable pink piglets and yummy pork products with admirable clarity.

The acting is flat, and the scientist's ideological speeches too bluntly designed to mirror post-9/11 rhetoric. But there's a dreamy fascination to the iconic images of machines fighting a perpetual war for the human creators they'll inevitably outlast.

Solomonoff cuts back and forth between 1984 and 1976, gradually revealing the truth of what happened, but the mystery is less important than the complex relationship between Natalia and Elena, which was sorely tested by events beyond their control.
Good pulp fiction is driven by the truths beneath the conventions. Prefab junk runs on contempt for fans, with a layer of goodies and gimmicks on top.
Zwick and screenwriter Charles Leavitt are torn between the competing masters of popular entertainment and education, and they wind up serving neither well.

There isn't an original moment in the mix, but it's not as crass or vulgar as much of what passes for 'family friendly' entertainment, and it keeps the precocious pop-culture references to a blessed minimum.
It's a mesmerizing vision of the past refracted through the dark obsessions of the present.
The laughs are low, the breasts are high, and the film is instantly forgettable.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, the film feels unfocused and attenuated, despite its brief running time.

A rare example of truly independent filmmaking, not only because of the way it was produced, but because it makes no effort to mimic the attitudes and style of contemporary mainstream Hollywood films.
The story's structure is overly configured, and [writer David] Greig's characters feel less like people than bullet points.
This retelling of the familiar tale is as solemnly predictable as a Catholic-school nativity play, and nearly as dull.
There isn't enough plot to fill out the film's 90-minute running time, but there are rude laughs ... and inspired bits tucked in amid the padding.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Diaz refuses to accept received wisdom about the RUF's savagery, and it clearly took more than one revolutionary movement to reduce Sierra Leone to abject poverty.
Scrappy and defiantly deglamorized, this chronicle of a couple of long, useless days in the life of a down-and-out coke addict oozes miserable authenticity without giving you a reason to care.
[The film] squanders a promising premise and a lot of cool special effects on a story that gets more ridiculous and less involving with each passing minute.

[The screenwriter] does an admirable job of streamlining a story that unfolds over the course of 20 years. Meanwhile, Apted allows his fine cast the breathing room to make historical figures feel like living, breathing people rather than waxworks.
This film stands as a tribute to the actresses who put their hearts on the line.
Flawed, but it knows where it's going, and it gets there in a chilling blaze of fire, blood and poisonous fog.
Spare, elegant and tailor-made for intense discussions over dark coffee, Boe's film is a slily bold and delightfully inventive variation on an age-old theme.

Uniquely warped Canadian cult filmmaker Guy Maddin's gleefully perverse exploration of feverish childhood terrors is audacious, hypnotic and utterly breathtaking, a near-silent film, almost entirely a black-and-white mosaic of starkly striking images.
You never know what you'll get, but it will always look ravishing.
Deraspe's film begins as a mystery and becomes a razor-sharp dissection of the self-promotion, pretension and deeply cynical inner workings of the art world.
While he tries not to lapse into the formula that has reduced sports films to white-hat/black-hat certitudes, the evenhandedness doesn't offset the film's fundamental dullness.
Spider-Man 3 is crammed with goodies.
Despite its failings, Wind Chill represents a road rarely taken by 21st-century American horror films: Original (in the non-remake sense of the term), subtle and restrained.

The "cute" kids are insufferable, but leads Ali Khan and Mukerji radiate the unabashed star quality that's all but gone from American movies -- poverty and desperation haven't looked so glamorous since the glory days of Joan Crawford.
There no way around it: Russell's performance is spunky and just about irresistible, no matter how much you hate spunk. It's hard to imagine Waitress working without her.
The film's artistry makes it possible to consider the subject without sniggering or recoiling reflexively.
Where [the Swedish version] was a downbeat story of cruel, capricious fate and hard, haunting choices, The Invisible is a formulaic tale of redemption and teen angst.
Sly, subtle and very French psychological drama.

Perhaps the worst aspect of this shameless rehash of better movies like Battle Royale (2000), Series 7 (2001) and even The Running Man (1987) is not its astonishing dullness but its pretentions to moral rectitude.

Olympia tries to impose order on a loosely shaped series of interviews with and about her dad via voice-over narration, but her trivial, self-absorbed musings only make the film seem more like an accomplished home movie than a serious documentary.
The films of writer/director Francis Veber are a bracing reminder that French comedies can be every bit as broad, unsophisticated and cliched as their American counterparts.
The story is compelling enough that even glib phrases like 'healing through hip-hop' can't drag it down.
Craven never quite manages to make it all seem a smoothly integrated piece.
The film's feisty cast and generally sunny outlook make for warm and reassuring comfort viewing, the equivalent of a straight-from-the-box dish of mac and cheese.

Caught between efforts to redress Eurocentric accounts of the conquest of Mexico and a tendency to slide into old-movie melodramatics, Carrasco's film is often gorgeous, never less than entertaining and occasionally moving.
[A] sublimely slippery, slightly surreal and not entirely 'just the facts, ma'am' documentary.
The New Jersey locations and soundtrack help ground the story in a particular time and place, and Schroeder delivers a terrific performance.
The story could easily bog down in its mix of cumulative incident and complicated interpersonal drama. But with Bekmambetov at the helm, it's a high-energy blast.
Plays like Red Dragon reimagined by filmmakers who think they're too smart or too sophisticated or too high-minded to give themselves over to the sordid, sleazy and flat-out nasty.
If less thematically dazzling than Millennium Actress, it's suffused with a giddy sense of the seething, mutable landscape of the mind.

[Doc's] failure to systematically lay clear, linear historical groundwork for the events of late 2004 and 2005 is obviously deliberate, but without it the film is unenlightening to anyone not already conversant with the history of modern Ukraine.
Cynical, misanthropic and embittered. Von Trier delivers some rueful, strangled laughs, most driven by the simmering guerrilla war between employees and management.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Besson's sniggering conception of Angela as a pure spirit in the body of a high-end hooker is just juvenile, and Andre is, frankly, a drag.
It's as laceratingly entertaining as its predecessor.
[Though] undermined by uneven performances, preachy digressions and a handful of clunky scenes, it's nonetheless compelling on a personal level.
The project's larger purpose is clearly to stimulate academic interest in youngsters brought up on Jurassic Park-style thrills.
Veers regularly into disease-of-the-week territory but is rescued by the powerhouse performances of Ken Watanabe and Kanako Higuchi.

A little bit nutty and pretty entertaining in a thoroughly unconvincing way. And watch out for that 11th-hour twist -- it's a head snapper.
This collection of cautionary anecdotes never adds up to much more than the sum of their obvious morals.

The real trouble is that the filmmakers consistently choose gags over character. Playing King Harold's death for comedy? He's Fiona's father, even if he is a frog -- Shrek would never have gone for a cheap laugh like that.
Minute-per-dollar, you get your money's worth, but an hour after you leave you'd be hard put to summarize the plot in any coherent way. If that's entertainment, then step right up!
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Provocative elements notwithstanding, there's less than meets the eye to Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu and Guillermo Arriaga's variations on the theme of miscommunication and devestatingly careless acts.

The film never degenerates into the mano-a-mano showdown between the grinning psycho and the cocky but fundamentally decent lawyer that's become de rigueur in big-budget Hollywood thrillers.
Story loses momentum in a wave of heavy-handed messages.

movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

Boon's film is both funny and heartbreaking, a supremely confident mix of political satire, free-floating paranoia, fractured family dynamics and the kind of comedy that regularly reconfigures itself into tragedy.

[Director Hattendorf's] willingess to shelter an aging, eccentric stranger brought about the ending that makes her film such a sweetly unsentimental charmer.
A chilling exercise in soul-eroding anxiety.

Won't win over any new fans to the form.
Handsomely photographed but painfully fey.
What's the difference between documentary and hagiography? Directors James Stern and Don Kempf don't seem to have given the matter much thought.

Fascinating? Absolutely.
Shrewder than you'd think and not half as dumb as it looks.
Cool hot-weather fun -- this will be the one to beat right through the dog days of summer.

Almost two hours of tedious vulgarity, which leaves plenty of time to feel sorry for Greenwood, whose efforts to deliver a warm, subtle performance are regularly upstaged by poo jokes and bratty hijinks.
Dutch filmmaker Paul Verhoeven returns to his roots with a WWII drama that's easily the best thing he's made in years.

Stylish and twisty, but not clever enough to support its more outrageous plot machinations.

Malkovich pulls out all the gaudy stops.
A sleek, taut entertainment spiked with timely political bile.
Does it feel like the real thing? No. Is it an incredible simulation? Yes, it's pretty incredible.

Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist David Turnley's first feature, photographed in shimmering black and white, is a portrait of the Havana dance hall La Tropical, but is first and foremost a celebration of Cuban dance and music.

The film is a singular achievement, if not one suited to all tastes and sensibilities. It's a creation on the order of David Lynch's Eraserhead (1977) or Guy Maddin's Tales From The Gimli Hospital (1988).

Brooke and Gary articulate their discontent with considerable precision and occasional verve. It's that they haven't figured out a way to make emotional torment funny, which is the tall order inherent in anti-romantic comedy.

Lurid though the material is, the film is scrupulously anti-erotic.
A crass, tedious sequel.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mess that works on the level of swoony fantasy if you're willing to accept that it makes absolutely no sense, not even within the context of its supernatural premise.
To call the film noisy and brainless isn't even a criticism -- it's unadulterated auto-porn, as shallow and shiny as it wants to be.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Richard Linklater wraps novelist Philip K. Dick's paranoid, prescient nightmare of addiction and identity lost down the rabbit hole in the same rotoscoped animation that helped produce the blissed-out groove of his Waking Life.
You can't beat on Dead Man's Chest on value-for-money terms, but it's like an all-you-can-eat buffet -- everything's tasty, the surfeit is sickening.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A fable of childhood's end with monsters, Miike's goofy, gallant, action-packed fantasy deserves to become a classic family film.

There's a surprisingly sharp little sting hidden in this sleek throwback to old-fashioned Hollywood melodramas about sweet young things thrown into the lairs of hard-edged harpies who value their careers above all things womanly.

Impassioned, unwieldy and padded with celebrity interviews, Paine's documentary ends on a surprisingly upbeat note.

A clear-eyed look at the pleasures and price of abandoning conventional mores for experimental lifestyles.

Strident, bombastic parable.
Rees' performance, of the variety customarily called 'fearless,' is the only reason to endure this tedious, arid glimpse into the S&M subculture.
