The film hardly moves in the first hour or so, picking up speed only after the intermission -- in fact it seems a little rushed in the second half.
Raman Raghav 2.0 may be Anurag Kashyap's baby (he's both director and co-writer) but the film belongs to Siddiqui who really steps into the shoes of the deranged character he's playing.
Aarif Shaikh and Aditya Banerjee's tight editing of Zaidi's script keeps the film fast paced. Even though it slows slightly after the interval, it picks up pace in the last quarter of the film.
It's disappointing to see a man of Mani Ratnam's calibre pen a story that loses its plot as it keeps presenting the same thing over and over again in slightly different settings.
Please don't try to understand a Salman Khan film. Simply, love it.
At one point when you think the film is over, it drags on for another 20 minutes.
SRK held the film from the beginning, first as the geek then as the superhero. Little Verma was good as Prateek while Rampal always makes a good baddie.
Despite good performances all around, it is Malhotra who plays Shahida alias Munni who steals the show.

The film's predictability and looseness of plot, which Khan tried to cover up under the garb of a (not-so-funny) comedy is quite tangible. You keep expecting it to grab your attention with each following scene. But that scene never comes.
All is not well with All Is Well. Watch it at your own risk.
It's very rare that I go into a theatre without the least expectations and come out smiling. Fugly is one of those rare moments.
How long can you watch a handsome face with all the expressiveness of a rock? That question will haunt you as you sit through John Abraham's new action thriller, Rocky Handsome.
Hrithik Roshan re-defines male privilege in Kaabil, his latest revenge drama, and serves it up with a distasteful flourish.
Watch this if you are a fan of Akshay Kumar and can turn a blind eye to some blatant objectification of women.
Watch this if you want to see a love story with lovers that are not squeaky clean.
This grand love tragedy requires you to show a willingness to be transported to a land where lovers are skittish and crazy.
While Shamitabh may not be gripping from start to finish, it's a treat to watch its lead actors.
Watch this if your are in the mood to see a pair of good-looking men act like boys.
Kill Dil doesn't offer any riveting twists, but you don't feel like putting a bullet to your head at the end of it either.
Shaadi Ke Side Effects redeems itself as we go along.
If you are looking for a propaganda-free film, then this is not it.
Between Amayra Dastur's shrill voice and Arunoday Singh's scowling, there's little to be enjoyed.
The suspense to the drama was so lame that we felt bad for the feisty Bobby and Balan: both deserved a riveting, gripping ending.
Some of the jokes and sharp dialogues were lost in translation and that's a tragedy. But don't let that dissuade you from watching Finding Fanny.
Don't skip this if you have a thing for happily-ever-after endings.
Amitabh Bachchan, Nawazuddin Siddiqui and Vidya Balan play their roles with elan, but a meandering plot proves the film's undoing.
Watch Mary Kom if you are a Priyanka Chopra fan.
Note to the Dishoom team: there's nothing remotely cool about blowing smoke into people's faces and, dude, such stupidity is going to just blow up your handsome face.
[Dishkiyaoon] is laughable and unintentionally funny. The gangsters in this drama speak in rhymes and riddles.
Weak links aside, it's a satisfying watch.
The twists are far too predictable and lame. Also, stereotypes such as the villains being dark-skinned and unwashed are peddled with cheerful abandon here.
Please don't try to understand a Salman Khan film. Simply, love it.
Sidharth Malhotra does the heavy-lifting in this genre-blending action-romance, but it will leave you unmoved.
Watch this film if you are a Khan fan and want to learn a thing or two about religious tolerance without making it a bitter pill for viewers.
It's engaging to watch a powerful actor and his seemingly powerless admirer indulge in a twisted battle of wills.
Bombay Velvet makes for a good one-time watch primarily due to good performances from its lead actors and a reminder of a forgotten era.
If you are looking for an all brawn and no brains feature, then watch Baaghi. Otherwise, it is wise to duck this missile of a movie.
Dangal is the last major film to be rolled out in 2016 and Khan has saved the best for the last for his fans.
Director Aniruddha Roy Chowdhury brings out the fears of single women working in a bustling metropolis such as Delhi with great dexterity.
If you are expecting Hashmi to deliver a captain's innings here, then you are looking up the wrong film.
While this may not be Pandey's best Bollywood innings, it's definitely watchable.
Tamasha may have its heart in the right place, but the conflict in Ved and Tara's lives will not get your pulse racing.
Don't give up on Dhanak. Stay with Pari and Chhotu, There's definitely a dhanak (rainbow) at the end of it all.
Wazir proves to show that actors are reduced to pawns if there's no solid story backing them.
Syed Ahmad Afzal injects verve into this dark drama by creating characters that are endearing.
Sarbjit feels too contrived and never becomes powerfully evocative.
There are moments in Fitoor which are brilliant, but they are few and far between.
Airlift is raw and real.
Watch this one for Bhatt and Hooda. They are at their vulnerable, rugged best. Plus, if you are in the mood to see India in its raw, unpolished state, Highway can be an exhilarating ride.
While the notion that the power of the common man shouldn't be underestimated is noble in Jai Ho, I wish its makers had also remembered not to underestimate their common sense.
If you are not squeamish about worm-infested pizzas or bloodied ghosts, you shouldn't hesitate to take a bite into this one.
Farah Khan seems to have taken a misstep with Happy New Year.
Watch this film if you are strictly a Shah Rukh Khan or Anushka Sharma fan. Others will hesitate to put a ring on this romantic comedy.
While the first half is amusing, the second half gets sluggish in the last 20 minutes.
Kapoor & Sons flourishes as a unit and is the sum total of mature performances by the entire Kapoor clan.
The movie has been perfectly cast. It's the pacing that's a let down.
Watch this if you are looking for an engaging film about love, extraordinary bravery and honour. But keep the tissues near by. You will need them.
The premise was promising, but the film never soars dramatically.
[Chef] is modern, funny and leaves you hungry for more.
There are several things that Secret Superstar, a tale of a repressed teenager in a town in Gujarat, gets right.
The love story is painfully predictable.
Both Sinha and Kashyap keep the film's momentum going with their arresting screen presence.
Give this romantic comedy a try if you are a fan of Khan.
Strong performances by the actress the rest of the cast gives this feel good film a lot of heart.
Watch this if you are in the mood for a comedy that doesn't require you to apply your intelligence.
Watch this if you are in the mood to see a stoic, stone-faced swashbuckling superhero, aka Salman Khan, and some supremely well-executed action sequences. Don't go looking for soul, though.

It's a delightful ringside view of athletes trying to make it in sports that are considered insignificant in India. Plus, how many times can you boast of watching a Hindi film that has flawed, but ferocious leads?
My eyes, my eyes! How do I unsee Nirdosh?
While all the actors were earnest in their roles, it's the reductive and predictable plot that lets them down.
Carbon is a mind-teaser. Watch this if you are in the mood for a thriller that doesn't tread the conventional path.
It's Kumar and Apte's show all the way as they take one for the women's team. Make sure to watch this inspirational film this weekend.
You get the distinct impression that it's the director who's scared of going rogue and demonising the establishment or the men in uniform.
What's interesting is that director Ranjan has done a splendid job of creating a believable extended family...If you are in the mood for a spirited bromance, then be sure to watch this one.
It's compelling, but leaves you eventually disturbed.
3 Storeys, which is well-cast with suitable talents, is a quirky cinematic experiment. Like bedtime stories, some stick while others are entirely forgettable.

The movie works in parts, but is anticlimactic because it doesn't work as a whole...But don't hesitate to give this film a shot. Powered by collective superlative acting, Aami has its flaws, but paints a compelling portrait of an idol with feet of clay.
There's nothing remotely redeeming about this film. Watch this at your own risk.
Prepare for some chills and thrills if you're heading to check out Daniel Radcliffe's post-Potter debut.
Everybody in Judwaa 2 overacts, and the dialogues feel like they were written by an adolescent for his high school drama.
In a matter of minutes you are invested in their lives and the sheer pace of the events that follow leaves you breathless, in a good way.
Anushka Sharma and her co-stars are ferociously good in this succinct thriller.
Despite a few hitches and ridiculous twists, Akira makes for an engaging watch.
Jai Gangaajal is crammed with issues such as corporate greed, debt-ridden farms, lawless cities and frustrated civilians, but there's no particular direction to all that chaos.
Force 2 is engaging enough to give it a shot.
As far as performances go, every one does their bit but they are let down by a confused storyline. Watch this only if you are a Rock On groupie, otherwise skip it.
Love is complicated and director Nitya Mehra makes it her business to educate us about how much work it takes to keep a relationship sturdy.
Heartbreak and unrequited love are gut-wrenching. Director Karan Johar makes it his mission to emotionally pummel us with them in Ae Dil Hai Mushkil.
Baahubali 2: The Conclusion is a colorful amalgamation of hit serials like Game Of Thrones and those archaic Indian mythological series such as Mahabharata or the Ramayna.
Just like the string of swanky cars and comic sidekicks rolled out in Dilwale, the movie is mostly sheen with a smattering of substance.
While the first half has some laugh-out loud moments, the second half meanders. But the climax, which has some golden moments, wrap things up nicely.
The way the worlds of a cop, a heroin addict, a rock star and a doctor intersect is cleverly shown. Be sure to give Udta Punjab a shot.
If you are looking for a heartwarming, sensitive film about troubled twenty-somethings, then make a date with Dear Zindagi. You won't live to regret it.
[1920 London] exhausts every cliche that has been regurgitated in Bollywood love stories.
You know what's coming long before it plays out and that makes it tedious and soul-destroying.
Watch this film if you are fan of syrupy romances or Ranveer Singh's groupie. Otherwise, jump into this at your own risk.
Madaari was engaging and touched upon some deep subjects such as corruption, the power of social media and public opinion, with alacrity.
Just like a marriage that has seen better days, this film was potent with promise but doesn't cash in on its potential.
Perhaps, this is all an attempt to appeal to the younger crowd. But the older ones might not feel the love.
What could have been an interesting premise and a nick at the seemingly utopian nature of suburban marriages disintegrates into a film that focuses on celebrating the hero, played by Kumar.
After watching this, the question about who is the wounded one - the viewer or the hero - may arise.
Mat achieves exhilaration from his angle shooting and the feeling throughout out of a concave screen. Whatever feel of baseball this picture has is the result of his running camera.
The movie's verve comes from the abstract use of a jangling zither and from squirting Orson Welles into the plot piece-meal with a tricky, facetious eyedropper.
The result is a gripping movie that often makes you wish its director, Zinnemann, knew as much about American life as he does about the art of telling a story with a camera.
An uncompromising study of American decadence displaying a sad, worn, methodical beauty few films have had since the late twenties.

While telling this story, haltingly and clumsily, the movie runs from burdensome through heavy and dull to bad. It stutters and stumbles as Welles submerges Tarkington's story in a mess of radio and stage technique.
The Big Sleep, though, is witty and sinister, and in an odd way is a realistic portrayal of big-city life with Arabian Nights overtones.

Capra is an old-time movie craftsman, the master of every trick in the bag, and in many ways he is more at home with the medium than any other Hollywood director. But all of his details give the impression of contrived effect.
It is a movie that takes its own measured, deliberate time finding ways to increase your pleasure.

Pandro Berman, the producer, and Clarence Brown, the director, have made it into a conservatively exciting and engaging film whose chief virtue is its acting, especially a letter-perfect, beautifully felt performance by Mickey Rooney as the jockey.
The bogus art which has been creeping into the Disney pictures is really hammered at you in this one.
[The script] tends to resolve its problems by having the cast embrace, fraternity-brother fashion, and break out into full-throated ballads.
The production, mainly because of Michael Curtiz's direction, is unimaginative and badly hoked-up.
The Paramount crew that worked on Roman Holiday reminded me of expert marksmen who had made "charm" their target and seldom if ever missed it.

While definitely athletic, pageant-minded and somewhat recognizable after all of the war dramas that have come out since Elizabethan times, no movie has given a more poignant impression of men in battle or been so cutting about the waste and folly of war.
movie_title: Henry V (The Chronicle History of King Henry the Fift with His Battell Fought at Agincourt in France) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: Employee of the Month knows it has a flimsy premise but it simply doesn't care. It's an agreeable comedy that makes its priorities clear: It wants to be funny at the expense of almost everything else.

The movie, based on the novel by Janette Oke, shows how time and belief can help deal with tragedies. These solutions, however, when applied to the LaHayes' particular tragedy, make for a stagnantly morose plot.
... despite these narrative shortcomings, what the actors accomplish is truly impressive; they embody their roles so convincingly that what's onscreen always feels authentic.

The film clearly puts its time, energy and promotion into its dance sequences and anyone who plans to attend the movie presumably will see it for that reason. On that level, they certainly will be entertained.
While this might sound amusing, animated inanimate objects can only do so much bouncing and rolling before their shtick gets stale.
The film succeeds because of the great lengths to which Ashmol goes to bring her peace of mind.
The Boys' & Girls' Guide To Getting Down is primarily a mock-instructional video about how to get the most out of your nightlife (albeit from a decidedly L.A. perspective).
movie_title: The Boys & Girls Guide to Getting Down (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Manny Lewis] and the rest of an endearing ensemble populate a film that, like their lives, progresses leisurely with a graceful balance of humor and melancholy.
The film exposes one of its most distracting flaws: its low production values.
What feels amusingly anarchic on the small screen feels underdeveloped and disjointed on the big screen, perhaps because instead of commercials gluing the jokes together there's dead air.
Set in wartime Iraq, The Situation is exploitation cinema of the most narcoleptic kind.
Literally and existentially down and dirty, In the Pit is an absorbing documentary about work and the transformation of men into laborers.
The Decomposition of the Soul tackles the unsettling topic of the East German Stasi in a way that might make your flesh crawl.
Notes on Marie Menken shines a welcome ray of light on a largely forgotten figure in the American avant-garde film scene.
A film about love and art, about passing time and time passing, Avenue Montaigne is a humble pleasure.
The thriller Breach manages to excite and unnerve despite our knowing the ending.
Lars and the Real Girl is part comedy, part tragedy and 100 percent pure calculation.
Antibodies brings together a philosophically minded serial killer, a devoutly religious cop and a cynical filmmaker clearly itching to go Hollywood.

Amazing Grace, a prettified take on the life and times of the 18th-century reformer William Wilberforce, carries a strong whiff of piety. It isn't a bad smell; there are notes of roses and treacle in the mix, but also elements of sweat and pain.
Muscles bulge and heads explode in this thoroughly reprehensible, satisfyingly violent entertainment about men and guns and things that go boom.
David Fincher's magnificently obsessive new film Zodiac is part police procedural, part monster movie, a funereal entertainment that is a testament to this cinematic savant's gifts.
The Host is a loopy, feverishly imaginative genre hybrid about the demons that haunt us from without and within.
The Page Turner is finally ersatz Chabrol, absent the master's perverse wit, complex psychology, social sensitivities and visual flair.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A depressing story, certainly, as well as moving, confusing and, at a fast 72 minutes, at once undercooked and overpadded.
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gently and quietly told, Daratt (Dry Season) is an unassumingly political work that unfolds with the simplicity of a parable and the gravity of a Bible story.
After the Wedding is a modern creation with a classic theme involving haves and have-nots, bloodlines and family ties.
This tender portrait of late-1960s French youth stars Louis Garrel as Franois, a 20-year-old Parisian struggling through the fires of revolutionary promise and its smoldering remains.
Paul Verhoeven' Black Book encompasses the best and very worst of its director's signature pulp brutalism, which means it's pretty much a hoot.
Killer of Sheep, largely hidden from view for three decades, is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone.
The only remotely notable thing about this particular jumble of boos, bangs and door creaks is that it tries to wed the horror trend with the heated-up God market.
The Number 23 is an accidental comedy starring a deadly serious Jim Carrey.
A dark fairy tale from Russia, The Italian pulls you into a richly atmospheric, persuasively inhabited world teeming with foundlings and pathos.
The third film iteration of The Painted Veil turns W. Somerset Maugham's distaff bildungsroman into a fine romance.
In Freedom Writers Hilary Swank uses neediness to fine effect in a film with a strong emotional tug and smartly laid foundation.
The brilliance of Borat is that its comedy is as pitiless as its social satire, and as brainy.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The third though probably not the last in the successful Clause franchise, this latest installment again stars Tim Allen as the Everyman turned Father Christmas.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Fur is a folly, though not a dishonorable one.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In Copying Beethoven Ed Harris proves an ideal substitute for the deaf, brooding composer, acting with a violent turbulence that sometimes floods the room.
In The Cave of the Yellow Dog, set in Mongolia, the dog is cute, the children are adorable, and the earth and the sky seem to stretch on without limit.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The latest James Bond vehicle finds the British spy leaner, meaner and a whole lot darker.
Even in a story about singing-and-dancing fat and feather, the director George Miller cant help but go dark and deep.
he her in the title of Jean-Luc Godard's 1967 film is meant to be Paris. There is, however, another 'her.'
movie_title: 2 ou 3 Choses que je Sais d'Elle (Two or Three Things I Know About Her) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: ... doesn't add anything substantively new to [the story of heroin addiction], though it has been nicely directed by Neil Armfield ...
An action flick in which the gaudy pyrotechnics are nowhere near as jaw-dropping as the screenplay that name-checks not one, not two, but three national tragedies.
This jolly rock n roll comedy, sprinkled with amusing one-liners and hilarious sight gags, is a spinoff from the short-lived HBO comedy series starring Jack Black and Kyle Gass.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This documentary is an unblinking, often disturbing look at industrial food production from field to factory.
If stupidity were a crime, the nitwits in the cheap horror flick Turistas would be doing time in Attica.
David Lynch's extraordinary, savagely uncompromised new film is as cracked as Mad magazine, though generally more difficult to parse.
The makers this exceptionally foolish thriller starring a most excellent Leonardo DiCaprio, want you to know there may be blood on your hands, specifically your wedding finger.
The Holiday is a tale of two women, two houses, two love interests -- Jude Law pairs with Cameron Diaz, Jack Black gets lucky with Kate Winslet -- but it's also about movie love.
Steven Soderbergh attempts to resurrect the magic of classical Hollywood, principally by sucking out all the air, energy and pleasure from his own filmmaking.
A fairy tale in realist drag, The Pursuit of Happyness is the kind of entertainment that goes down smoothly until it gets stuck in your craw.
Private Fears in Public Places is far from difficult and that, it is also worth noting, is not a criticism. The film is accessible, pleasant, dreamy, a touch goofy and melancholic.
In The Case of the Grinning Cat, the filmmaker Chris Marker fluidly moves over and under Paris, capturing images of fugitive beauty and pathos.
movie_title: The Case of the Grinning Cat (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Directed by Robert De Niro, The Good Shepherd is an origin story about the C.I.A., and for the filmmakers that story boils down to fathers who fail their sons.
Children of Men, the superbly directed political thriller by Alfonso Cuarn, may be something of a bummer, but it's the kind of glorious bummer that lifts you to the rafters.
Judi Dench and Cate Blanchett star in a misanthropic game of cat and mouse from which no one emerges unscathed, including saps like us who think we're watching a film about other people.
Alpha Dog has much the same entertainment value you get from watching monkeys fling scat at one another in a zoo or reading the latest issue of Star magazine.
Year of the Dog is funny ha-ha but firmly in touch with its downer side, which means it's also funny in a kind of existential way.
It's too bad that Mr. Cage couldn't tap into those powers to save himself from another bad choice in roles.
All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick Pathfinder has little to recommend it.

As the ship moves closer to the Sun, and people and things begin to fall apart, Mr. Doyle and his screenwriter, Alex Garland, goose their science fiction with action- and horror-genre beats, increasingly turning up the chills and thrills.
Brutal, urgent, devastating -- the documentary The Devil Came on Horseback demands to be seen as soon as possible and by as many viewers as possible.
A modest, near-flawless gem, This Is England is a humbly, if insistently political, autobiographical homage to a lost world of youth.
For Jason Bourne, who rises and rises again in this fantastically kinetic, propulsive film, resurrection is the name of the game, just as it is for franchises.
With Dans Paris, Christophe Honor picks up where the early Franois Truffaut and his comrades-in-cinema left off -- with a playful, liberatory style, and a song in his heart.
Beautifully photographed, the elliptical, often mysterious and wholly beguiling film Colossal Youth looks and sounds as if it were made on another planet.
The junky, clunky, grimly unfunny Rush Hour 3 isn't the worst movie of the summer. But it's an enervating bummer nonetheless.
Horny is as horny does in the sweetly absurd high school comedy Superbad.
An unnerving, surprisingly affecting documentary about our environmental calamity [that] is such essential viewing.

The latest and lamest version of Invasion of the Body Snatchers might have been an accidental camp classic if its politics weren't so abhorrent and the movie didn't try to hide its ineptitude behind a veil of pomposity.
Sporadically funny, casually sexist, blithely racist and about as visually sophisticated as a parking-garage surveillance video.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One from the heart, Salvador Allende is a plaintive look back at the rise and violent fall of the world's first democratically elected Marxist president.
Something wicked this way comes in the nifty horror film The Last Winter, crawling through the hallways and howling into the dread night.
The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford adds another gauzy chapter to the overtaxed James myth, if not much rhyme or reason, heart or soul.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Far too readily tends to play this pathetic story for laughs.
There are ghosts haunting Banished, about the forced expulsion of black Southerners from their homes in the troubled and violent decades after the Civil War.
Lust, Caution is a sleepy, musty period drama about wartime maneuvers and bedroom calisthenics, and the misguided use of a solid director.
One lesson of Lake of Fire is the galvanizing power of the visual image. Sometimes a picture is worth a thousand words, and sometimes pictures are not enough.
It's hard to know who the audience might be for the documentary oddity Kurt Cobain About a Son, but I bet its subject would have hated it.
Dark in color, mood and outraged worldview, Michael Clayton is a film that speaks to the way we live now.
In the remake of Sleuth, what was once insignificant is now insufferable.
Nuri Bilge Ceylan's film paints a haunting portrait of existential solitude, one in which the images speak louder and often more forcefully than do any of the words.
The Hunting Party is a misfired, misguided would-be satire set in postwar Bosnia.
In the anime Tekkonkinkreet, two orphans of life's storms sail through the air like birds, like superheroes, like Jackie Chan.
Vaporous and chilled to freezing, Interview lacks a single honest moment, but it does have plenty of diverting ones.
Drama/Mexmeans to say something about its country of origin, though it's hard to know exactly what.
This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel.

The glib entertainment Fracture offers an assortment of tasty treats, notably the spectacle of that crafty scene stealer Anthony Hopkins mixing it up with that equally cunning screen nibbler Ryan Gosling.
Think of Hot Fuzz, a British parody of Hollywood-style action flicks, as The Full Monty blown to smithereens.
Zoo is, to a large extent, about the rhetorical uses of beauty. It is, rather more coyly, also about a man who died after having sex with a stallion.
The surfaces gleam as luxuriously in Johnnie To's exemplary gangster thriller Triad Election as those in a similarly slicked-up Hollywood film, but the blood on the floor here seems stickier.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Aesthetically and conceptually wrung out, fizzled rather than fizzy, this latest installment in the spider-bites-boy adventure story shoots high, swings low and every so often hits the sweet spot, but mostly just plods and plods along.
The Treatment is a movie with its heart and head in the right place. Too bad its aesthetic sensibilities and technical coordinates are not as well situated.

Written by Mr. Maddin and George Toles, his longtime screenwriting partner, the story builds on familiar types and narrative conventions that, over time, are all but obscured by layer upon layer of idiosyncratic detail.
Private Property has the pulse of an emotional thriller, but without commercial cinema's usual shrieking violins and storytelling beats.
In Paprika, a gorgeous riot of future-shock ideas and brightly animated imagery, the doors of perception never close.
With Ocean's Thirteen, the gang's all here, looking fighting trim and Hollywood beautiful, at your disposable pleasure.
This 70-minute exercise ends before it begins.
Rise of the Silver Surfer is an existentially and aesthetically unnecessary sequel to the equally irrelevant if depressingly successful Fantastic Four.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In the ticklishly amusing satire Fido, the undead stagger along like stunned toddlers.
As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature Gypsy Caravan could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Manufactured Landscapes is an absorbing if unsettling documentary about the work of the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky.
Effectively fashioned, as jolting as it is polished, as well as a surprising, insistently political work of commercial art.
With its shadows and gallows humor, You Kill Me goes about as dark as a comedy can go before turning into tragedy or self-parody.
[McClane] still has the same knack for trouble, the adrenaline-pumping, cheerfully anarchic kind that causes cars to ignite, bodies to fly, eardrums to pop and hearts to race and gladden.
Proves that not every book deserves its own film.
A movie of epically assaultive noise and nonsense.
Falling is at once a character study times five and something of a generational snapshot.
An itty-bitty movie with a great big heart, Colma: The Musical is about how we learn to give voice -- joyfully, honestly, loudly -- to the truest parts of ourselves.
The overripe morsel who gets batted around in the Japanese absurdithon The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai looks like she was conjured up by a teenage boy in dangerous hormonal overdrive.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An artful mixture of carefully culled and originally produced material, Werner Herzog's a science fiction fantasy purports to tell the story of an alien species.
Filled with sprays of vomit, fountains of spit and enough hot body air to launch a flotilla of passenger balloons, The Benchwarmers is the sort of trash that Hollywood does really well.
In his new film about the battle for Iwo Jima, Clint Eastwood says something new and urgent about the uses of war and of the men who fight.

What interests the Dardennes ... is not only how Bruno became the kind of man who would sell a child as casually as a slab of beef, but also whether a man like this, having committed such a repellent offense, can find redemption.
The director Yan-Ting Yuen revisits China's recent past to explore the history and legacy of one of the strangest byproducts of totalitarian madness: the revolutionary spectacular.
movie_title: Yang Ban Xi: The 8 ModelWorks (Yang Ban Xi, de 8 modelwerken) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The long-gestating follow-up to Paul Verhoeven's 1992 blip on the zeitgeist screen is a disaster of the highest or perhaps lowest order.
What makes Slither work is how nimbly it slaloms from yucks to yuks, slip-sliding from horror to comedy and back again on its gore-slicked foundation.
Nicole Holofcener's bittersweet comedy is about friendship and money and about how having one sometimes, maybe always, interferes with the other.
The terminally bleak meets the hypnotically beautiful in the Russian cryptogram 4, directed by the newcomer Ilya Khrzhanovsky.
Elizabeth: The Golden Age is a kitsch extravaganza aquiver with trembling bosoms, booming guns and wild energy.
More sour than hard, this highfalutin exploitation flick starts with an unsavory premise that quickly becomes downright unpalatable.
Mary Harron's exuberant biographical film stars Gretchen Mol as the 1950's pinup queen Bettie Page.
Based on depressingly true events, Mountain Patrol: Kekexili tracks the heroic efforts of a small group of Tibetans struggling to keep the Tibetan antelope from extinction.
Inside Man, directed by Spike Lee, works because it takes a familiar setup a Wall Street bank heist that mutates into a hostage crisis and twists it ever so slightly.
In his smart, timely documentary, David Zeiger remembers that war and the veterans whose struggles against it are too often forgotten.
Why would Michael Douglas attach himself to a Washington thriller as deeply ridiculous, suspense-free and potentially career-damaging as The Sentinel?
Although its leisurely pace might be a bit tough going for restless Westerners, Mongolian Ping Pong is the kind of film that should be seen by children, not just adults.
This documentary about one of the most loathed, lampooned and beloved music genres isn't the kind of film to rock your world, though it may well inspire laughter.
A trilogy of desire from the Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien in which the same actress and actor play variations on lovers in three distinct historical periods.
movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: ... beat for beat, the whole thing plays out very much according to the Hollywood playbook.
[A] rare work of art that thrills the senses and the mind.
... a delicately funny tale about everyday surrealism.
Although he slams into stationary objects with his customary zeal, Tom Cruise is off his game here, sabotaged by a misguided attempt to shade his character with gray.
This Australian western, written by the darkly moody musician and author Nick Cave, tells a story of murder in the outback that is as cruel as it is aesthetically flamboyant.
No doubt the people at DreamWorks who made Over the Hedge would prefer that their film bring to mind animated classics like Disney's Bambi (or, as Hammy suggests, Ice Age), but no such luck.
Paul Weitz's film is a seriously unfunny comedy about that intersection where politics meets entertainment.
This future-shock story about a masked avenger at war with a totalitarian British regime sags when it should zip.
The film won a sack of Goya Awards in 2004.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Glibly funny and eager to please, the film version of Christopher Buckley's novel Thank You for Smoking is not unlike the down-and-dirty habit of its title.
This story of a gentle soul (Queen Latifah) who learns to live only after learning of her imminent death is as witless as it is formulaic.
The disorganized documentary 24 Hours on Craigslist is primarily a stroll through human desire as manifested on the popular Internet site Craigslist.org.

... even those of radical political persuasion might find it hard to accept Mr. Jarecki's argument that American militarism is, underneath the talk about freedom and democracy, a simple question of dollars.
Steven Soderbergh's latest and willfully perverse excursion into experimentation.
The enervating trifle Imagine Me & You will soon be gathering dust [on the shelves of video stores].
A film filled with terrifically choreographed action and very little on its mind.
Clocking in at 80 minutes, this glib, largely uninformative and poorly organized prcis of the post-World War II art scene succeeds neither as history nor as art history.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In this pleasantly diverting romance about a black woman and a white man forced to transcend prejudice, the chemistry between the leads is as unmistakable as the setup is contrived.
The Brazilian film Cinema, Aspirins and Vultures shows how a little imagination and a quality cinematographer can triumph over a poverty of means.
movie_title: Cinema, Asprin And Vultures (cinema, Aspirinas E Urubus) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Firewall, a thrill-challenged thriller starring Harrison Ford, manages to entertain mildly only because it gives moviegoers ample opportunity to test their action-movie I.Q.
Jonathan Demme's concert film captures Neil Young in a ruminative state of mind at Nashville's storied Ryman Auditorium, original home of the Grand Ole Opry.
Graham Greene liked to say that he preferred The Fallen Idol (1948) to the more famous The Third Man (1949) because it was more a writer's film than a director's.
Satire via sledgehammer, Kevin Willmott's fake documentary imagines an alternative American history in which the South won the Civil War.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Freedomland, a lethally dull drama about a white child who may have gone missing in a New Jersey public housing complex, is an early candidate for worst film of the year.
At once unmoored and ruthlessly calculating, the Mexican film Battle in Heaven has everything for everyone or perhaps nothing at all.
Rupert Murray's thought-stirring documentary recounts the bizarre saga of man who walked into a Coney Island hospital claiming not to know who he was.
Tsotsi, an Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, isn't much different from every studio cautionary tale with an unhappy past, a criminal present and an unhappier future.
In the gleefully violent Running Scared, the writer and director Wayne Kramer tries to go over the rainbow and put a self-consciously bloody spin on once upon a time.
Dave Chappelle's exhilarating new film chronicles a free block party that was held in 2004 on a dead-end street in the Bed-Stuy neighborhood of Brooklyn.
Short on words and long on action, Richard Donner's adrenaline-spiked action flick is a compendium of familiar genre components.
Towne ... has turned Fante's glorious howl into a requiem for a city and those who escape its gilded clutches.
A story about friendship and the ecstasy of communion (not coincidentally, the story opens on a Sunday morning), Duck Season suggests that transcendence arrives when you least expect it.
Viewer discretion is advised, if only because it's well-nigh unwatchable.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As might be expected, The Last Stand pretty much looks and plays like the first two X-Men films, though perhaps with more noise and babe action and a little less glum.
The director Phillip Noyce revisits the ordeal of an ordinary black South African who became a foot soldier in the war against apartheid.
While the appealing Mr. Bernal can do little with the cruel task he has been given, the rest of the cast, particularly Mr. Hurt and Mr. Dano, invest their characters with real feeling.
... both in its ingratiating vibe and bland execution, Cars is nothing if not totally, disappointingly new-age Disney ...
Directed by the newcomer Fabrice du Welz, the Belgian horror film Calvaire is pompous, but not without talent or shivers.
Don't the filmmakers know there are children watching -- and listening?
Matt Dillon inhabits the role of Henry Chinanski, the alter ego of the writer Charles Bukowski, in Bent Hamer's adaptation of Bukowski's 1975 novel of the same name.
Opening a film with a small child straining on a toilet and talking about poop isnt just a bad idea; its an invitation to unfortunate metaphor.
All anyone really needs to know about this amusingly crude, honestly satisfying artifact is snakes + plane + Samuel L. Jackson.
Europe's genocidal adventures in Africa receive a passionate reckoning in this ambitious documentary based on Adam Hochschild's best-selling history of the same title.
An incompetent spin on the poor-little-rich-girl story, the film involves a lot of wardrobe changes and product placements, and a smidgen of intrigue and some chaste romance.
The familiar story of the innocent soul who travels from the country to the big, bad city receives a thorough workout in this crude attempt at a cinematic bildungsroman.
The joint doesn't jump in the OutKast musical Idlewild; it just twitches and stumbles.
The film version of Thomas Rockwell's 1973 book proves refreshingly free of the customary blights that affect most modern childrens movies, notably adult condescension.
A delectable fusion of New Age babble and luridly bad filmmaking based on the best-selling 1993 book by James Redfield.
Neither ambitious enough to take seriously nor sleazy enough to enjoy, The Quiet flirts with the trappings of exploitation cinema without going all the way.
The tough, satisfying French film Le Petit Lieutenant is an austere drama of the sort that rarely makes it to American screens except on cable television.
The movies love a tasty murder, which is why Ben Affleck has packed on the pounds, slipped on some tights and given this exasperating film far more than it gives in return.
Brian De Palma drains the life out of James Ellroy's take on the spectacularly cruel 1947 murder of a young Los Angeles woman known as the Black Dahlia.
Kelly Reichardt's film is a triumph of modesty and of seriousness that also happens to be one of the finest American films of the year.
Kevin Macdonald's queasily enjoyable fiction film creates a portrait of the Ugandan dictator Idi Amin from inside the palace walls.
Stephen Frears' sublimely nimble evisceration of the British royal family pries open a window in the House of Windsor around the time of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.
Billy Bob Thornton's estimable talents are squandered in this shoddy comedy directed by Todd Phillips (Old School).
John Cameron Mitchell's ode to the joy and sweet release of sex also manages to be a sincere, modest political venture that finds humor where you might least expect it.
Martin Scorsese's cubistic entertainment about men divided by power, loyalty and their own selves finds the director back on the mean streets where he belongs.
Girl meets horse yet again in this entertainingly ridiculous update of Mary O'Hara's 1941 childrens novel, My Friend Flicka.
Written and directed by Andrew Bujalski, this wonderful independent film won't save or change your life, but it may make your heart swell.
Half Nelson is that rarest of marvels: an American fiction film that wears its political heart on its sleeve.
The mad and the sane take a leisurely spin around the dance floor in the Czech filmmaker Jan Svankmajer's feature-length phantasmagoria.
In The Bridesmaid, the latest of his works to be released in the United States, Mr. Chabrol again takes up a sharp instrument and directs it at one of his favorite targets, the family.
The hoop dreams of the teenage girls in the documentary The Heart of the Game are fairly straightforward if a wee bit intense.
An infectiously enjoyable survey of contemporary Turkish music, Fatih Akin's documentary works as a corollary to his breakout fiction film, Head-On.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Josh Gilbert's film tells the depressing, often ridiculous and generally enraging story of how and why Tommy Chong ended up doing time in a minimum-security prison.
In his endearingly ridiculous new comedy, Jack Black plays a half-Mexican, half-Scandinavian monastery cook from Oaxaca who moonlights as a masked wrestler.
In the second Garfield movie, the indignities are as enormous as the food bills.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Adam Sandler turns his careless attention to family life in this comedy about a harried white-collar father who acquires a remote control that allows him to hopscotch through time.
Some films offer up their mysteries openly; others, like this quietly affecting Sri Lankan film, keep their secrets close, revealing them gradually shot by shot, scene by scene.
Where once the Man of Steel flew up, up and away, in a leaden new film he flies down, down, down, sent from above to save mankind from its sins.
Fast and furious, Who Killed the Electric Car? is the sad tale of yet one more attempt by a heroic group of civic-minded souls to save the browning, warming planet.
Identities shift and melt like shadows in Richard Linklater's animated adaptation of the 1977 novel by the science fiction visionary Philip K. Dick.
S. A. Crary's music documentary examines New York's No Wave scene of the late 1970's an offshoot of punk, the anti-New Wave.
A more accurate title of this conceptually anemic if prettily mounted take on the Scandinavian epic might be Beowulf and the Vixen.
There are several problems with the romantic comedy You, Me and Dupree, not least that there is no filmmaking to speak of.
Patrice Chreau's startling drama recounts the dissolution of a marriage of a couple (Pascal Greggory and Isabelle Huppert) from the haute bourgeoisie.
Michael Hanekes 1994 feature is an icy-cool study of violence both mediated and horribly real.
movie_title: 71 Fragmente einer Chronologie des Zufalls (71 Fragments of a Chronology of Chance) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Mini's First Time is delectably vulgar for 20 minutes or so, almost too bad to be true, but it soon loses its cheap-thrills appeal.
M. Night Shyamalan's Lady in the Water is one of the more watchable films of the summer. A folly, true, but watchable.
Uma Thurman does double duty as a New York neurotic, Jenny Johnson, and a secret superhero, G-Girl, in a shaky comedy directed by Ivan Reitman.
Adapted from the manga of the same title, this 2003 action flick tracks the blood-spurting adventures of its title character, a young female assassin who wields a lethally mean sword.
This bittersweet comedy of dysfunction takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.
A quick-sketch portrait of Kenny Shopsin, of the legendary or notorious, depending on your experience, Greenwich Village eatery that bears his name.
In his not especially funny yet oddly appealing new comedy, Woody Allen manages to act his age and prove theres life in those old jokes yet.
The babes are buff and the scares bountiful in Neil Marshall's full-throttle horror freakout about six women on a caving expedition.
An engrossing if intellectually thin documentary that purports to explain how suicide bombing evolved from a weapon of war into a weapon of terror.
movie_title: The Cult of the Suicide Bomber (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Summer Love has been called the first Polish western and the first Polish spaghetti western, though the truer description might be the first deconstructed art western.
Johnny Mad Dog is an assaultive fiction about Liberian child soldiers.
A satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.
Revolutionary Road, a waxworks edition of the furiously unsentimental novel by Richard Yates, tracks the unraveling of a handsome young suburban couple in the 1950s.
Valkyrie transforms World War II into a boy's adventure.
There's something irresistible about watching two people fall in love, even in contrived, sniffle- and sometimes gag-inducing films like Last Chance Harvey.
A dopey if largely painless romantic comedy

The film teeters so perilously and routinely at the edge of camp, both with some of its casting choices and some unfortunate dialogue...that it's hard to know if Mr. Goyer wants to make us howl with fear or laughter.
By turns absorbing, confounding, exhausting and altogether stranger than most fiction, Mock Up on Mu, comes close to defying categorization.
With Crips and Bloods: Made in America, the director Stacy Peralta manages to put a human face on a subject that tends to inspire inflamed debate.
movie_title: Crips and Bloods: Made in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike Mr. Nighy, who puts an amusing camp spin on his every line and gesture, Mr. Sheen appears to have taken his monster duties seriously.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Filipino movie Serbis is gentle, bawdy and at times rambunctiously, ticklishly rude.
Taken starts in low gear and almost immediately stalls out.
In his inspired, inspiring essayistic documentary Theater of War the filmmaker John Walter jumps from art to history and politics and back again.
Imagine an action flick in which the hero spends the entire movie chasing the villain without the satisfaction of smashing his enemy to smithereens.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like the flailing American economy, Confessions of a Shopaholic wants to eat its cake and have its spiritual redemption too. (Talk about timing!)
Gomorrah is a corrosive and ferociously unsentimental fictional look at Italian organized crime.
Raises unsettling questions about the erosion of the private sphere.
At once funnier than it should be and more witless than it should have been.
There are some sharp ideas tucked alongside the tedious high jinks and rank sexism of Dillinger Is Dead.
Crossing Over delivers its sanctimony with less hand-wringing and more fist-shaking, complete with lurid violence and periodically bared female flesh.
There is much to argue with, and much to regret, about a film whose director thinks he needs to drop an anvil on our heads when art would suffice.
Fados is Carlos Saura's big-screen film about the musical genre that is the soul music of Portugal.
Love is a universe of two in Philippe Garrel's fatalistic romance Frontier of Dawn.
movie_title: La Frontiere de l'Aube (Frontier of the Dawn) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though Tokyo Sonata looks like a family melodrama, there is more than a touch of horror to its story of a downsized salaryman.
I not only watched all 286 minutes, I also rewatched a few sections.
movie_title: Lithuania and the Collapse of the USSR (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despereaux is a pleasantly immersive, beautifully animated, occasionally sleepy tale.
Despite [it being] about a journalist at a powerful newspaper who is jailed for refusing to name her source, Nothing but the Truth has nothing to do with you know what or who.
Rather it tells a good story well, and in the process quietly says a little something about what it means to look at the American dream from the bottom up.

The violence is idiotic and brutal (the story is just idiotic), but it's also so noncommittal that it doesn't offend. Like the filmmaking itself, the violence has no passion, no oomph, no sense of real or even feigned purpose.
Happy-Go-Lucky is closely tuned to the pulse of communal life, to the rhythms of how people work, play and struggle together.
Pop go the dialectics in Filth and Wisdom, a tale of bumping and grinding your way to happiness from the hardest-working hard body in show business.
W. does something most journalism and even documentaries can't or won't do: it reminds us what a long, strange trip it's been to the Bush White House.
The most notable thing about Sex Drive is that it reserves all its creativity for ways to revolt and ostensibly delight its target audience.
To say that Charlie Kaufman's Synecdoche, New York is one of the best films of the year is such a pathetic response to its soaring ambition that I might as well pack it in right now.
While [director] Alfredson takes a darkly amused attitude toward the little world he has fashioned with such care, he also takes the morbid unhappiness of his young characters seriously.
You learn little by way of hard facts about the adored French soccer star and famous head-butter Zinedine Zidane in the formalist exercise that bears his name.
movie_title: Zidane, un Portrait du 21e Sicle (Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's a generally more diverting entertainment waddling along the edges of Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa than the larger one lollygagging on screen.
A fascinating, often chilling look at the rock star apparatus at its most grotesque and banal.
Uplifting, disheartening, inspiring, enraging -- the mind reels while watching the documentary Pray the Devil Back to Hell.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: See the Holocaust trivialized, glossed over, kitsched up, commercially exploited and hijacked for a tragedy about a Nazi family. Better yet and in all sincerity: don't.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion, Slumdog Millionaire doesn't travel through the lower depths, it giddily bounces from one horror to the next.
The filmmaker Josh Koury has latched onto a great subject for We Are Wizards, his peek at some of the more engaged fans circulating in the Harry Potter world.
Kevin Rafferty makes the case for remembrance and for the art of the story in his preposterously entertaining documentary Harvard Beats Yale 29-29.
Australia is a pastiche of genres and references wrapped up into one horse-galloping, cattle-stampeding, camera-swooping, music-swelling, widescreen package.
To chart the differences between Transporter 3 and its two predecessors is as pointless as trying to parse its flimsy plot.
It's twinkle versus glower in the big-screen edition of Peter Morgan's theatrical smackdown Frost/Nixon.
An aggressively noisy exercise in style over substance about nasty people doing nasty things to one another in (sigh) Southern California.
Deeply sincere and exceedingly slow even at 87 minutes, Ciao involves two strangers who become acquaintances after the death of a mutual friend.
The Reader is a scrupulously tasteful film about an erotic affair that turns to love.

These spectral figures, totems of masculinity and mementos from a heroic cinematic age, are what make this unassuming film small in scale if not in the scope of its ideas -- more than just a vendetta flick.
The air is thick with paranoia in Doubt, but nowhere as thick, juicy, sustained or sustaining as Meryl Streep's performance.
If nothing else, Mr. Stone, from his tangled hair to dirty feet, has taken himself and his story into the beyond -- way, way beyond.
movie_title: Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The crushingly unfunny and slopped-together How to Lose Friends & Alienate People has neither the ambition nor the intelligence to do justice to its source material.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Alexander the Last, a 72-minute series of loosely connected scenes, follows an actress's lurching conversations and tentative gestures in life and the theater.
A fitfully funny comedy that owes much to Judd Apatow.
A would-be transgression that tries to squeeze dark laughs from the spectacle of human suffering.
Michael Mann's Public Enemies is a grave and beautiful work of art.
It's a remarkable history, rich in comedy and occasionally heartbreaking, filled with wise reflections and strange digressions about the wonders of life.
The lag time between the final books and the movies has drained much of the urgency from this screen adaptation, which, far more than any of the previous films, feels like an afterthought.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shane Meadows has been busily carving out his own corner in British cinema.
A cynical, clumsy, aptly titled attempt to cross the female-oriented romantic comedy with the male-oriented gross-out comedy.
Henry Marsh is a British brain surgeon whose humanity and talent with power drills make him an uncommonly enthralling linchpin.
Actors have to eat like the rest of us, but you still have to wonder how Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard ended up wading through Orphan and not laughing.
There's something irritatingly self-satisfied about Funny People, which explains why, though it glances on the perils of fame, it mostly affirms its pleasures.
Ulrich Seidl's Import Export is an unflinching, at times almost unbearably hard yet moral look at human exploitation.
In Chri you see the frailty and the strength, yet you rarely experience either with the depth of feeling you might because of the palpable uneasiness surrounding her performance.
The director Ole Christian Madsen's Flame & Citron is a fictionalized film, based on fact, about two Danish Resistance fighters.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious, elegantly shot, tonally cool first feature written and directed by Sophie Barthes.
Just the thing for the summertime movie blahs: it's a genuinely satisfying cheap thrill.
A fine pair of grave robbers, (director) Mr. McQuaid and (producer) Mr. Fessenden plunder freely from the movie crypt, unearthing other chomping, glowing mysteries and monstrosities.
This pricey, juiceless pulp could never have been killed by critics, simply because it was already dead.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When the ocean rises in this wonderful movie, each leaping wave stares out at us with a baleful eye as if in watchful and worried wait.
A grubby-looking comedy about the art of the sale.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Often ridiculous, awkward, unsatisfying and dour melodramatic adaptation.
A feature-length talkathon built on a sketchy premise and strong star turns from Liam Neeson and James Nesbitt.

Simply another testament to his movie love. The problem is that by making the star attraction of his latest film a most delightful Nazi, one whose smooth talk is as lovingly presented as his murderous violence, Mr. Tarantino has polluted that love.
A taut, unnerving, forcefully unromantic film.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The casting directors of Fragments deserve credit for assembling so much talent in one modest movie; if only Rowan Woods, the director, knew what to do with them.
In Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, the director's subject is as blatant and consistent as his cluttered mise-en-scne.
Chomp-chomp, zip-zip go the Nazi zombies in Dead Snow, a self-consciously outlandish horror flick.
Like most Hollywood romantic comedies these days, The Proposal is all about bringing a woman to her knees.
Booze and jealousy make a toxic cocktail, one that's heavily imbibed with much self-lacerating gusto in the grim British drama The Edge of Love.
Despite some floundering, Lymelife keeps you hooked, mostly through its performances.
A potentially brilliant conceptual comedy that fizzles because its writer and director, Jody Hill, doesn't have the guts to go with his spleen.
Oblivion is a movie so suffused with feeling for its human subjects that when a man starts weeping, you don't feel dirty about watching his tears fall.
Silence, interrupted only by the periodic violent howls of the wind and animal mewls and bleats, pervades the otherworldly landscape of Desert Dream.
Melville's eye for exacting detail here is expected. What is remarkable is the depth of feeling he exacts from the juxtaposition of these ordinary moments with their extraordinary context.
movie_title: Lon Morin, Prtre (Leon Morin, Priest) (The Forgiven Sinner) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Keeps people and things moving fast enough so that you don't have time to worry about the details, like the inanity of the story.
Treeless Mountain has the tang of real life, though this is realism that has been filtered through 60 or so years of world art cinema.
The film is imperfect, periodically if unsurprisingly sentimental, overly tidy and often very moving.
An austere, nearly pitch-perfect character study of two mismatched yet ideally matched souls.
A nondramatic work best appreciated as a pure image-and-sound event.
A junky-looking romantic comedy that's neither remotely romantic nor passably comic.
A bright, shiny blast from a newly imagined past.
Ms. Swinton doesn't have Ms. Rowlands' tenderness, but, damn, she has just about everything else you need or want.
[Noe is] using pure cinema and not just cheap exploitation tricks to make an impact.
As in their finest work, the Pixar filmmakers have created thrilling cinema simply by rifling through its history.
Mr. Coogan doesn't seem altogether comfortable with his part, which, like the story, undergoes a number of unconvincing changes.
The only marginally interesting, if unsurprising, thing about Land of the Lost is that a lot of money has been spent on yet another cultural throwaway.
Downloading Nancy is a nasty exploitation flick tarted up with art-house actors and psychobabble.
The actors in 24 City, an experimental fiction-nonfiction hybrid, bring their own existential realities to their short, touching performances.
Tetro is a visually lush cinematic fugue about love, ambivalence and two brothers fleeing the dark shadow of their domineering father.
One of the scariest movies of the year [is] Food, Inc., an informative, often infuriating activist documentary.
A thoroughly, sometimes gaggingly broad and sly conceptual laugh-in.
The caressing, honeyed light in Sin Nombre beautifies and softens every ugly moment in this equivocating story about geographic and moral border crossings.
Ballast is a serious achievement and a welcome sign of a newly invigorated American independent cinema.
An artful, intelligent movie about modern French identity and the attempt to transform those bodies into citizens through talk, talk, talk.
It's no wonder the faithful continue to forsake the movies, given junky embarrassments like Nights in Rodanthe.
In Still Life, the blood and the sweat run directly into the Yangtze River, where they mingle with more than a few tears.
In 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, a ferocious, unsentimental, often brilliantly directed film, the camera doesn't follow the action, it expresses consciousness itself.
Like the music it celebrates, this is a film made in glory of the world.
movie_title: The Silence Before Bach (Die Stille vor Bach) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [McDonagh] talks a blue streak beautifully, but he has yet to find the nuance and poetry that make his red images signify with commensurate sizzle and pop.
I'm not entirely sure what [director Williams] was trying to pull off in London to Brighton or even if Mr. Williams knew what he was trying to pull off.
Jumper is a barely coherent genre mishmash about a guy who transports himself across the globe at will.
A gimmick in search of its own point.
The Unforeseen explores the rights of man, the death of nature, the water below, the air above and all that going, going, gone green in between.
It's a free world, Ken Loach asserts in his latest film with well-practiced disgust and unfortunately little hope.
More slog than romp, The Other Boleyn Girl tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII.
Cassandra's Dream, Woody Allen's latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn't just stop making comedies once and for all.
Paranoid Park is a haunting, voluptuously beautiful portrait of a teenage boy who, after being suddenly caught in midflight, falls to earth.
This is personal cinema at its most uncompromising and fierce.
Blind Mountain, the second feature from Li Yang, is a reminder that art sometimes keeps the truth alive far better than the news.
Intriguing, frustrating, exasperating -- the French film Heartbeat Detector succeeds best as a provocation.
Boarding Gate plays with various genre codes and conventions very differently than most run-of-the-mill modern thrillers.
Alexander Sokurov's Alexandra feels like a communiqu from another time, another place, anywhere but here.
Greed is good and comes without a hint of conscience in 21, a feature-length bore about some smarty-pants who take Vegas for a ride.
The Cool School, a breezy, lively documentary about a thin slice of the Los Angeles fine art scene in the 1950s, is easy on the eyes, and the ears too.
A subtly intelligent and sharply argued documentary.
The luscious red orb in Flight of the Red Balloon is as much a reminder of the precariousness of life as an emblem of innocence.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The flowers that bloom in the French film Water Lilies belong to a familiar cinematic species, the newly sexualized teenage girl.
The workmanlike title The Bank Job is a nice fit for this wham-bam caper flick.

Works as a showcase for impressively realistic-looking special effects, a realism that fails to extend to the scurrying humans whose fates are meant to invoke pity and fear but instead inspire yawns and contempt.
Much like man's best friend, the rough-hewn Filipino movie The Bet Collector chases its protagonist from step to step, misery to misery, all but nipping at her heels.
Woman on the Beach is a bittersweet accounting of the geography of desire.
Whether you dig Lynch, a feature-length video visit with the director David Lynch, will largely depend on your views of his work.
Jimmy Carter isn't a real saint, but he plays one in Jimmy Carter Man From Plains.
Rails & Ties is so self-consciously unadorned that it feels as if its director didn't want us to think that she was trying to make a cinematic statement. She hasn't.
Greatness hovers just outside American Gangster, knocking, angling to be let in.
100 percent goo.
Career Politicians, the Fourth Estate and Disaffected Youth all earn a stern knuckle rapping in Lions for Lambs.
Fred Claus is a tacky would-be comedy about family dysfunction that fronts some Scrooge attitude only to dissolve into slobbering sentimentality and canned uplift.
Southland Tales is a funny, audacious, messy and feverishly inspired look at America and its discontents.
More than 50 years after its first screening in America, Monika arrives in New York again to light up the screen, this time without a trace of impropriety.
You don't need to wait for Angelina Jolie to rise from the vaporous depths naked to know that this Beowulf isn't your high school teacher's Old English epic poem.
Enchanted works its magic largely by sending up some of the very stereotypes that have long been Walt Disney Pictures' profitable stock in trade.
Until the director Frank Darabont decides that he's saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, The Mist isn't half bad.
Based on the video game franchise of the same title, Hitman exploits every action-flick clich imaginable and still manages to be dull.
Tamara Jenkins's The Savages is a beautifully nuanced tragicomedy about two floundering souls.
The great relief of D. A. Pennebaker's 65 Revisited is that this time you can hear Bob Dylan's songs in their entirety.
The tiny, tough, sneakily moving film The Violin wears its revolutionary romanticism on its sleeve, not far from its gun.
Hampered by its fealty to the book and its madly rushed pace.
The Band's Visit, the first feature by the Israeli writer and director Eran Kolirin, flirts recklessly with obviousness, cuteness too.

Mr. Forster has been soundly defeated by The Kite Runner. Despite the film's far-flung locations, there is remarkably little of visual interest here; the setups are banal, and the scenes lack tension, which no amount of editing can provide.
Youth Without Youth is a narratively ambitious, visually sumptuous surrealist enterprise that tries to bend time and space together as neatly as the folds in an origami swan.
Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story has a good beat and you can dance to it, though mostly you'll probably just tap your foot.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: P.S. I Love You looks squeaky clean and utterly straight. Yet as directed by Richard LaGravenese, it has a curious morbid quality.
There Will Be Blood Paul Thomas Anderson's epic American nightmare, arrives belching fire and brimstone and damnation to Hell.
The screenwriter Daniel Waters has some funny films to his name, but Sex and Death 101 is not one of them.
Drenched in emotion and suffused with good intentions, Body of War is impossible not to like, but difficult to admire.
Street Kings is an absurd if accidentally entertaining potboiler, based on a story by James Ellroy.
It's clever, or at least clever enough to keep you going and interested from start to finish. It just isn't scary.
Hancock makes for one unexpectedly satisfying and kinky addition to Hollywood's superhero chronicles.
The actors look as if they're having a reasonably fine time, but there's no sense of commitment here, no sense that this was a movie that absolutely, passionately had to be made.
In the once-upon-a-time fairy tale called La France, French soldiers move through darkly verdant landscapes worthy of Henri Rousseau.
If Journey to the Center of the Earth is not a ride, then what is it? One thing it may not be, quite, is a movie.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Meet Dave, the latest in a long line of disposable Eddie Murphy vehicles, plays like a half-hour sitcom episode that has been stretched to feature-length running time.
Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, The Dark Knight goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.
If the insanely inventive and entertaining Mad Detective weren't so weird -- and in Cantonese -- hordes of action geeks would be lining the block to see it.
Wise and soberly affecting documentary about the separate but unequal Mardi Gras festivities that take place each year in Mobile, Ala.
Noisy, fitfully amusing, ultimately tiresome havoc.
Lightly sweetened and just a touch bitter, the romantic comedy In Search of a Midnight Kiss treads familiar if appealing ground.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most surprising, politically suggestive movies to come out of Hollywood this year.
As it shifts genre gears and cranks up the noise, becomes disappointingly sober and self-serious.
A lovely, drifty first feature that feels less like a documentary and more like an act of rapturous devotion.
Elegy is such a serious, oftentimes grave exploration of desire and the ways of aging that it's a miracle the two central characters have as much sex as they do.
Tropic Thunder is a flashy, nasty, on-and-off funny and assaultive sendup of the film industry.
A Girl Cut in Two is a rich, textured divertissement from Claude Chabrol, a sinister master of the art.
movie_title: La Fille Coupe en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Vicky Cristina Barcelona is a rueful comedy about two young American women who savor many Continental delicacies.
A touchingly true film, part weepie, part comedy, about the agonies of navigating that slippery slope called adulthood.
Time, alas, doesn't so much pass in Righteous Kill as crawl, despite the usual overcutting, which tries to pump energy into the inert proceedings.
Burn After Reading, the clubby, predictably self-amused comedy from Joel and Ethan Coen, has a tricky plot, visual style, er, to burn, but little heart.
The title of the documentary Virtual J F K: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived pretty much says it all, though the movie itself says not nearly enough.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Duchess is an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.
Elite Squad is a relentlessly ugly, unpleasant, often incoherent assault on the senses from Brazil.
In The Last Mistress, the director Catherine Breillat's explorations of desire are so far from the antiseptic world of most screen depictions as to seem far out.
movie_title: Une Vieille Matresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The tears and the blame mix uneasily in Reservation Road, a grim, mechanistic thriller about death and suffering, life and healing among the civilized.
Wanted shows life in the killing lane with lots of zippy effects, action and exploding heads.
The funny, sad, offbeat, sometimes off-the-beat romance Expired is one of those precariously balanced movies that might fall to pieces with a different cast.
Jacques Rivette's Duchess of Langeais seems to me a nearly impeccable work of art -- beautiful, true, profound.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The serial killer in Anamorph shows promise, even if some of his best moves are derivative. The same is true of the film's director.
Although it's often laugh-out-loud laughably bad, 88 Minutes is mostly just a slog.
The new comedy Baby Mama never comes fully to term, as it were.
It is, predictably, a bleak, depressing movie, but if you stick around through the end credits, you may also be in for a few surprises.

A would-be erotic thriller with no heat and zero chills, Deception has the kind of glassy, glossy sheen and risible story that mean to suggest Basic Instinct but instead invoke lesser laughers like Jade and Sliver.
Redbelt, is a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy.
A likable, lightly sticky valentine to childhood.
A startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution.
In Battle for Haditha the British filmmaker Nick Broomfield revisits a wretched chapter of the war in Iraq.
What Happens in Vegas, one of those junky time-wasters that routinely pop up in movie theaters, won't make you laugh much or at all.
The real surprise of Frontier(s) is that this creepy, bloody contemporary gross-out also has some ideas, visual and otherwise, wedged among its sanguineous drips.
Surfwise has a bohemian vibe and a cool sheen, but it's an eager-to-please, pleasing commercial enterprise with a reassuring narrative arc.

An exuberant, exhilaratingly playful testament to being young and hungry " for life and meaning and immortality, and for other young and restless bodies " Reprise is a blast of unadulterated movie pleasure.
There's plenty of frantic energy in Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, lots of noise and money too, but what's absent is any sense of rediscovery.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite Ms. Jolie's hard work and Mr. Eastwood's scrupulous attention, [Jolie's] difficult, fairly one-dimensional character fails to take hold.
There is something undeniably pleasant about an entertainment like Tristan & Isolde that delivers exactly what it promises, no less, no more.
There is something depressingly stunted about this movie; something desperate too.
Operation Filmmaker is an absorbing story about the best intentions gone terribly and comically awry.
At once fuzzy-wuzzy and industrial strength, the tacky-sounding Kung Fu Panda is high concept with a heart.
When Did You Last See Your Father? is grown-up, civilized fare, even though the whole thing might have been improved with a bit of messiness.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does in Encounters at the End of the World.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Happening is a divertingly goofy thriller with an animistic bent, moments of shivery and twitchy suspense and a solid lead performance from Mark Wahlberg.
Get Smart is made up of feeble and funny jokes, brand actors and enough special effects to give you some bang for your summertime buck.
The vogue for retro-horror, particularly the stripped-down shivers of 1970's slasher flicks, continues apace in this nasty little piece of work from Australia.
The silly, unconscionably entertaining action film Unleashed earns most of its juice from the martial-arts star Jet Li.
An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, Munich is by far the toughest film of Steven Spielberg's career and the most anguished.
At seven hours, Bela Tarr's 1994 Satantango is one of those unusual works of contemporary art that demand from the audience a concentrated commitment -- the luxury of time.

Instead of the multi-everything family that races, parties and thieves together, Singleton unleashes spasms of sadism and innumerable leering shots of girls gone wild, albeit -- alas -- not behind the wheel.
There are no big surprises in Caetano's film, which plays out exactly as ordained, only a sense of life at its most precarious and real.

[The Pangs'] sense of pacing is nicely arrhythmic, which makes the 'boo' moments all the more heart-thudding, but what's even more pleasurable are the pockets of quiet, those lacuna of low-frequency dread when nothing much happens.
No one comes out of Hollywood Homicide looking good, but the film fades fast.
Director Troy Miller doesn't just lack the comic juice to extend his and co-writer Robert Brener's sketchy ideas into a feature, he's not above selling out his characters for a cheap laugh or two.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rose gives as good as she gets, and one of the film's exceedingly modest pleasures is watching how the director rescues this woman from stereotype and Flix's (and our) prejudice.
Packed with characters wallowing in self-conscious cool that's as tedious as their anomie.
[A] likable if tame monster movie.
28 Days Later induces the sort of physical reactions that these days are more often incited by the nightly news than the latest monster flick.
A vividly entertaining portrait.
Legally Blonde 2 moves at such a brisk, easy clip that there isn't much time to linger over its flaws.
It's sexy, brainy and slightly nuts.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: These guys have dumbed down a comic book.
A disarming, appealingly modest discovery, beautifully shot, nicely performed.
A mainstream endeavor tricked out as an indie, Garage Days gives us plenty to look at but no reason to care.
A mind-boggling, nerve-numbing, adrenaline-pumping combination of shock-and-awe brilliance and idiocy.
A movie that looks like a muddy second-generation Xerox and contains all the emotional and intellectual appeal of cold tea and soggy toast.
A distinct if distinctly minor improvement on the first.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Because the movie doesn't have any real politics -- just a few funny gags and sarcasm -- the satire never jells.
Nearly as unwatchable as it is unpronounceable.
The grossest, least funny installment in the American Pie series.
This is the first film Ozon has shot in English, and his attempt to explain Sarah may be a bid to soften her and help the film's commercial viability. Luckily for him, his actress stays in character.
