Director Peyton Reed gets the film's look and, in moments, its disingenuous innocence, but you have to wonder what he and the screenwriters, Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, thought they were parodying.
As a filmmaker, [Leconte] doesn't have anything profound to say but does say his something with craft, visual flair and professionalism.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The group-talk and anguished groping feel true, as does David's frustrations with the kids.
The film offers up simultaneous critiques of Palestinian and Israeli extremism, but the most radical thing about it is that it's often disquietingly funny.
The film has great forward thrust -- Friedkin's a full-throttle guy -- and the director knows where to put the camera.
In Spun, the nightmare never ends for the pretty young Hollywood things like Mena Suvari and Brittany Murphy who play methamphetamine dress-up with pasted-on pimples and brushed-on bruises.
Worth commenting on only for its shocking ineptitude.
There's undeniable enjoyment to be had from films crammed with movie references, but the fun wears thin -- then out -- when there's nothing else happening.

Rock can't set up a decent-looking shot, and he doesn't care about niceties such as character development and all that narrative downtime in between jokes. But he nonetheless wrings biting humor from serious issues.
Written and directed by Duvall, Assassination Tango is a wonderfully eccentric piece of filmmaking -- to demand it cohere to formula would be to miss the point.
A gentle warning that in a world guided by an eye for an eye, everyone ends up blind.

If the whole thing flags, then dive-bombs at the midway point, it's not because Farrell and Schumacher aren't trying hard, but because the filmmakers struggle to wedge in some meaning where none belongs.
Blood Simple is so derivative -- of Dashiell Hammett and James M. Cain and a thousand and one noirs -- that who or what is being ripped off is essentially beside the point.
In love with 1970s film style but not 1970s grit, Chick never pushes his characters anyplace that's overly uncomfortable for either him or us.
An accomplished technician and an adept director of actors, Lin doesn't have a distinctive visual style but he does have the advantage of being as smart as he is slick.

The jokes would be funny even if they weren't perfectly timed, but what makes them come across as so poignant is the seriousness with which the director and his co-conspirators deliver their jabs and japes.
His film may be something of a beautiful lie, but what's true about Sollett's characters is that their dreams, their grace and their struggles are as real as it gets.
This isn't an easy film -- only a memorable one.
Zwigoff pulls off something in Ghost World that seems a minor miracle -- he creates someone with a complex inner life.
A routine genre film.

Once in Phnom Penh, Jimmy meets up with the usual suspects -- some human wreckage in a soiled tropical suit, a mysterious beauty with a Modigliani neck -- but, more encouragingly, tumbles into a story that doesn't succumb to its more suspect clichs.
Unlike a lot of young filmmakers, the 31-year-old Reygadas takes his ideas about the world and our place in it as seriously as his filmmaking ambitions.
A conceptual tour de force and a brainiac's road movie, Abbas Kiarostami's Ten goes from chilly abstraction to hot emotion in less than 60 seconds.

The stultifying pace and Moskowitz's filmmaking laziness are forgivable, but it's exasperating and indicative of our low expectations for the documentary form that a film that taps the likes of Leslie Fiedler could be so devoid of ideas.

Here, the urgent question of how an individual maintains his humanity when his paychecks are cut by a government every bit as corrupt as its terrorist outlaws isn't the stuff of abstract speculation but a matter of life, death and honest screen thrills.
I laughed a couple of times, but mostly I was bored out of my mind and not a little depressed.
Watching Curtis gently cut loose is one of the low-key pleasures of the winsome generational comedy Freaky Friday.
A dazzling epic of love, guns, gangsters and cigarettes.
A film in which the City of Light's seductions and perils are as dimmed as the novelist's point and purpose.
Many cuts above most big-screen soap operas.
If directing bad movies were a sin to confess, Bo Welch would say oops for making this mess.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Watts, Penn and Del Toro have all been brilliant before, and if we're lucky, they will all be brilliant again. But to watch these three -- working alone and in tandem -- is to experience the strange, at times frightening alchemy of screen acting.
How anyone in the cast manages to keep a straight face is one of the film's innumerable mysteries.
By turns risibly puerile and purely risible, the screenplay groans under the weight of its multiple platitudes.

This is a superb stink bomb of an entertainment, generously larded with jokes about alcoholics, short people, dim children and the kind of sexual congress that until recently was illegal in nine states.
Effectively conveys the fears and frustrations of Palestinians struggling in a country that treats them as the enemy.
Taken on the level of spectacle rather than of sense, The Last Samurai affords the sort of fizzy enjoyment that can come with epic movie endeavors.

Big fish often swim in small ponds, but in Tim Burton's wistful new film about a son, a father and the lies that come between them there are no small ponds -- just big, bright movie sets shimmering and bubbling with the director's imagination.

Sweeter and softer than their earlier comedies, and largely devoid of gags about bodily functions, Stuck on You has the vibe of a transitional work, as if the brothers were trying to see how a post-scatological Farrelly comedy could play.

Bresson is one of the few directors for whom cinema was both an aesthetic and spiritual pursuit, a search that was reflected in films for which the words 'sublime,' 'transcendent' and 'masterpiece' can seem somehow lacking.
It isn't just difficult to do justice to Shanae and Megan in an average of 44 minutes apiece; as it turns out, it's impossible.

[Mona Lisa Smile] lets us spend some quality time with some of the finest actresses in American film as they give energetic life to one of the most radically underrepresented minorities in Hollywood: the intelligent woman.
Paycheck is the sort of noisy nonsense that Woo's earlier action movies made irrelevant, but alas not extinct.

An unabashed romantic, Minghella takes to Ada and Inman's love story with appreciable feeling, but the irony of Cold Mountain is that it's the director's grasp of violent action that proves his greatest cinematic gift.
Phony choppers and a startling resemblance to Jon Voight aren't enough to transform Theron into Wuornos, and I didn't buy either the performance or the character for a second.
She was guilty, no doubt, but as this immensely moving film makes clear, Aileen Wuornos was also heartbreakingly human.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Strangely entertaining.
A well-told story, forged on vision and delivered with heart.
Maladroit exploitation flick.
There may once have been a real movie rattling inside the empty studio package known as The Big Bounce, but no longer.
This tough, bristling story about a working-class man pushed over the edge vividly brings to mind the great Hollywood social dramas of the 1930s.
Raw and wretchedly current, it is a story that packs a cruel emotional wallop.
A paper-thin comic distraction.
With Carnage, a pungent tale of love and sacrifice, French filmmaker Delphine Gleize has fashioned a modest epic about our ridiculous human comedy.
Pitched wider and lower than Who Framed Roger Rabbit, Looney Tunes doesn't have much on its addled mind other than pure entertainment, and on this level it succeeds quite nicely.

Although it ultimately collapses under the weight of its repulsive imagery ... De Van's film is one of the few features in recent memory that explores violence intellectually, rather than to employ it simply for easy entertainment.

Cast adrift with vague, improbable characters and a plot that's at once under- and overcooked, the actors struggle to find a steady tone, lurching from somber to silly as the director tries to figure out what he's doing.
The film fizzles rather than fizzes.
Roth and co-writer Randy Pearlstein choke up the occasional belly laugh in Cabin Fever, but they're so busy selling their jokes and their film-geek smarts they never figure out how to scare us.
Its action often feels chaotic, simultaneously lazy and agitated, rather than choreographed.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Modestly conceived and affably low-key.
It's an exasperating, irresistible, must-see mess of a movie about life in the modern world and so very good that even when its story finally crashes and burns the filmmaking remains unscathed.

Alas, as is often the case with lower-end genre movies, the story cooked up by Wiseman and his friends, actor Kevin Grevioux and the film's screenwriter, Danny McBride, is decidedly less important than the look of the film and its influences.
The movie pretends it's peddling a vision of 'you-go-girl' independence in which it doesn't remotely believe.
Even when the screenplay groans with cliches, the four lead actresses play their parts with truckloads of heart.
Despite the standard-issue ingredients -- the palm trees, the femme fatale, the dirty money -- there's something about the movie that sets it apart from the usual thriller.
Although it has a delectable cast, Wonderland skims over its seedy characters to glamorize drug addiction and the role porn star John C. Holmes had in four murders.
For the first time in Tarantino's filmmaking career, the written story -- both in word and development -- proves the least interesting part of the whole equation.
There are some very fine directors represented here ... but none has fully risen to the full measure of their talent.
A smooth, comfortable ride all the way, with Hackman and Hoffman, of course, the ultimate in fine engineering.
The remake moves faster and sounds louder, but comes off as callous rather than creepy.
Like all good B-movies, Returner comes loaded with enough eccentric touches to give the recycling a whiff of freshness.
May be the most maddening and imperfect great movie of the year.
An unblinking look at our mania for murder, the film is a stunning response to an American tragedy that in its senselessness and human cost embodies the larger tragedy of this country's blood lust.
An unhurried model of nonfiction filmmaking and a vision of life at its most persuasively humanistic.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Twenty-four years later -- digitally spruced up, with some scenes shaved and others padded with previously cut material -- Scott's film still shreds nerves.

Benton and Mayer have gutted the novel's uncivil, discomforting viscera -- including Roth's pokes at political correctness -- and delivered an uninteresting, at times comically inappropriate 'tasteful' story.
Built on small telling gestures and well-observed moments, and periodically rocked by a spasm of everyday weirdness, Suddenly works its charms slowly but steadily.
How did something that started out so cool get so dorky?
Giamatti looks nothing like Pekar either in person or in his various cartoon guises, but in a warmly sympathetic performance he brings the character to grubby, soulful life.
It's Bruckheimer for babies.
A movie that desperately wants [Latifah's] hip, her edge and mostly her blackness but doesn't know what to do with the human being who comes with the package.
No isn't concerned with subverting the status quo. Indeed, what he really seems to want to do is make a Hollywood movie.

If it seems like a minor miracle that its septuagenarian star is young enough to be the nonagenarian filmmaker's son, more incredible still are the clear-eyed boldness and quiet irony with which actor and director take on life's urgent questions.
Belly dancing isn't always the most thrilling of dances, but it's a blast to see these women shaking and rolling because they're so thoroughly in charge of the male clientele and their own sexuality.

Godard has always made films that are as thrilling for their ideas and ideals as for the sheer beauty of their images; the difference here is that for the first time in years he's more interested in turning us on than in turning us off.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (loge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Ripped from the pages of the See Dick Run, See Jane Stalk Him handbook, the thrill-less thriller Swimfan is as dumb as it gets.
A dreary indulgence.
This isn't a retooled genre piece, the tale of a guy and his gun, but an amiably idiosyncratic work.
Although it starts off vaguely amusing, 8 Women grows progressively sour, curdled by the filmmakers' bad faith and lack of compassion.
It's a demented kitsch mess (although the smeary digital video does match the muddled narrative), but it's savvy about celebrity and has more guts and energy than much of what will open this year.
For all the dolorous trim, Secretary is a genial romance that maintains a surprisingly buoyant tone throughout, notwithstanding some of the writers' sporadic dips into pop Freudianism.
A period story about a Catholic boy who tries to help a Jewish friend get into heaven by sending the audience straight to hell.
It sounds like another clever if pointless excursion into the abyss, and that's more or less how it plays out.
Dawdles and drags when it should pop; it doesn't even have the virtue of enough mindless violence to break up the tedium of all its generational bonding.
Most of the time it's a kick.
Given great lyrical force by Folland, it comes closer to unlocking the secret lives of girls than any other recent American movie.

The film shimmers with the irresistible pleasures that define Hollywood at its best -- it's polished like glass, funny, knowing and bright, and filled with characters whose lives are invariably sexier and more purposeful than our own.
Bristles with the sort of passion and bold purpose so often lacking in contemporary nonfiction filmmaking.
Despite its gritty Cleveland locations, it has the vacuum-sealed feel of a student film bankrolled by rich uncles.
Tykwer's surface flash isn't just a poor fit with Kieslowski's lyrical pessimism; it completely contradicts everything Kieslowski's work aspired to, including the condition of art.
The problem is that Kaye, who's used to selling cars on TV, shoots Derek the Hater as lovingly as he would a new Volkswagen.
Quote not available.
This rough trade Punch-and-Judy act didn't play well then and it plays worse now.
If Below had been released in 1943 -- the year of its story -- it would have come in at an agile 70 minutes instead of a protracted 104.

Witherspoon has charmed her way through weak material before, but she's too inexperienced to save the character from director Andy Tennant, whose main achievement here is to turn his star's natural twinkling menace into malice.
It's a drag how Nettelbeck sees working women -- or at least this working woman -- for whom she shows little understanding.
Unfunny and lacking any sense of commitment to or affection for its characters, the Reginald Hudlin comedy relies on toilet humor, ethnic slurs.
A mess, but it's a sincere mess.
Big Fan is a spasmodically funny and bleak film about the love that speaks its name.
A maddening mess, but there's some real feeling in its madness.

In the new film, it's personal tragedy that provokes the journey, not social upheaval or even scientific curiosity -- which, predictably, makes for a story that's at once more familiar and less interesting.
This isn't a terrible film by any means, but it's also far from being a realized work.
Yet another bootleg copy of the Lethal Weapon franchise.
A fundamentally insipid bid at experimental narrative.
What's curious about Unfaithful is just how little it pops.
The Vietnam setting looks authentic enough, but the action is as inert and unpersuasive as Gibson's attempt to fashion Bill Mauldin poetry out of his $20-million-plus smirk.
A cinematic sucker punch.
An intelligent, moral shocker.

A nerve-jangling, pictorially beautiful, mostly engrossing phantasmagoria of ghouls and warriors, oozing ambitions and towering dark castles, waylaid only by an occasional dip into the bog of exposition.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A frenetic bore that insists on its audience's adoration while making no demands upon their intelligence.
Introduced in 1962, the original superhero helped to initiate the age of modern comics. Raimi hasn't figured out how to reconfigure him for the blockbuster age.
From the squirrel's mad, droopy eyes, to the rumba rhythms of Manny's rear end, to the way Diego settles into sleep like a tabby, these creatures are alive enough to love, and lament.
Jeffs' meticulous framing nicely counterpoints all the messy turmoil, and her screenplay flows with the cadences of life.

The frog prince of New York comedy again wallows in the middle of the frame as various familiar faces, namely various princes and princesses from television, dart about him like so many flies with a death wish.
Easily one of the sexiest and funniest films about class struggle ever made.
There's just no denying Fincher's gifts. Give the guy a camera or two or three, millions upon millions of dollars and state-of-the-art technologies, and there's no stopping him.
Despite all the closed-door hanky-panky, the film is essentially juiceless.
Enormously enjoyable, high-adrenaline documentary.
The two stars? They're exactly right.
There's not much more to this adaptation of the Nick Hornby novel than charm -- effortless, pleasurable, featherweight charm.
Astonishing isn't the word -- neither is incompetent, incoherent or just plain crap. Indeed, none of these words really gets at the very special type of badness that is Deuces Wild.
This month's Luc Besson movie plays a lot like last month's -- only better.
There wasn't a moment in the film that I didn't enjoy, but neither was there anything that got my mind or heart racing.

Cinematic pyrotechnics aside, the only thing Avary seems to care about are mean giggles and pulchritude. It makes sense that he went back to school to check out the girls -- his film is a frat boy's idea of a good time.
It isn't just that there's something unsettling about a film that aestheticizes a crematorium; it's that there's something trivializing about the very effort.
If the second film never reaches the highs of the first -- we have met the players before and there are no new worlds of wonder -- it nonetheless invests moviegoing with a sense of adventure.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There are two films at war in director Spike Lee's newest feature 25th Hour, one uninteresting, the other an epic of near-tragic miscalculation.
Over and over, every gesture and character in Narc summons up yet another movie.
For all his genre-hopping and shape-shifting Spielberg seems to have become too big to tell small stories, which is one reason why the film sputters on one too many false endings.
With The Pianist, Polanski's strange genius serves Szpilman's remembrance and, in doing so, rescues his legacy from the blunder of much of the director's recent work.
It's Zeta-Jones who keeps you watching from start to finish.
Like the Dickens novel on which it's based, director Douglas McGrath's Nicholas Nickleby overcomes the earnest blandness of its eponymous hero with wonderful side characters.
Did it really take four Writers Guild members (Greg Glienna, Pete Schwaba, Matt Tarses and Bill Wrubel) to write a joke about some soiled underwear?
Beautiful and baffling.
Visceral, unrelenting, affecting and, as often, exasperating.

Perfectly pitched between comedy and tragedy, hope and despair, About Schmidt instead comes far closer than many movies to expressing the way many of us live -- someplace between consuming self-absorption and insistently demanding otherness.
Calculated swill.
The Recruit is little more than a fairy tale, one in which the prince gets to shoot the ball to smithereens.
Calibrated to please, The Guru is a down-market but enjoyable goof.
Lazy and resolutely witless.
A tough, vigorous exercise in cinematic form and pure aesthetics.
Kept in check by his character's neuroses, Pearce holds our attention throughout, but it isn't until near the end that he manages to break free of his character's and his director's inhibitions.
Parker's tendency to smash through stories ends up being brutal on Spacey and Winslet.
It's no Animal House, but Old School is helped by a curious pathos for its thirtysomething boys.
A strange, discomfiting and fascinating film about the horrors of adolescence.
The few promising skirmishes that do erupt sputter out quickly as if fight choreographer Corey Yuen had dropped his cell connection while phoning in his moves.
The film groans under the weight of its platitudes no matter how lightly Johnny dances around a pool table.
Unlike Terrence Malick, whose shadow looms over the film's visual style, the Smiths over-explain, not grasping that all those barren fields and blood-red clouds are doing plenty of work for them.
As saccharine as it is disposable.

The jokes are delivered with all the surprise you get with filmmaking on cruise control, but Ramis and Co. seem to be having a good time and every so often they do manage to slide in a bit that's so wily and understated it nearly avoids detection.
A science-fiction pastiche so lacking in originality that if you stripped away its inspirations there would be precious little left.
An execrable mess that leaves no genre cliche unturned or human body or soul untrammeled.
Alternately frustrating and rewarding.
Ballistic is a generic blur of metallic blue and fireball orange set to the contrapuntal sounds of throbbing techno and eardrum-puncturing noise.
Fleder can only fling the camera about and indulge in some familiar screen sadism ... as he tries to squeeze a few thrills from material as desiccated as his leading man.
Ghost Ship is the sort of flimflam that would have filled eight paneled pages in the great horror comic book Tales From the Crypt or consumed about 30 minutes on the latter-day HBO spinoff.
Meticulously mounted, exasperatingly well-behaved film, which ticks off Kahlo's lifetime milestones with the dutiful precision of a tax accountant.

Deploying a seamless blend of talking-head interviews, trenchant archival photographs and newsreels, topped off by a sheaf of newly declassified U.S. government documents, Gibney and Jarecki are smart enough to let the evidence and experts do the talking.
Every bit as disreputable and often as embarrassingly funny as the MTV program, only longer.
Some of this is insulting, all of it is tedious.
The film isn't just banal, it's aggressively, arrogantly banal.
It's good and good-looking and features one of the best soundtracks in years ... but it's also slick and schematic, weak on feeling and overly indebted to Tarantino.
No matter how deep her hurt, Jean and her insecurities make for an impoverished counterpoint to the tragedy of a woman imprisoned by history as well as by madness.
A work that lacks both a purpose and a strong pulse.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The film has the high-buffed gloss and high-octane jolts you expect of De Palma, but what makes it transporting is that it's also one of the smartest, most pleasurable expressions of pure movie love to come from an American director in years.
The film's three leads are extraordinary, but what Moore does with her role is so beyond the parameters of what we call great acting that it nearly defies categorization.
Admirers of director Abel Ferrara may be relieved that his latest feature, R Xmas, marks a modest if encouraging return to form.
Gives the Funk Brothers their due and more, mostly through wonderfully juicy anecdotes.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Whether softening his military cadences with a touch of the South or shimmying down the outside wall of a motel, the veteran character actor [Barry] goes a long way toward padding what is a clever if fundamentally minor conceit.
Absent one original moment and bathed in de rigueur steel blue punctuated by sporadic bursts of flaming orange, the movie is notable only for its creative approach to Seagal's bulky gracelessness.
Die Another Day is only intermittently entertaining but it's hard not to be a sucker for its charms, or perhaps it's just impossible not to feel nostalgia for movies you grew up with.
A movie that at its best doesn't just make the most out of its characters' flaws but insists on the virtue of imperfection.

Serves as unassailable proof of Noyce's good intentions, even if as a political statement it's at once over- and under-cooked, with little memorable dialogue and neither enough moral or political nuance.

Some writer dude, I think his name was, uh, Michael Zaidan, was supposed to have like written the screenplay or something, but, dude, the only thing that I ever saw that was written down were the zeroes on my paycheck.
Strangely wonderful and weirdly touching.
Twisted is rubbish, but it looks good enough, moves fast enough and does improve as it progresses, principally because its plot disintegrates to the point of outright comedy.
No one involved with Starsky & Hutch actually seems to care about the movie.
For its first hour or so, the story moves at a steady clip, generating enough mystery to keep you guessing and enough atmosphere to keep you interested.
Hugely likable.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This most unfortunate film combines standard documentary techniques with maladroit dramatizations from the life of the author of Story of O.
Ridley Scott's plaintive epic about the Crusades is an ostensibly fair-minded, even-handed account of one of the least fair-minded, even-handed chapters in human history.
Thin but pleasantly diverting.
Michelangelo Antonioni's film about a man on the run from himself dazzles from first shot to last.
The newest in British gangland entertainment and the tastiest in years.

Softer, louder and cleaner than the 1974 version, the new film sentimentalizes the prisoners and the game, filing down their sharpest edges so that winning becomes a matter of triumph rather than resistance.
In this decorous trifle from France, the director lonore Faucher builds her story with studied deliberation and piece by precious piece.
Ron Howard's film about the heavyweight boxer James J. Braddock is a shamefully ingratiating old-fashioned weepie.
An alternately hilarious and alarming documentary profile of Paul Green, the extravagantly voluble founder of a music school for pint-sized rockers.
The producing team behind this sequel to XXX has apparently decided that the only place to go is over the top way over the top.
Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie star as married assassins who try to kill each other in a genre hybrid that combines comedy and action to awkward effect.
What makes this Batman so enjoyable is how the director Christopher Nolan arranges familiar genre elements in new, unforeseen ways.
Andrew Wagner's strange and delightful movie shouldn't work but does rather remarkably.
... cumbersome drama.
Outside of the perfomers, which include Nicole Kidman, Will Ferrell and a nicely tuned supporting cast, there isn't much to look at here.
An excellent freakout of a movie.
Ethical capitalism may sound like an oxymoron to some, but that concept is a linchpin of this cursory, irritatingly facile look at the human cost of globalization.
Superb remake [of James Toback's Fingers].
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrt (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A dull and occasionally risible remake of an even duller, more risible Japanese horror flick ...
Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson star in this amiably raunchy sex comedy as two cut-rate Lotharios who attend weddings specifically to pick up women.
The writer and director Don Roos's slyly subversive ensemble piece is a drama disguised as a wisp of a comedy.

Like the fairly recent Cabin Fever and like earlier slasher films of that grisly ilk, High Tension takes a fairly straightforward approach to its essential reason for being, namely the stagecraft of death.
Ashton Kutcher and Amanda Peet star as a would-be couple in a pleasant romantic comedy without arty aspirations or low-brow yucks.
A dog named Earth and aliens both domestic and imported rotate around one another in this self-consciously freaky, rambunctiously goofy genre hybrid from South Korea.
In Michael Dowse's faux documentary about a D. J. who goes stone deaf, everything that can go wrong generally does, mostly to surprisingly sweet effect.
Robert De Niro rises to a formidable challenge in this sufficiently unsettling thriller: he holds his own against the scene-swiping 10-year-old actress Dakota Fanning.

Despite the periodic twinkling, the occasional detours into sentimentality and, most egregiously, the syrupy soundtrack that threatens to engulf the story at every turn, Rory O'Shea Was Here is better than the usual three-stage journey of courage.
Gurinder Chadha's film, which transports Jane Austen's 1813 novel to 21st-century India, is as high concept and rife with cliche as anything ever churned out by Hollywood.
This lively, if maddeningly reductive documentary examines the influence of the low-budget 1972 film Deep Throat.
In the Israeli film Or, about a prostitute and her teenage daughter, both clothes and humanity are stripped away with impunity.
The unutterably charming Cinvardaphoto brings together three short works by the filmmaker Agns Varda, one shot in digital video, the others on celluloid.
Laura Gabbert's deeply affecting documentary profiles a pair of extraordinary women who live in a 'nonprofit retirement home for free-thinking elders.'
A tediously didactic, often condescendingly reductive 10-part lesson on cinema.
A deadpan comedy shot through with a vein of despair, the Uruguayan film Whisky is a pint-size pleasure.
John Travolta returns as the reformed mobster he played in Get Shorty. But while Get Shorty rode the Pulp Fiction craze with finesse, Be Cool is running on empty.
Danny Boyle (Trainspotting) has directed a heartfelt, emotionally delicate children's movie about life and death and all the parts in between.
Ostensibly a coming-of-age story, this languorous, beautifully shot feature debut from Vietnam tells a deceptively simple tale in a deceptively simple fashion.
Despite its spasms of brutality and a swerve into the macabre, Yasuaki Nakajima's post-apocalypse movie is gentle at heart and terribly sincere.
Despite Mr. Nakata's track record and the radiant presence of its star, Naomi Watts, The Ring Two is a dud.
It isn't just that Miss Congeniality 2 is nearly absent a single genuine laugh; it's that instead of a screenplay and a story we now have stereotypes and sketch comedy.
Rebecca Miller's attempt to elevate a small Oedipal story about two damaged souls into a grandiloquent epic misses by a significantly wide mark.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Park Chanwook's frenzied thriller is entertaining to watch, which is a good thing, because there is not much to think about here, outside of the choreographed mayhem.
Sin City has been made with such scrupulous care and obvious love for its genre influences that it's a shame the movie is kind of a bore.
Set in northern Italy and in the darkest recesses of a woman's heart, Primo Amore is a horror movie about desire and the toxic pursuit of perfection.
This thoroughly winning if not especially good romantic comedy by Peter and Bobby Farrelly is loosely based on the Nick Hornby memoir of the same title.
Sam Peckinpah's famously butchered 1965 western, Major Dundee, has been returned to the big screen in a form that is closer to the director's original vision.
It's a mystery what the Swedish filmmaker Lukas Moodysson thought he was up to in A Hole in My Heart, a movie teeming with ugly images and grotesque behavior.
movie_title: Hl i mitt hjrta, Ett (A Hole In My Heart) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Low-key creepy rather than outright scary, the new Amityville marks a modest improvement over the original.
Memories of Murder is such a taut, effective thriller it's a shame you have to read subtitles to gauge just how good a movie it is.
More of a sketch than a fully developed portrait, Arakimentari is an up-close and generally impersonal introduction to the Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki.
Mesmerizing dream of a film.
Has the makings of a kitsch classic.
Tony Scott's tongue-in-check interpolation of the life and times of a privileged brat turned bounty hunter has no social value outside of a feverish will to entertain.
An inept drama concerning three siblings after the death of their farmer father.
A wobbly fiction about a real pioneering sex-discrimination case, North Country is an unabashed vehicle for its modestly de-glammed star, Charlize Theron.
Rod Serling would have wrapped this mysterioso story about a psychiatrist and a suicidal patient dislocated by time, space and a lot of crazily raked angles into a tight half-hour episode.
The ghastly story of King Leopold II of Belgium's reign of terror in Africa during the late 19th- and early-20th centuries forms the subject of Peter Bate's documentary.
movie_title: Congo: White King, Red Rubber, Black Death (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The line between cinematic art and exploitation has rarely seemed finer and nervier, at least in recent memory, than in the French film Innocence.
Made in 1968, William Greaves's fiction-nonfiction hybrid playfully takes itself apart scene by scene, code by code, in a bid to reveal how cinematic illusions are manufactured.
This fainthearted bid at social satire stars Nicolas Cage as a middle-aged man gazing into the yawning void of his life.
Jennifer Aniston and Clive Owen star in this glossy and often risible bit of trash about an adulterous affair gone bad, bad, bad.
Based on the well-regarded novel by Myla Goldberg, Bee Season is a serious film filled with both great and awkward ideas.
In telling the story of a fictional comedy team, the director Atom Egoyan seems to want to deconstruct celebrity through the familiar mechanics of a murder mystery.
The fascinating French actress Emmanuelle Devos stars as a woman in 1930's France who discovers her husband has developed a passion for another woman.
Crammed with barflies, strippers and assorted reprobates, The Ice Harvest easily takes the honors as this holiday season's biggest and dirtiest lump of coal.
Johnny Depp's beauty and talent salvage this rigorously stagy film on the life and bad-boy times of the second Earl of Rochester.
Directed by the young actor Adam Goldberg, "I Love Your Work is an attempt to say something interesting about modern celebrity.
It takes about 28 days for the moon to orbit the earth and approximately 60 minutes for Far Side of the Moon to reveal its full splendor.
Swathed in silk and longing (mostly for a bald guy called Oscar), the big-screen version of Memoirs of a Geisha arrives with good intentions firmly in place.
There isn't much going on in Mrs. Henderson Presents beyond the odd-couple routine, some gaudy musical numbers and artful nudity.
As a vision of the American West and the wide country around it, Tommy Lee Jones's western strikes both fresh and familiar chords, most of them pleasingly dissonant.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Set in New Orleans, this collection of loosely connected set pieces was written and directed by Michael Almereyda, who is perhaps best known for his 2000 iteration of Hamlet.
Sarah Jessica Parker's nimble performance is reason alone to see this creaky fairy tale about a Manhattan executive marrying into an unhappy family.
The fun in the film's title comes from watching comfortably middle-class people do without the usual buffers and privileges.
Childhood ends for the young wizard with the zigzag scar in the happily satisfying film adaptation of the fourth book in J. K. Rowling's series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A sincere and sincerely turgid male weepie about sports betting, Two for the Money lurches from upbeat to downbeat without ever settling into a coherent groove.
Curtis Hanson wrests a richly textured story of love from Jennifer Weiner's breezy bestselling fiction about two sisters engaged in an epic battle of the heart.
This soulful, piercingly beautiful story about a boy and his cheetah marks the welcome return to the screen of the director Carroll Ballard.
This 77-minute primer sheds partial light on this B-movie legend who, unlike his contemporaries like Lang, never managed to ascend to the A-list.
movie_title: Edgar G. Ulmer: The Man Off-Screen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A delicate wisp of a film with a surprisingly sharp sting.
The result is an unqualified triumph.
Treadwell's journey was no less bold or reckless than ... earlier Herzogian tales and certainly no less enthralling.
One of the most enjoyably inane movies of the season, this faux Southern Gothic offers an embarrassment of geek pleasures.
In the dreary, claustrophobic drama Asylum, Natasha Richardson plays a married Englishwoman who falls for a loony-bin hunk.
This nifty, tense thriller directed by Wes Craven brings together a classic setup and a relevant-sounding if thoroughly undercooked story involving worldwide terrorism.
There is so much talent on display in Park Chanwook's Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance, it is a drag that the film never rises to the level of its director's obvious ability.
Steve Carell plays the title character in a charmingly bent comedy about a likable geek's progress from action figures to real action.
A film that considers hard-core political realities alongside agonizing personal truths.
Despite a few early sparks of promise, The Brothers Grimm sputters and coughs along like an unoiled machine, grinding gears and nerves in equal measure.

In the rather less twisty [than Memento], if nicely kinked Belgian thriller The Memory of a Killer, the title character faces his own dangerous adversary, except that here the enemy hot on his heels is dementia.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The yummy Japanese confection Kamikaze Girls deserves both a better title and an audience to go with it.
A feature-length folly about the terrors and self-affirming joys of football (that is, soccer) hooliganism.
[Coppola's] revisions to the film, which include a new, improved soundtrack, invest it with grandeur worthy of both its characters and his own ambitions.
Nicolas Cage stars as a globe-trotting gunrunner in this misfire of a political satire about the international gun market.
A necrophiliac entertainment for the whole family to enjoy, Tim Burton's Corpse Bride marks the director's latest venture into the world of stop-motion animation.
Gwyneth Paltrow plays the daughter of a famous dead mathematician in John Maddens terribly serious film adaptation of the much-admired Broadway play.
To watch Jodie Foster storm through a phony airplane for an entire movie has its very minor pleasures, but there is nothing here to feed the head or fray the nerves.
A masterpiece of indirection and pure visceral thrills, David Cronenberg's latest mindblower is the feel-good, feel-bad movie of the year.
A drowsy comedy about a handful of kids grooving and roller-skating, Roll Bounce has heart and good vibes but little else to recommend it.
Joss Whedon's unassuming science-fiction adventure is superior in almost every respect to George Lucas's aggressively more ambitious screen entertainments.
A soggy adventure best suited to DVD-rental desperation.
Richard Linklater's enjoyable remake is filled with small, cute kids and large, goofy laughs.
Love doesn't just hurt in the jagged German romance Head-On; it cuts and bleeds and even kills.
A deeply conventional story about truculent or orphaned boys and the gentle soul who finds himself by shaping the tots into a chorus.
The latest Hollywood movie to give comic books a bad name, Elektra stars Jennifer Garner as a superheroine who dons fetish-wear the color of blood before laying waste to every man in sight.

An amorphous, laugh-flecked drama about a New York City pickpocket that mostly comes across as a feature-length advertisement for its likable star and writer, Peter Facinelli.
Whether he's slowing down time or ignoring its rules altogether, Mr. Kormakur's eccentric pacing brings its own dividends, as does what really gets him going in the film.
It's only fitting that Harry Belafonte's big, bountiful life has inspired an expansive, understandably hagiographic documentary, "Sing Your Song."
A smart, effectively unsettling movie about the need to believe and the hard, cruel arts of persuasion.
An appealing, largely upbeat documentary about young ballet dancers duking it out, sometimes on point and in tulle, for top honors at the Youth America Grand Prix.
While it's frustrating that Mr. Palmer doesn't dig deep into the complexities of the fights, one of the movie's strengths is the honesty with which he confesses his doubts about them.

"Dark Shadows" isn't among Mr. Burton's most richly realized works, but it's very enjoyable, visually sumptuous and, despite its lugubrious source material and a sporadic tremor of violence, surprisingly effervescent.
While "Celeste and Jesse" is decidedly conventional in most respects, it's pretty swell as an exploration of a relationship between a man and a woman that's no longer predicated by mutual desire.

Mr. Morgan has written some good movies, notably "The Queen," and Mr. Meirelles has won fans for neo-exploitation titles like "City of God." There's no way to know what went wrong with "360" and whether it was this uninvolving and shallow from the start.

The story, an amusing if not especially fresh tale involving a witch and some Puritans, is principally a vehicle for the movie's meticulously detailed pictorial beauty, which turns each scene into an occasion for discovery and sometimes delight.

Frank Langella plays so many variations on cute and crotchety and with such suppleness - he's by turns a charming codger, a silver fox and a wise graybeard - that his performance comes close to a saving grace.
A largely likable tale about a 38-year-old man-child trying finally to grow up.

Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types - few prettier than its lead, Joseph Gordon-Levitt - and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon.
[A] dramatically unsteady, blustery if likable film, which was adapted by Judy Morris from the Patrick White novel.

The movie is apparently the most popular British comedy in history. I guarantee that its success has nothing to do with the quality of the actual movie ...
Mr. Gere is one of cinema's great walkers, graced with a suggestively predatory physical suppleness, and he slips through the movie like a panther. He's the film's most deluxe item.
A muscular, maddening exploitation movie embellished with art-house style and anchored by solid performances.

Dizzily enjoyable ...

movie_review_blurb: Likable, unsurprising and principally a showcase for the pretty young cast, notably Mr. Miller, who brings texture to his witty if sensitive gay quipster.

A dreamy, elliptical neo-noir about a cop turned killer turned something else altogether.

Lurches from realism to corn-pone absurdism and exploitation-cinema surrealism.

A tender, wrenching, impeccably directed story of love and death.

"No" is an ugly looking movie - literally - for an ugly time. It's smeary, with little pictorial beauty or detail, but its anti-aesthetic is purposeful and, after your eyes stop hurting, watchable and persuasive.
A hugely appealing documentary about fans, faith and an enigmatic Age of Aquarius musician who burned bright and hopeful before disappearing.

The grave and satisfying finish to Mr. Nolan's operatic bat-trilogy.

Where's Mike Tyson when you need him?
No fun costume change in a phone booth, no wowing humans with his powers and no repartee with reporter Lois Lane.
Depp has done the kooky, costumed character shtick so many times, it's no longer surprising to see him bury his index finger into the desert sand, then lick it
It's an unflinching, 360-degree character portrait.
The exquisite Blanchett amazes, bringing brittleness and vulnerability to a woman on the edge.
Naturally, there are roadblocks galore -- but the breezy film stays one mile ahead in terms of plot and punch lines
Amusing stunt casting aside, it's riveting to observe how civil rights evolved from inside the Oval Office
There's a distinct possibility that you don't know or care a lick about Formula 1 racing. After this sexy thrill ride, you will
A frustrating puzzle in which the pieces don't quite fit together
An utterly delightful, grown-up romantic comedy
With so many scenes that end in harsh emotional purging, there's little opportunity for the cast to put the fun in dysfunctional.
A positively harrowing and gut-wrenching true story that gets everything right.
The unreliable, brooding Llewyn is a prickly sort, making it a challenge for his industry - and movie audiences - to fully embrace him. And yet, the talent is undeniable.
Ryan returns in a quick-footed reboot that does its duty as an escape from the January doldrums.
The wildly evocative film proves there's a Lou Bloom lurking inside most of us. He's just the one willing to cross the yellow police tape.
It's like the silly, superhero-loving kids goofing off in the back of the classroom looked at The Avengers and X-Men and declared, "Hey, how hard can it be to save the world? Let's do it too!"
An enchanting look at unlikely powers of love, this comedy is fluffier than a croissant just out of the oven. That's not good enough.
A wonderfully offbeat film about, yes, an abortion.
We'll have what they're having.
Two years after Jennifer Lawrence appeared in David O. Russell's American Hustle, she gets to show some.
As this riveting documentary proves, two thumbs up made up only a small part of the total man.
This is more than a groundbreaker: It's a new American classic.
Don't know how the special effects team pulled this off; don't want to know.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's not funny. None of it. Only the most juvenile of moviegoers want to see a heroine fall on her face over and over physically and emotionally

This tepid fourth installment is actually an improvement over 2011's ridiculous Dark of the Moon entry. But that's like saying the flu is better than pneumonia. Either way, a high threshold for pain is required.
The 51-year-old Cruise clearly relishes playing the flawed hero - one who gets to be smarmy, duplicitous, exasperated, intimidated, bad-ass and wise.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: See? You don't always need vampires and factions to show teens in all their angst-filled, acid-tongued and hopeful glory.
There's an ultrasappy, unnecessary and modern spin on the classic happily ever after. You know, because so many people have complained for centuries that the end needed a do-over.
Consider this review as confirmation of your fears and hopes: The flick is really really really really dumb - yet gets by thanks to the sweet chemistry of its stars.

This could have easily been one of those blockbusters that seemed tantalizing in the crowded hallways of Comic-Con yet resulted in a convoluted disaster. What we have here is an electrifying ride that grips until its last frame.
Harping on a genuinely spirited and uplifting feel gooder is a little like booing the team mascot for acting too goofy on the field.
In terms of fun, it ranks somewhere between a friendly game of beer pong and a raucous toga party.
When it comes to creating chemistry on screen, Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone don't need any help from those whizzes in CGI department.
Depp appears mostly from the waist-up on a computer screen, mumbling in a monotone voice that would lull a cup of coffee to sleep.
Fans of this franchise should expect more than a boilerplate action flick that brings absolutely nothing new to the genre.
The thriller moves as fast as one of the speeding trains that Tris must learn to jump out of.
The adaptation is akin to a killer episode - plus a few swear words and a sexy PG-13 roll in the sheets thrown in for good measure.
Director Wes Anderson's films are so artistically exquisite that they should be framed and mounted. And this effort may be his most astounding.
Once again, Neeson carries a generic outing on his weary shoulders.
Clooney, who's grown into quite a versatile actor over the past decade, gives himself a role that he could phone in from his living room in Lake Cuomo.
And you thought The Hobbit was a fantasy.
Forget super. This bighearted and intelligent drama is supercalifragili. . . .you get the idea

George Clooney, Scarlett Johansson, Josh Brolin, Jonah Hill, Ralph Fiennes and Channing Tatum must really, really, really, really, really, really love working with writer-directors Joel and Ethan Coen.
The film is loaded with more good times than the last bachelorette party you pretended to have fun at while you secretly longed to be home bingeing Orange Is the New Black.
It's OK to go and enjoy this sugar-coated Girls Night Out flick. But don't be surprised if you're just not that into it.
It works as diverting entertainment. In fact, is it wrong to conclude it's the ideal movie to watch on an airplane?
In terms of a sequel besting the original, Blade Runner 2049 is not a unicorn. But it is a breathtaking, non-comformist achievement.
The ever-in-control Tom Cruise veers wildly off course in a lively, brash and ridiculously entertaining biopic. I hope I had you at "wildly."
You know an action movie doesn't work when the visual highlight is Elton John sitting at a piano dressed like an overstuffed turkey.
It's a true mind-melting wowza that rivets from the first seemingly innocent moment to the last dagger into the bleeding heart. (That's a metaphor. Maybe.)
Jessica Chastain tears into the rich material with the ferociousness of a starving wolf.
Just because a period movie screams "still so socially and politically relevant!" doesn't make it a riveting must-see.

It's a riveting coming-of-age yarn that centers on the horrors of being an adolescent. Irrational fears are shining bright. But loyal friends that stand by you can make all that the misery more tolerable.
Thinly drawn characters drift through a preposterous story in a Nancy Meyers production. Plus, the kitchen isn't even all that!
Billy Jean King wins. Not just the 1973 Battle of the Sexes tennis match against Bobby Riggs, but the hugely entertaining and inspiring movie of the same name. It's all aces.
Four years after his self-imposed retirement, maverick director Steven Soderbergh takes the easy way out. Or, rather, back in.
This brutally sharp satire that skewers celebrity in the social media age cuts deep.
In an electrifying performance, Robert Pattinson finally shows that he has range beyond that of a brooding, sleepy-eyed vampire.
Instead of a triumphant tale about perseverance, we get a glossed-over love letter to the joys of quirky hippie-dippy parenting.
Between his GQ appearance and drawling psychobabble, Matthew McConaughey plays the villain as if he's filming an extended version of a Lincoln commercial.
How nice to see Avengers Jeremy Renner and Elizabeth Olsen working together and acting heroically without all those wonderful toys.
Excuse me while I scan my phone for the vomit emoji.
The scenes are powerful; the characters are powerless. The result is a sense of utter claustrophobia and dread.
A potent mix of crass, sass, and (whoa) class.
The rush of cold open water leaves you shivering. A nosediving fighter plane causes you to gasp for air. An explosion makes you want to duck for cover. All that and . . . Harry Styles?!
The trilogy's intense yet introspective last chapter is engulfed in a heart of darkness.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is the reason why people rave about the golden age of television.
It's a near-miracle that six screenwriters were able to pool their talents and craft such a winsome, witty story.
Explain again why this madcap franchise is a cultural phenomenon worth a zillion dollars?
To quote the title of Roxy Music's New Wave hit that Coppola brilliantly employed in Lost in Translation, I expected more than this. More darkness. More suspense. More oomph.
It's a winning and genuinely funny rom-com that proves there's more than one way to a heart-swelling happily ever after. Call it The Big Crowd Pleaser.
By the 28th penis gag, audiences might be itching to exit this party early. The sober audiences, anyway.
Walk away from the straightforward legal drama and you will learn this towering, influential titular figure . . . was a smooth lawyer in 1940.
Bickering, bonding, bickering, bonding. This is really the best comedy vehicle Amy Schumer and Goldie Hawn could find?
This comedy of neurotic manners is so achingly, universally relatable that is feels like a documentary.
The off-kilter thriller was such an excruciating slow burn that I kept checking my watch, counting down the moments until the credits so the tension would subside.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director Ava DuVernay takes a classic story and, in a terribly misguided decision, spins it in 2018 wash cycle. The intentions are good; the results are disappointing.
Jennifer Lawrence and Joel Edgerton's chemistry is colder than Moscow in January.
Several months from now, you'll still be thinking about that unsettling closing image. Wow.
Snappily paced and cleverly plotted, Game Night is the rare farce that exceeds low-ish expectations.
Ryan Coogler has eschewed the familiar Marvel glut of smug in-jokes and mind-numbing CGI explosions to create a visually dazzling work of art.
Just turn off your brain and submit.
Though set in a post-apocalyptic universe, this uneven and unwieldy Maze Runner finale reeks of 2012.
The roll-up-the-sleeves-and-dig-in attitude is a joy to watch; the multitude of self-righteous monologues are anything but.
Co-writer and director Alexander Payne takes an intriguing premise and inexplicably flushes it down the toilet.
The Greatest Showman's performances are of the blustery jazz hands variety. Not the musical type? Out of luck. The narrative is peanuts.
The Bellas' musical journey has been stretched into a thin whimper.
A big-budget follow-up that doesn't unreel like a lazy money grab is a victory in of itself. Everybody wins this game.

The Last Jedi at its heart is a love letter to a childhood. From Luke's sly wink to an old friend to General Leia's leadership, the familiar heroes dominate the screen, earn the biggest applause and serve as a compass to the next generation.
The film's pitch-black humor is sharper than that of a skating blade.
There's enough dreamy beauty here to smooth out the rough edges. (Fish sex, anyone?)
The result is a hysterical and loving tribute sure to generate just as much raucous cheering as one of The Room's urban midnight screenings.
Call Me By Your Name is like a treasured artifact from your youth, back when withering looks from a first love felt like daggers to the heart.
Once again, Pixar delivers the most delightfuland insightful family movie of the season.
Justice League is just fine. But considering that the would-be blockbuster features a collection of A-list superheroes, the word "fine" is like kryptonite.
Denzel Washington, a movie star for a reason, fails to sell himself as a socially awkward introvert and self-proclaimed "man behind the curtain."
In a lavish, star-studded murder mystery, the big takeaway shouldn't be Kenneth Branagh's facial hair.
The narrative builds in admirably inventive and surprising ways. You'll have to see it twice just to appreciate it.
Lady Bird is an angsty coming-of-age tale set in 2002 that feels remarkably and delightfully fresh.
Thor 1.0 grumbled as he saved the world; new Thor 2.0 makes small talk with a skeleton to pass the time. The latter works better.
The sharply observed, wryly funny work for addresses difficult questions about race and class that most people usually just whisper about.
Ben Stiller's follow-up to his 2001 mini-classic is ridiculously funny. Stupid and unnecessary ... but funny.
It's a beautifully crafted story about love and acceptance and the powers of child-like curiosity.
For his directorial debut, Andy Serkis eschews sleek motion-capture technology to focus on an old-fashioned (albeit safe) love story.
What a wasted chance at, ahem, a bouncy start of the summer movie season.
Director Sean Baker's sun-drenched, pastel-colored drama has a vibrant energy even amid the most heartbreaking moments
For the sequel, writer-director James Gunn has doubled down on all his once-nifty novelties. Strip them away and what remains is a bloated semi-mess.
Watching that airplane land on the Hudson River is a heart-stopping wonder. But the entire ordeal lasted just 208 seconds. The movie is 96 minutes.
The most biting comedy of the summer has nothing to do with talking pets.
He bears the nickname of a comic book hero, the brains of a scholar, the soul of a rebel. And his story is a richly rewarding film experience.
You don't need to know Steve Gleason's name to be enraptured by his extraordinary story.
Guess who's headed for another Oscar nomination.
The tension and anger in this neo-Western practically radiate off the screen.
David Ayer's flash-and-dash directing style makes it a challenge to follow the story, not to mention a chore to process the onslaught of violence.
The raunchy comedy is the equivalent of drinking a poolside margarita while the kids are at camp. It's a load of empty calories -- but, boy, does it go down easy.
It's freewheeling enough to entertain a casual moviegoer - and faithful enough to satisfy a Comic-Con nerd.

The talented stars are not to blame for a pointless, harmless and mildly funny remake that will leave most moviegoers shrugging their shoulders and musing, "well, at least it's better than Ghostbusters 2."
Zac Efron's goofy comedic chops have become even more defined than his abs.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The drama is so dreadful that you will root for the apes to eat the evil humans just so it will end faster.
The film's one fresh angle - the relationship between Brad and Brett - is relegated to the B-side during the debauchery.
Sometimes it takes a plucky animated fish to illustrate the benefits of thinking on your fins (er, feet). Now that's a lesson worth retaining.
Don't bother unless you have a deep emotional investment in the history of Professor X's hair loss and Jean Grey's skills set.
You won't see Captain America and Iron Man squaring off at an airport, but you do get Russell Crowe breaking Ryan Gosling's arm and then cheerfully downing a Yoo-hoo.
No matter how many times Jack O'Connell waves his gun in the air and threatens to detonate the place with a bomb, you never truly believe anyone's life is in danger.
It's a rollicking and action-packed extravaganza in which every superhero has a moment to shine.
Charlize Theron is offscreen for a full hour, presumably reading better scripts.
A dazzling, charming and utterly immersive 3-D experience, it's sure to capture the imagination of moviegoers of all ages.
The gifted Melissa McCarthy has spent the bulk of her post-Bridesmaids career elevating so-so material. Add this raunchy comedy to the pile of mediocrity.
A popcorn film - and this is  a popcorn film - should never feel like Sunday night homework.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All the plots are blah sitcom material, at best - and there's a reason why Vardalos' CBS spinoff, My Big Fat Greek Life, lasted all of seven episodes back in 2003.
Let's be Candor: This franchise is tumbling downhill at an alarming speed.
For the love of Google, don't scour the web for third-act spoilers. Just know that an old-fashioned scary movie can still make you squirm, laugh and gasp for air.
In her most impressive role to date, Tina Fey plays a journalist in the throes of an identity crisis. Alas, her movie has one too.
The fault is not in our stars. In breakout performances, Emilia Clarke and Sam Claflin are magnetic as soulmates doomed by a Dire Medical Prognosis.
Who's the daddy? Who cares! What's really important is that after a 12-year absence from the big screen, the lovably flawed singleton remains true to herself.
Even if you're not aware of this real-life story, you'll recognize the well-worn narrative of dudes who hustle their way to the top - only to see it all fall apart in spectacular fashion.
Peter Berg directs the action onboard the fiery rig with a tense urgency. After all, these workers can't just run out of a building into fresh air or pull over on the side of the road.
Buckle up knowing that this once-gritty franchise has officially reached the point of no return.
There's something glorious about Spider-Man, Edward Cullen and a would-be Christian Grey coming together in a highbrow drama.
When Emma Watson walks down the staircase in that iconic yellow ball gown, it's as true (and goose bump-inducing) as it can be.
This ferocious beast is the reason CGI was created!
Just because a comic book flick takes the dirt road less traveled doesn't mean it's a cinematic work of art.
Only a master satirist like Jordan Peele could take audiences on an insane thrill ride and make us all think about racial stereotyping along the way.
You will most definitely care more about Anastasia Steele's red lipstick shade than her tortured romance with cold billionaire Christian Grey.
Everything is still awesome in the irreverent Lego Movie universe!!! All right, maybe not everything. But enough things.
In space, no one can hear you flirt.
Somewhere in a forest, a maple tree wants all its sap back.

Hard-core fans who thought Episode VII was a dumbed-down rehash will bask in an action-packed film that refuses to spoon-feed information. Mind you, that's the same reason why the casual fan will be disengaged.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The remake of the 1960 classic Western moseys along at the pace of a long-in-the-tooth horse.
Natalie Portman depicts the former First Lady not as an enigmatic glamour icon, but as a flesh-and-blood woman grieving her husband - as well the end of her fairy-tale Camelot life.
The indie drama touches on themes of race, sexuality and isolation in ways that are rarely depicted in cinema.
A gorgeous homage to the golden age of Hollywood musicals in the 1950s, the film has the power to make audiences laugh, weep and feel as if they can float on air.
It's a masterful, all-American tale that delves deep into the black hole of grief. At times, it can all be emotionally overwhelming - but isn't that a characteristic of a great movie?
The real mystery: How did a spine-tingling bestseller turn into a plodding Lifetime-esque melodrama that's devoid of suspense?
Thanks to its edgy sense of humor and achingly accurate poignancy, the flick will touch a nerve with anyone who has ever had to ride that tidal wave of teenage angst. By the way, that's everybody.
Nobody is having much fun here. Well, except for Doctor Strange's devilish Cloak of Levitation.
The sci-fi thriller not only subverts expectations in brilliant ways, it explores deeply felt themes of life, loss and love. In other words, it's light-years away from Independence Day 3.
Every person who puts on the special glasses will be able to see that expensive effects can't cover for clunky dialogue and a story more tired than a college student with mono.
Hold the audit: The thriller ever-so-slightly succeeds because it has the smarts to bask in its own ridiculousness.
For holiday family entertainment, it does not get better than a fantastically lush Disney musical.
Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard's unbridled passion drives this satisfying period piece.
Ditch the cynicism; take the Kleenex.
Designer turned director Tom Ford uses his gift for striking visuals to create a must-see.
Rowling, who wrote the screenplay, has layered a sophisticated and surprisingly dark origin story that will appeal more to grownups than the younger set.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For all of Wonder Woman's nifty weapons, the one that proves most indispensable is her chemistry with Chris Pine's ultra-charismatic American spy Steve Trevor.
It's pretty clear by now that characters in sci-fi movies have never seen a sci-fi movie.
Just as you think to yourself, ''This flick would be way better if it had Van Damme playing twins,'' along comes a plot twist so ingenious that it almost redeems the rest of the flick.
The big innovation here is that the two nimble leads, stuntmen-turned-stars, are devotees of parkour, a fancy French word for the fluid use of urban environments as jungle gyms.
It's silly, at times laughable, sure, but Jaa has a reckless, bone-cracking grace that transcends the film's triviality. For fight fans, he's worth the price of admission.
Cheesy enough to satisfy your B-movie cravings in half Grindhouse's running time.
For a second, the movie has the snap of a truly surprising thriller... But then we go back to following the kid, who manages to both mope and strut along the path to manhood.
In this post-Apatow-the-arrested-development-genius world, it can't compete. The only thing worth watching is Sarandon, popping in from a classier reality.

There's a breezy propulsion to An Adventure in Space and Time - written by Sherlock's Mark Gatiss, a member of the Steven Moffat mafia - as it charts the evolution of Doctor Who and the invention of so many things beloved by Whovians the world over.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Without Underwood and Moyer selling us on this legendary love story, The Sound of Music Live plays like very expensive karaoke.
You wouldn't think a movie called Need For Speed would feel so slow.

As a nerd and as a black man, I've been waiting for this movie for my entire life, whether I knew it or not. The fact that Black Panther gets so much right, but one crucial thing wrong, is both thrilling and maddening.
The adaptation is a shallow sci-fi spectacle that almost makes you care.
Entertaining and clever, Tim Burton is right at home with his latest film.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite being a little heavy and disjointed, this is irreverent, mad-cap fun.
movie_title: They Call Me Jeeg (Lo chiamavano Jeeg Robot) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more fulfilling buddy flicks in the past few decades, one that's nearly on par with Edgar Wright fare.
Do's film is sluggishly paced with mundane drama that doesn't really make a splash.
A gripping character study that succeeds because of the minimal effects and fanfare.
The Keeping Room shines thanks to exchanges between Brit Marling, Hailee Steinfeld and Muna Otaru.
Sly, pensive and punctuated by the right amount of wrong elements to help keep you in suspense for the duration.
A stellar and ambitious sci-fi gem that just gives and gives. Top notch in every category.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A valuable and deeply haunting portrait of a social activist who lived and died for the highest ideals.
Evokes a handful of compelling and tantalizing passages.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Chomsky's rapier-sharp intelligence, his curmudgeonly wit, his goofy charisma -- not to mention his considerable political acumen -- are all but lost in this sometimes-lugubrious hodgepodge.
movie_title: Power and Terror: Noam Chomsky in Our Times (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Acut-price, transatlantic version of Amelie that keeps you at clinical distance, when you need to see the world through their eyes.
Kick Ass. It's epic. Intimate. Genuine and genuinely messed-up.
As far as blatant milking of cash-cows go, it retains much of the heart and charm of the franchise, if not the cracking humour.
Smart, intense, tragic, blackly funny, atmospheric and freaking awesome.
The movie wasn't so much directed as it was designed.
Funny, inventive, touching; flawless.
Tighter, scarier; this is the best of the Twilight films. Which is a lot like saying that getting punched is better than being stabbed.
A decent family film that shows how cultural accuracy is optional, hanging with strange old men is fine and all of life's problems can be solved with a roundhouse kick to the head.
Brain, meet spasm. Inception is the cleverest, most original use of a Blockbuster budget we've seen in years. Shame some of the characters are a bit underdeveloped.
A smart, funny, insightful take on the dynamics of Modern Families. It taps into both the universal and specific dynamics of the family unit. Bening gives a career best performance.
The most unintentionally homoerotic film of the year. Eventually you start willing them to make out. Solid script. Slightly unconvincing Clinton performance from Quaid.
You're not going to have huge laughs or terrible sadness or excitement. It's a bittersweet love letter to thespians of old.
Perfectly interprets the world of a slacker through the language of all the pop-culture slacker's consume (games, comics, music) Also, it's an epic nerd-splosion of pure molten awesome. FTW.

The Greyscale Adventures Of Tony Blair: SuperSpy (as I call it) is a deliberately directed, well acted and classy treatment of a plot that is so balls-out ridiculous I firmly believe the writer wears a tin-foil hat.

Patchy acting, fantastic action and some great slivers of humour in a movie that only gives off the faintest whiff of a xenophobic nation terrified of being invaded. It's not like the rest of the world didn't already think we were red-necks.
A raunchy rom-com that is surprisingly authentic in its emotions and hilariously obscene.
At its best when it finds humour and sadness in the grey areas between what is traditionally "right" and "wrong".
A movie fueled by the wet dreams and rage fantasies of a thousand pubescent boys. Perfectly attuned to its audience -- 3D boobs, gore and dodgy science abound.
A sweet, charming flick where the humour reverberates with authenticity. A case of plot drift and abandoned subplots hold it back, though.
In spite of Nic Cage's 'Hobo-with-a-leather-fetish' chic there are some inventive effects sequences. Feels likes like a watchable-but-unremarkable patchwork quilt of every fantasy flick ever made.
A well-made movie filled with authentic moments of humour and insight, If only the central character wasn't such an unlikeable tool.
It's a simple story, told well with some blinding performances.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Max Payne. Epic Fail.
It's not that the movie is bad -- it's definitely not a bad film. The source material, however had the makings of a BRILLIANT film.
If you're a fan of Ferrell's tangential humour, this is a blast with some particularly impressive directorial flourishes from McKay. Still not as funny/weird/demented as Anchorman.
It's a movie driving in neutral. It never really gets as clever, as emotional or as funny as I wanted it too.
Ironman is great fun, but it could've been better. And judging by interviews with director Jon Favreau the sequel sounds like it'll be a corker.
Oh, and if skin-crawling performances, complex storytelling, and profound ideas don't do it for you...did I mention that the film is completely badass?
Ten Empty is an exhausting film. But it doesn't offer anything back.
It's a trailer.
One of the most compelling, clever and insightful satires on the world of aussie party politics I've seen in a long time.
There comes a point when all this action starts to feel a bit mechanical.
The thing I loved most about this movie is just how ludicrous the whole thing is.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I'll give it this: Southland Tales is never boring.
Hey, it won't cure cancer. But it is a lot of fun.
You sense that we still only view something 'Aussie' as being impressive after a foreigner validates it.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You're constantly aware of the fluidity of memory, without being seriously distracted by it.
Without giving anything away, let's just say that the ending of Eagle Eye is about as subtle as being impaled to death by an American flag.
Honestly, if the makers of this ever got serious about making web-based comedy, I reckon that they would absolutely rock it.
It's flawed, but when Newcastle works, it rocks.
The plot's key turning points have either too much or not enough emphasis and are often in the wrong spot.
If you're a fan of the book, I'm so sorry.
The climax was so tense I actually fell off my chair. And the ending had me in tears. Tears of joy.
Sooner or later it becomes very hard to escape the sense that nothing actually happens in this film.
Zack and Miri may be a gross-out movie, but it's a damn clever one.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You couldve recast the whole film with a row of totem poles and I'm not 100% sure anyone would've noticed the difference.
Smart, funny and charming. Easy A is a textbook example of how to make a Hollywood teen comedy well -- save for a slightly too-neat ending.
A tight, surprising, well made action flick that relishes in macho-ness.
Knoxville's gang have transformed from 'a band of oddly resiliant dudes making dicks of themselves' to "men who really should know better". It's lost that essential youthful energy
Visually impressive, but the script needed a big angry red pen taken to it. Oh, and does every character need to shuffle around like they're in a My Chemical Romance video clip?
Far too neat and schmaltzy but otherwise a surprisingly witty film from the Dark City/Inception mould.
There is a limit to how many times one human can watch toothless, malnourished men stumble around the desert bitching about communism and a lack of borscht.
Unemployment is not a naturally cinematic thing. A far-too-neat conclusion notwithstanding, This is a decent exploration of the psychology of what happens when you loose your job.
Anthony Hopkins playing someone evil? SHOCKING. He is rather good at this schtick, but the script is flabby and cliche ridden. The young lead looks distractingly like an emo Ken doll too.
Stretches plausibility but enormously engaging with with rhythmic visuals, killer soundtrack and ballsy cast.
So badly scripted, performed and directed that it literally destroyed my faith in humanity.
A perfectly fine collection of ridiculous stunts and gratuitous explosions ruined by the addition of nonsensical plot and acting that appears to be submerged beneath weapons-grade painkillers.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: 4 good jokes do not a good comedy feature film make.
A fantastic big screen sensory experience that unfortunately has a plot built entirely from nonsensical technophilosphy wank
Stunning visuals, some suprising plot twists, dreadfully mediocre dialogue delivered by a woefully miscast James Franco.
Who would've thought that Emo Witches and Satanic Southern MILFS could end up being so entertaining?
Being punched in the face was easier that watching this movie.
A bit like watching the West Wing played by Amish People. Desperately needed 40 minutes cut out of what is essentially quite a beautifully made movie.
A film of infectious urgency, questionable accuracy, murky morality and undeniable emotional and intellectual power
A bloody masterpiece. Funny, Thrilling, cleverly structured.
Stunning design, clever twists and turns, strong performances and one of the best soundtracks in recent memory marred by one of the most patronising unnecessary voice-over narrations of all time.

Sparse, tense, beautiful... and strangely empty. The dialogue, plot and characterisation are nowhere near as deep or profound as the filmmakers seem to think they are.
